This presentation greatly detracts from the overall story and gets extremely tedious as the series progresses. Viewers want to see a good crime drama, not an exposé on the writers warped views of feminism. This hatred of men is evident throughout the show. All the male characters are thin and uninteresting. They are all doormats.The killer is also pretty much cookie-cutter unoriginal. He is interesting from the point of view of how he likes to invade his victim's lives and privacy. But the follow-through to his killings is ultimately boring. The writer tries to tie this man's aberrations as a normal part of male psyche. They keep trying to tie his behavior to his childhood -- which is simply idiotic. He's deranged -- as are all serial killers no matter what the BBC and Hollywood try to do. This tripe makes the whole investigation of the murders flawed since they are working off the wrong premise the entire time.The final flaw in this series is that they have all the time in the world to develop the story. It's just one detective and one killer. But they still leave gaping holes and pull things in from out of the blue -- such utter coincidence that it defies credulity. For example, somehow, the thug who lost is son and is beating his wife, just happens to know the reporter trying to cover the story on a first-name basis. This leads to a series of events that allows the final episode to end abruptly. There are several cases where random things like this happen in the show and there is simply no reason for it. There was plenty of time to develop a real series of events that make sense. It's just plain bad writing, direction, and editing that leads to these gaps.The ending is silly. It's extremely abrupt. I suppose they're trying for a cliff-hanger for season 3 (if there is going to be one)? But if they are, then it will be of soap-opera proportions. Pretty ridiculous.I'm disappointed in this series overall because of the reasons above. It could have been so much better than it was if the writer/director would have focused the story rather than his own political/sociological perceptions and views.

First let me say I never saw one episode of X-Files. I have only seen Gillian Anderson in "The House of Mirth," a period piece. Here she stars as the head of a Belfast investigation in "The Fall." Anderson plays Stella Gibson, sent to head up the investigation of a series of murders. It doesn't take her long to realize that they're linked.We see who the killer is, so there's no mystery there. What is intriguing is the psychology both of the killer and Stella. The killer becomes obsessed with her as he grows to hate her - she knows too much about him, and it's made him angry. So he makes it his business to know too much about her.We feel that Stella has a back story, a tragedy in her life - we aren't told what it is, but it's there. She gives away nothing. In the entire first two seasons, she has one moment of real emotion.I found the performance of Gillian Anderson mind-blowing. Colder than ice and professional, she's a woman who goes after sex the way a man does and makes no bones about it. She's detached from her team -- it's only late in the game when she shows a sign of friendship toward any of them. Great to see one of my favorites, Archie Panjabi, in this as a medical examiner.I don't want to give too much away. The story is multi-layered, the characters complicated. I'll just say the story is absorbing and intriguing, and the acting from everyone is wonderful, particularly Anderson, Jamie Dornan, Bronagh Waugh, and John Lynch.Looking forward to series 3.

Where do I even begin?About 60% of what you see on screen is completely irrelevant to the main plot. "Why are you showing me this?" I wondered again and again as minor characters engaged in meaningless conversations. Such a waste of time.When I did get to watch the main plot unravel, it became clear that sometimes it is better to have meaningless drivel instead. It was ludicrous! Spector is probably the worst, most careless serial killer ever. He leaves mementos of his deeds in practically plain sight for his daughter, wife and babysitter (yes) to find. His MO of a "warning" break-in prior to the fatal one ensures that he will be easy to capture once the pattern becomes clear. He uses gloves and mask but takes them off in the process, because why not show your face and leave prints for the nice cops. And he keeps a girlish scrapbook with drawings of his victims, which is probably supposed to be creepy but instead is quite ridiculous.Worst of all, he is a completely shallow character, as is Stella, the detective. Both are mind-numbingly dull, void of emotion or interest. They are further hindered by Dornan and Anderson's wooden acting.Seriously, I could find no redeeming qualities about this series. Bad writing, bad acting, just bad through and through. Why it is so highly rated is beyond me.

It gets one extra star from me for being a well made (with one critical exception) good story, but easily loses the other 8 because the whole story (both series combined) could have been told in a four episode mini-series, in which it might have been entertaining. Every single scene was edited abominably – At least 80% of it should have been edited out, including a lot of entirely redundant scenes. The Fall isn't really entertaining; instead because it's too slow it's an assault on your free time that is barely intriguing enough to keep you watching (if you're unlucky). It just doesn't provide enough value for your time by a long long way. I wish that I'd never started watching and I'm only wasting my time reviewing it now through pure altruism in the hope that anyone reading this will think again about buying the boxed set.

Caught this on Netflix and was hooked after the first episode. Sadly it didn't quite live up to it's expectations in the four remaining episodes. I did watch the whole series tho.Things I liked was definitely the portrayal of the killer. It was unlike I've seen before. Not necessarily the most believable one tho - the killer and his wife were not exactly a matching couple and I'm not sure if the character was that consistently written, but he was a psycho after all. Acting by Jamie Dornan is really good tho, I had never heard of him, but if he pulls off his next roles, he might have what it takes to be really big in silver screen.The ending was quite good. Many have criticized it, but I figured it was quite fitting and good. The police work was quite sloppy up until that point and they left a lot of stuff open, so maybe it's not the end of the story.That's sadly pretty much all there was good in my opinion. I didn't like Gillian Andersons portrayal of her quite unlikable character. She just flows thru the series, very uninteresting. Charismatic maybe, but not interesting. Most of the other performers were quite dull too.I felt that the whole series was a bit feminist by purpose. Like the producers had thought "let's make a detective series where we'll switch the (already dated) traditional male/female setup and let's make the males a lot dumber while at it". So most of the male characters were really weak and women were mostly perfect wives and mothers (with maybe one exception), vigorous man-eaters or content lesbians. Nothing really wrong with that, it just felt a bit too intentional and it took the focus out of the actual storyline. And I didn't really get the feeling that Gillian Anderson would be quite as desirable as they made her be. I think she was really uninteresting.Then there's a lot of subplots that didn't really have much to add for the story.I was initially interested in this being set in Belfast, but in my opinion this could've happened pretty much anywhere, the location didn't really matter that much.As a word of warning, the show is quite tense and at times difficult to watch as you get to see most of the killers actions first hand. The killings and the way he spends time with the dead victims is seriously disturbing. There are a few scenes that are really difficult to watch.I may give a chance for the rumored second season, but won't waste my time on the whole series if it's the same as the first season.

reviews.review_title: Series 3 of the "The Fall." A season without a reason. (Warning: Season 2 and 3 spoilers ahead)
reviews.content: If you could get past Gillian Anderson croaking out her lines and her perpetually stricken expression, the excellent story and Jamie Dornan's scary performance made the first two seasons of "The Fall" riveting drama. However, once Paul Spector, "The Belfast Strangler" was apprehended and Rose Stagg was saved, the story was done. Over.Based on its popularity the makers of "The Fall" decided to go for a third series which has turned out to be a huge mistake. Spector is in custody after being shot at the end of Season 2 and has suffered "memory loss" of all the murders. The problem with that is "who cares?" He made a full confession in Season 2, led them to Rose Stagg whom he'd kidnapped and stuffed in the trunk of his car and the cops have discovered a mountain of new evidence in another car he's stored in a garage. So, the only drama in this season is whether his faking his memory loss and whether he'll go to prison or a hospital for the criminally insane. Regardless of the outcome, this man is never going to walk free again. These are hardly the life and death stakes of the first two seasons and not nearly enough for us to endure Gillian Anderson for another six superfluous and tedious hours.

reviews.review_title: The devil lies in the detail, stark-gory-scary detail .
reviews.content: I believe you all are aware of the quality of BBC productions. At a stretch just now finished another one of their brilliant installments The Fall - TV. The success of a psycho serial killing show depends on the depiction of showing the intensity of the fetish perversion of that killer. The Fall did that job meticulously. Beautiful n Gorgeous Gillian Anderson was the best thing that could happen to her role. There is an unique vibe and glitter in her presence that showcase a staggering personality, that is what called a real show !The most perfect job that the show did was not exaggerating or over- qualifying the killer, nor glorifying or idolizing his motives. A serial killer always doesn't need to be recluse. He could a loving father to his children, a loving husband to his wife. He has to deal the redundancy and mundane cliché of the day to day life. But at the same time he could do the 'Doubling' perfectly. But when the hunter meets his perfect opponent, he could really get 'hunted' ! The devil lies in the detail, stark-gory-scary detail. And the details of this series parts it from others. You wont feel rush like the traditional USA releases, it takes time to build the story in UK production. But less dramatization and raw nature of the fetish was something 'sickening to the stomach' was present here that you won't be able to deny. This is dark, really really 'DARK', and if you don't have the stomach for that, don't come near here !

Yeah this series is pretty good in its own way. But it preaches feminism in an obvious way that is offensive and at times and laughable. The fact that many reviewers didn't see that is a shame, and shows the disrespect for men in general has become so pervasive in society that it's not not even recognized.
On the other hand there was an intense slow burn that I think was done very well. I see in other reviews complaints that the series was too slow but I didn't feel that way. I think it played out more like life does, at times terribly slow but a real sense of time passing.
Lastly, I like how they ended the series. Things came to conclusion in a bleak and chaotic way that felt real as well.

I stumbled upon "The Fall" by accident, and it was worth it-every minute! If you're into gore, or should we say, visual messy violence, this is not the show for you! It Is a little bit slow paced, but leads to agreat culmination. It raises all kinds of questions-real ones-what makes a murderer kill? How does the system work when dealing with psychopaths? Does the punishment meet the crime? It shows both sides-the side of the killer and the side of the police trying to catch him and bring him to justice. It's a deep story, one that looks very, very real-not like some horror shows that...well, you just know that what you're seeing is not possible, and it's not going to happen. Jamie Dornan does a great job (nothing to do with 50 shades of Grey), and Gillian Anderson is fantastic! Just see for yourself-if you like a dark story, with characters that have real problems-this one should do the job for you!

Apparently, it is a versatile and realistic series, but for me, it included too many elements I disliked. The pace was slow and disjunct, the wrongdoer was revealed too soon (less pondering on and over guilt), Season 3 started somewhat as a medical drama - and those I tend to skip... Jamie Dornan is great, Gillian Anderson - above average (I have never followed her career as avoided X-Files), the rest are just good artisans trying to get the most out of trivial characters... Based on the run of Season 1 I thought that next seasons would bring along different cases but lingering all this Gibson-Spector duo into 17 episodes of 1 hour soon became filled with unnecessary scenes and characters.True, compared to many US series, it is good, but I can name dozens of British series far catchier and more versatile... And the environment of Northern Ireland could have been more visible place in the Series.

reviews.review_title: If this is policing in Ireland someone needs to be fired
reviews.content: We know the formula for a modern TV show is that a white male always has to be the bad guy and the strong man-hating female lead has it in for him. Littered along the wreck of a plot there has to be female to female kissing etc etc.But I expected a plot that made some sense and a police force that actually efficiently rounds up the bad guy. I didn't expect a woman who was not only a Keystone cop but a sl*t on top of it to be the lead. None of the show is believable .Its very slow moving and bizarre .Its on the level of a bad pornographic movie with plastic characters thrown into the series like random darts given flight in a bar full of drunks.At the end of the second season the turgid lead Anderson is holding the killer rather than seeing if the man she slept with the night before is hurt after both were shot.A fitting end would have been the killer garroting the already lifeless Jillian Anderson and sparing her audience the misery of her acting . Above all, this show lacks any sense of propriety or decency .Its just plain creepy from start to finish.

Started off really good - Season 1 was pure thriller pleasure. Then Season 2 put the brakes on slowly but surely. Season 3 is a battle to get through, scenes are drawn out, far too much repetitive dialogue.

reviews.review_title: Just a loss of time, unfortunately
reviews.content: Worst turn off for series - Gillian Anderson's wooden face and acting COMPLETELY ruined series (as well as poorly written "strong, independent, feminist character). It started well, interesting, story builds up - and that's it. Should've stayed only on 1st season.Rest is just selling us short, prolonging it, so they could make some money, while giving nothing in return. One funny observation, also - the more episodes pass, more terrible Gillian's acting is. As if she wanted just to get over with.All in all, 1st season is good - but shouldn't even be watched, as it just takes your time, leading to bad plot/conversations, and ending - all rounded by wooden acting.
The first 2 seasons are excellent. Season 3 was lacklustre in comparison but still intriguing.Great performances all round.

reviews.review_title: Other reviews may miss the point: This story may have no heroes
reviews.content: Don't read this unless you've watched the entire first series of The Fall, as it's less an evaluation of overall quality than an argument about how viewers should interpret events.All the reviewers both professional and amateur have noted the parallels between the killer and DSI Gibson, but I think those parallels are meant to extend much further than most folks realize. Unless I'm really misreading things, it's wrong to view Gibson as a brilliant feminist heroine. She's as much a monster as the killer, a woman who hates men and wants to destroy them.Take, first, the scene that made so many women cheer. "Man, subject, f***s woman, object: no problem. Woman, subject, f***s man, object..." Yes, some people hold double standards about one-night stands, but that's not why Gibson's actions and demeanor disturbed her interlocutor. No decent person in 2013 believes that a senior exec of either sex should be able to order up a one-night stand from a junior employee, which is what she did. Furthermore, no decent person doesn't feel a bit bad upon learning that a one-night-stand was married with kids. Yes, it's the married person's responsibility to be faithful but decent people still don't sleep with married people and, if they do so mistakenly, feel a bit bad about it afterward.Not only doesn't Gibson feel bad on either front, she seems to enjoy both transgressions, the first because it demeans the man more and the second because it will help break up his marriage. Indeed, she's clearly pleased to hear that she nearly destroyed the assistant commissioner's marriage. She suppresses a little smirk when she says it would have been "unwise" for him to have left his wife for her.Consider, also, her choice for second-in-command: not an experienced detective (because all of them seemed to be male) but a female beat cop who was only known to Gibson because she had screwed up the case.More importantly, consider how differently she reacts to the death of women and me. She moves into the police station and devotes her life to hunting down the killer of three women she's never met but cares not one bit about the death of two cops, one of them a recent sexual partner. (And think about the moving-in bit. Others say it's supposed to show devotion but I think it's just supposed to show she's crazed in her attempt to avenge womankind. There has to be a hotel within five minutes of the station. No sane person would instead choose a cot and the resulting exhaustion?)What's more, I'm not sure she's really supposed to be all that good a police officer. She does no good police work during the show. She only gets near the killer because her colleague miraculously knows someone who survived an early choking attempt, because the killer's daughter sees herself on TV and because the killer screws up spectacularly in his last attempted kill.Perhaps I'm wrong, but I think the people behind The Fall intend her to be a monster. We'll see in the next series.

reviews.review_title: Season 1 was ok, rest is trash
reviews.content: So the first season was pretty good. For some strange reason the show insist on telling us that for a woman to be powerful she needs to have sex with random men - it makes no sense.Season 2 is where they ran out of material and the show grinds to a halt. Last episodes are as boring and slow as staring at a wall. I actually fell asleep during the season finale and after waking up half an hour later the same discussion was still going on.After starting to watch season 3 I just simply stopped - there was nothing of interest left and I'd rather put toothpicks in my eyes than waste anymore time with this garbage.

Gillian Anderson isn't so bad but certainly isn't the best female actor around. She is always the same character, shallow and predictable. Although in Fall she plays complex women, clearly disturbed and deranged, she make same expressions as since X-files. Now she is older, and tougher. But all in all it is same old Scully. And there's goofy Cantona... enough said. Hey, that's not so bad. What really bad in this show is - screenplay. In first, I thought this was written by some really angry woman, a feminist, or lesbian perhaps. But, to my own surprise, author was man (probably he i s a man, right?). What is wrong, you may ask? Everything. Everything is wrong here. Gillian Anderson is cold, emotionally distracted and deranged woman who wants to be and acts like a man. And that's just a half of a problem. I don't mind if there has to be some "cool" women, but this character goes to the edge. What I want to say? Remember capt. Jane from, Star Trek? If you do, you know how really woman in charge acts. Strictly and tightly, strongly, smart and cold-blooded but still feminine. This character of Gillian is like a zombie in comparison to Jane. She has almost no natural, human feelings and emotions. But, writer Allan wants her to be manly in every way. And not only that. She is totally deranged, and proof of that is scene with her and her partner Cantona, when she's saying to him (he is crying like hysterical woman, tried to kiss her and then she broke his nose!): "Maleness is a kind of birth defect." Really, Allan?? In first, I couldn't believe my own ears. Such stupidity you can hardly hear even from a mouth of the most bitterly feminists or lesbians. Author has serious issues or all of this was kind of a joke for feminists. Men in this show are, all of them, unworthy idiots. And women are in need of liberation, they are superior race who can exists without ridiculous and evil men... huh... Even now I'm laughing. OK, if we turn a blind eye, this was solid crime drama with just a few mistakes / stupidities. It could be better, and much dynamic, but for that we would need another author...

I don't know why everyone gives high praise to this lame series; if the main purpose of it was to show Gillian Anderson's wardrobe and an unbelievably clownish incompetence of an entire police operation, then yes, it gets a 10 at that. More than half the show the police are made look like stupid monkeys by a serial killer which is not doing anything special to anticipate or outmaneuver them. It's not like the killer has an extremely elaborate plan or is playing with them; no! It's just that the police are scripted to be plain stupid! At one point they have found their main suspect and he is in close range to them, but they still let him stroll right under their noses without making the first move (and no, the cliché of "let's leave him make his move so he takes us closer to where he is hiding the victim" is not even well developed to justify that dumb approach).And the other half of the series is to show Anderson's wardrobe and lust, which in the end has NOTHING to do with anything from the case; it's not even that the series is deep in character development, it's like the screenwriter thought "hey! Let's portray Gibson like a hungry cougar that takes to bed anything/anyone that stands near her. Oh! and let's include a lesbian kiss! yeah! Homosexuality out of the nothing should raise the ratings! ::genius::" I mean, Gillian Anderson is not even attractive enough to fit the role of a woman who is desired by everyone...A female detective who wears skirts, unbuttoned up to the cleavage silk blouses and 4 inches high heels to a crime scene on a muddy road by the country side... Seriously?????

I really like the first season but expected to see how the serial killer gets caught. By the middle of the second season I was getting too exasperated waiting & waiting. I liked all the the actors & thought they did just fine. The characters were interesting except for my usual distain for kids & teenagers in movies - this being no exception. The 15 year old conceited flirtatious teenager babysitter was hard to watch & the serial killer's daughter was a brat. I appreciated that there wasn't any graphic sex or nudity. I didn't finish the 3 seasons because in the middle of season two they hadn't caught him yet & started involving the babysitter. Even though she threatened him he doesn't kill her & starts being friends with her. That's unrealistic. Then when babysitter started doing crimes for him I thought that was way too over the top unrealistic. Aren't serial killers loners? Plus it's taking too long to catch him so I gave up the show.

I Loved this whole series. Gillian Anderson is my favourite actress, so she can do no wrong in my eyes! And Jamie Dornan in my opinion was perfect for the part.
Yes , it was slow in parts , and not every episode was as captivating but overall
it was tense and dark. For me the ending was fitting , I was so glad that it was NOT left open for another season, as so many other dramas seem to do automatically. All in all, a gripping and well acted drama .

reviews.review_title: A chillingly real portrayal of the hunt for a serial killer.
reviews.content: This to me has all the suffering so wonderfully dramatised by The Missing with all the driven energy of the detective side of shows such as Prime Suspect or The Tunnel. This is a truly riveting show, brilliantly acted, highly photogenic, and displaying all the professionalism and angst from the investigative side seamlessly contrasted with all heartache and tension of those around the identity of the killer, and the cold ice star of the killer himself.

I really wanted to like The Fall.Season 1: 8 stars. (Good actors and interesting story.)
Season 2: 5 stars. (Gillian suddenly starts to whisper when she talks - weird.)
Season 3: 1 star. (Nothing happens in this season, they're just milking it as much as possible. Gillian's pathetic whispering is extremely annoying in this season.)One last thing: When they operate on Spector there is almost no light in the operating room. An operating room without light? I laughed.

reviews.review_title: AMAZING - the most perfectly executed programme ever
reviews.content: Incredible script, incredible acting, incredible direction, incredible producing the best programme my husband and I have watched in so many years - I am hoping there is an series 2 and beyondwe were drawn so far into the story line - sat on the edge of our seats - this is the most perfectly executed programme I have seen - EVER!!Jamie Dornan was beyond words amazing - he had us feeling sorry for him - almost hoping he would not get caught - he had compassion yet an evil streak in him that was very alluring - as said previously perfectly executed script and acting to have this affect.I would give this series a 11 if possible.

reviews.review_title: Great Until Season 3... And Then "The Fall"
reviews.content: A very good series that for some reason went wrong in the last season. So many situations that could have been concluded... but instead it goes on this whole new bs path. Also there is much to much tedious time overall. Should have been a one season mini series. All in all I enjoyed it but Season 3 took it from a 10 to a 7.

''The Fall'' is a television series which radiates novelty and originality, consciously avoiding the clichés of the conventional shows and succeeds in leaving its own mark in the genre's tv productions history. The story is completed in three seasons consisting of a total of seventeen episodes, and we are introduced in the story of Paul Spector, a bereavement counselor, and serial rapist/murderer living in present-day's Belfast. Spector is struggling to juggle his family life, being married and a father of two little kids, and his secret impulses and actions and he seems to achieve his goal until a new Inspector from England, Stella Gibson, enters the picture. Gibson is a brilliant and driven police officer who becomes obsessed with the ''Belfast Strangler'' case and follows every single lead in order to apprehend him. This is the basis of the show's plot which unfolds in a rather slow pace, as it is mainly focused in the characters of the two protagonists and its development. ''The Fall'' is, above everything else, a character-study which dares to explore the dark side of humanity, represented by Spector and the complexity of human emotions as reflected in Gibsons's behavior. Jamie Dornan gives one of the best performances in a television series in the last years, portraying a deeply flawed but nevertheless human character devoid of empathy and for whom we sometimes, as viewers, find ourselves to root for despite his depraved and callous actions. Gillian Anderson (''X-Files'') does a fine job in her role as Stella, with her blunt and detached manner but her performance is overshadowed by Dornan's impeccable acting. This is a really dark show that doesn't offer any relief to the viewer but this murkiness makes it even more compelling and fascinating and you will probably binge-watch the three seasons. I haven't' seen any other Irish television series but ''The Fall'' made me curious enough to search for more productions from this beautiful country. If you are tired with the usual crime shows, you should definitely give this one a try and you will not regret it.

So at the end of season 1, the lead investigators have interviewed, pulled DNA, got a photo fit, & seen & spoken to the prime suspect in person and on the phone, they even have a name - the guy then leaves, burns his car with the evidence in & they still spend another 2 seasons trying to catch him?😂😂😂😂🙈🙈🙈🙄🙄🙄🙄

reviews.review_title: Decent (but slow) crime drama targeted at third-wave feminists
reviews.content: The Fall is a slow-paced, thoughtful drama that pits a sociopathic serial killer who strangles women to death against a sociopathic detective who bludgeons viewers to death with feminist clichés. Both actors are excellent in their roles.The series will appeal particularly to women who believe all men are fundamentally worthless scumbags, because every single male in the series is a fundamentally worthless scumbag. The men in the show range the whole gamut: street thugs, wife beaters, corrupt cops, low-IQ misogynists, serial-killer sympathizers, adulterers, rapists, weak-willed whiners. Every male character is deeply flawed, and no male character ever has an idea or makes a suggestion that is relevant or valuable to any pending investigation. There are heavy-handed implications throughout the series that all men are problematic and ultimately unnecessary.The plot is essentially the same as that of any serial-murder investigation, with the story more or less following the broad outline, pacing and atmosphere of the excellent move 'Manhunter' (1986).Both the protagonist and antagonist are written as complex characters; unfortunately, each of them has at least one dimension that is totally unbelievable. Dornan plays a family man and counselor by day and a murderer by night, leading to some interesting contrasts. But late in the series he also plays the stereotypical megalomaniac cat-and-mouse with his pursuers, and it doesn't fit his character at all. Dornan gives it his best, but the writing is a failure here.Andersen plays a bog-typical lead investigator, but with a penchant for cat-and- mouse games with all the men around her. Although her role does wonders for debunking stereotypes about women (e.g., can't be in charge, can't have one- night stands, can't be a willingly childless bachelor), she is unfortunately neither charismatic nor attractive enough to pull off all the sexy encounters with cops who look like magazine models. Although Andersen is an outstanding actor, and the script is fine, the casting just doesn't work here.There are few surprises, and the plot unfolds rather predictably. What keeps it going are the acting, the excellent music, the brooding atmosphere, and the fascination of killer, who is portrayed as sympathetic most of the time.The end of the series is an abrupt mess, with loose ends quickly tied up and a possible cliffhanger for Season 3. However, for those looking for a feminist agenda in classic crime drama, the series delivers in a big way. The women are all in charge, the men are all assholes, there are lots of incorrect and self-serving claims about the "matriarchal" Mosuo people of China, and if you really hate men, there's a lot here to make you feel good about yourself.6/10. Would have been 7/10 if the ending hadn't been such shite.

Really good show and had it not been for the constant down with men up with women messages being forced upon us it would be 10 stars. You have strong woman lead and lots of woman characters, there's no need for the constant woman power evil men comments. There would be outrage if it was the other way round. Just let us enjoy that story and grow to love the characters for who they are. Forcing sexist messages down people's throats is not the way to go. Ignore that nonsense and it is a very good show.

reviews.review_title: Started well but ended as a boring feminist propaganda
reviews.content: I thought the first and half of second season were captivating, but then it just all became slow, monotonous and boring. Also, the excessive over-the-top blatant feminist propaganda gets really annoying... Basically, there are no positive male characters and the very few there are appear weak and obey the women around them. If you're trying to convey messages as a filmmaker, it needs to be much more subtle, not just showing how terrible and weak men are and how strong women are. There are many inspiring movies and TV shows that empower women, without resorting to such distasteful innuendos and gratuitous preaching. So many cliches, how women must survive amidst the terrible patriarchy, how "men are afraid women will laugh at them, but women are afraid men will kill them" (this is a quote), just such banal, pathetic attempt to cater to a certain audience, and not even truly succeeding at it in the end. What a shame... Started out promising...

With successes like Broadchurch, Happy Valley and The Guilty, British crime dramas with fantastic casts and great writing are getting better and better in recent years, and this one from the BBC was no different. Basically a string of murders are occurring in Northern Ireland, and the Police Service are investigating, but after almost a month Detective Superintendent Stella Gibson (Gillian Anderson) of the London Metropolitan Police is called in to try and solve the case, with Jim Burns (John Lynch) as Assistant Chief Constable. Leading the investigation Stella and the local detectives must track down and stop the serial killer, Paul Spector (Jamie Dornan), who is stalking and murdering young professional women in Belfast, Stella is convinced that she is tracking the same man from a previous case. Through the series we see both Stella reviewing the investigation and doing everything she can to get close to and catch the dangerous man, and we seen see Paul living what seems an ordinary life with his wife and two children and working as a bereavement counsellor, but a psychopathic existence stalking and attacking women, it is essentially the lives of two hunters. The end of the first series saw Stella talking to Paul on the phone, he was speaking coldly and trying to convince her that she will not catch him, there will be a second series to continue the plot. Also starring Valene Kane as Rose Stagg, Sarah Beattie as Olivia Spector, Niamh McGrady as Danielle Ferrington, Bronagh Waugh as Sally Ann Spector, Siobhan McSweeney as Mary McCurdy and Ian McElhinney as Morgan Monroe. As the determined police woman Anderson is a fantastic leading actress, and as the twisted man stalking and killing innocent young professional women Dornan is a brilliant choice, the series is scripted well, and has the right amount of violence and thrills, gripping you all the way through, I cannot for the continuation, a great crime drama. Very good!

This series would have been better served had it ended with the second season. The third season is just a disaster unraveling everything that occurred in the first two seasons. Even in the second season the number of gaffes and unrealistic events are depicted which have to be overlooked in order to keep watching what is quickly becoming difficult. There's not a single truly likable character in the whole story and Gillian Anderson's portrayal of Stella Gibson is almost unbearable at times. Granted she's supposed to be an "ice queen" but her acting is so dull and stilted at times, she acts like she's on sleeping pills.

This should be a violent and disturbing series about a serial killer fixated with pretty, dark-haired women in their 30s, investigated from the female point of view of ace detective Stella Gibson. However and not being a misogynist, since I am a woman, I am quite fed up with her type of contemporary "heroine", usually a woman who has "sex like men" and who's always right.Stella looks like a femme fatale from a 40s movie, she's an icicle with "several" university degrees and who speaks in pretentious, indoctrinating sentences to the men around her, but in sweeter tones to women. Her one night-stand with a guy she just met is presented as her female right to objectify men... or whatever.It does not help that her antagonist is the equally icy and way creepier Paul, played by Jamie Dornan, an actor I don't find attractive even if he's an alleged chick magnet. Regardless of personal taste, his Paul is played as a cold, sarcastic, violent, withdrawn and unsympathetic character and it's impossible to imagine women attracted to him, such as his dumb, child-popping wife and the teenage babysitter.Two dispassionate main characters don't make for an engaging story, albeit the cold and wet Belfast background and some scenes add a bit of thrills to a plot that's quite predictable; at some stage they even go for that worn out cliche of the criminal and the police-person being the same... I could live happily without hearing that ever mentioned again in any thriller, but I was not that lucky this time.

Anderson only worked as an actor alongside good old Mulder of X Files. He was much the stronger character and her sullen disbelieving self was a counterpoint to his exuberance. This series just proved she can't remotely act. Anderson remains sullen to the point if boring and tedious. So many other good actresses could have done a much much better job. No wonder she's no longer in demand in the USA.

I feel bad for the viewers that didn't appreciate this series. I might be a little prejudiced but since seeing every episode of Xfiles & everything Gillian Anderson has done, I remain completely enthralled with her ability to portray a character with the depth she does. I was very impressed with Jamie Dorman as well. Look - this series isn't like what Americans are used to. It isn't bright & shiny, every character doesn't look like they came from Central Casting and THAT is why you should give it a chance. It's raw, and dark and if you let it - it will suck you in. It feels so much more REAL So it is very procedural and there's a lot of talking but it can take you places that pictures or actions might not. You might not like all details but that's closer to real. Let the power of your own mind and imagination and the brilliance of Gillian & Jamie transport you.I compare this to the works of Stephen King - whose written words can scare me deeper and longer than any of his movies. His books are extremely detail oriented but that's what draws you in. You feel there. His characters don't just eat dinner. They have freshly caught catfish, with tender golden French fries with a tall glass of iced tea with a splash of lemon.Give me details and procedures- and then the drama with have so much more.The end left me breathless and watching Gillian Anderson will never disappoint me

The show started out excellent, but as it moves on it becomes too obvious that every male character is evil, weak or moronic; or a combo of the 3. The scenarios become less and less believable. And Archie.. can't recall her last name ( the actress from "Good Wife") is so laughably unbelievable in her role. I literally had start laughing every time she came on screen; doing an autopsy in that prim and proper expression and body language.
But it is Season 3 that sinks it. The series is really pretty good. Gillian is always great. But IMo the problem is that they insisted on keeping the same plot and bad guy going. He was not all that fascinating. And Gillian's character either needed to become more twisted or go back to England. It became extremely boring. I just could not stay interested.

"The Fall: Tod in Belfast" initially convinced me a lot.The story of a nondescript family man trying to balance his life as an autonormal citizen and his existence as a serial killer is very interesting to watch.In addition, both Gillian Anderson and Jamie Dornan are very convincing in the leading roles.I also find the narrative style, which constantly switches between the perspective of the murderer and the investigation against him, superbly done.Now I come to the big BUT:
The killer is often described as intelligent, but the fact that he doesn't get caught is more due to a lot of happy coincidences.In addition, the series is very noticeably lengthened by the 3rd season and the ending is also very disappointing.In my opinion, the series would have been better off with a 2nd season concept with 7 episodes each and without the superfluous twist in the 3rd season.

reviews.review_title: A thriller which borders on near perfection!
reviews.content: For some odd reason there aren't a lot of psychological crime thrillers on US television, and I seem to be okay with it. Why? Because BBC fulfills that want with gripping, high-quality, crime dramas. The Fall is extraordinarily real, scary, compelling, and just outright excellent! Jamie Dornan delivers a performance that rivals to Ruth Wilson's, Alice Morgan, in Luther. However, Jamie is far more darker and closeted with his emotions. At times one almost feels empathy for him, and that is not right (he's a serial killer for goodness sakes!).Gillian Anderson plays the detective hunting Jamie Dornan's character. She, too, is controlling, dominant, intelligent and somewhat heartless. Although Gillian Anderson's character is aggressive and seeks respect for women, Mrs. Anderson plays the role in a way that the character doesn't come across as overbearing or a woman who has a feminist agenda.The only issues that I have with the show is: the dual storyline involving the death of a fellow police officer and the widow of one of the victim's of Jamie Dornan's character, and the absurdity of a fifteen year old always being home alone when Jamie Dornan's character comes to her house. I find it distracting at times. I'm selfish, I guess. I only want to watch the storyline involving Mr. Dornan's character and the detectives chasing him down.I highly recommend this show if you like to see how lines can get blurred when someone chooses to act on his or her fantasies that are not considered sane by most of society. It makes you ask the question: How does a person become the person that most people loathe-a murderer.
Down hill for the next two. Police and everybody else making stupid mistakes, doing things that make no sense. Drawn out series that lost my interest.
Just watched all the series of the fall. I had watched 1&2 a few years ago but never got round to watching the final one. I really enjoyed them all. What a spectacular ending. Would recommend it

Brilliant all the way.All three seasons kept me gripped.Superb acting great storyline and good adherence to policing procedures.One thing I noticed is Gibson's voice changes in season 3 to a raspy whisper which is quite strange.

reviews.review_title: Unbearably slow, unrealistic, and bad acting
reviews.content: I typically like British crime dramas. I enjoyed Broadchurch, The Stranger, Safe, Sherlock, etc.. However, this show was unbearable. First, Sally, played by Gillian Anderson, kept on whispering. She would have long pauses followed by whispers as if she was some deity whispering wisdom to everybody. She also came off as arrogant without anything to follow it up with because she made so many mistakes. Second, this show could have been made into four episodes, literally! I understand the character buildup but there were so many pointless scenes that went on for way too long. Thirdly, I'm not sure if this was the intention but it made British police look real inept. For example, they were tailing the killer but couldn't arrest him until some other cop checked on something somewhere else. The only thing this cop had to do was to look at a newly dead body. But instead of rushing to look at the body, she slowly strolls to where the body is, hears another cop come, strolls back down to talk to the cop in her annoying whispery voice, then slowly puts on gear, and slowly...you get the point. Would not recommend.

What a great show, the outstanding actors does it all, with great tension between these two, Gillian Anderson and Jamie Dornam, haven't heard of him before and yet for me, he did a great performance! 🇮🇪🇬🇧

Very good job with the first season.After that, all the story loses gripping going forward... I don't understand the third season ... pointless and really slow.The show it's really stuffed of moments of these infinte silences sighed , so hard to give them any reasonable meanings. The story is ended but the fiction keep going without saying anything really relevant. Not to fall asleep became so difficult at this point.Some characters are not relevant at all and so, ultimately is difficult to follow and understand their true part in this "should be" thriller-crime TV fiction.I do not suggest it, at all, if you feel sleepy.

Why could they not find a British actress? I love Gillian Anderson but why was she whispering the entire series? Dramatic effect? Was it the only way she could maintain her brittish accent? She was absolutely expressionless the entire series, and maintained the same tone. What was the deal with her dad? Why was it shown that she sleeps with random guys and that it's a bad thing? What ever happened to the sub plot in season 1 with the German guy and the prostitutes?Why was this series made, it was way way too slow, nothing original about it at all. Boy is sexually abused by priest, boy becomes angry man who becomes serial killer. "Tough" female cop brought in to catch him.By providing no background on any characters there's no connection therefore no one cares what happens to them. What happens to Katie? What happens to his wife and kids? Why did he kill himself? Why was a self proclaimed sadistic murderer allowed to wonder around?If you want a good cat and mouse killer vs cop show watch killing eve

This is truly awful. First series was watchable if you are able to ignore every scene Gillian Anderson is in. Her character is a disgusting women who gives her hotel room number to a younger detective she's only met for 2 minutes and he visits because apparently she's irresistible and later on asks for another younger detective to join her team only to have sex with him too.
This is made worse when the female pathologist she is having an innocent drink with gets hit on by a man offering to buy her a drink, Ms Anderson's response is to thrust herself onto the female, kissing her passionately and then being rude to the innocent man, the two women begin to make their way to her hotel room only for the pathologist to have second thoughts, maybe realising if Gillians acting is anything like her lovemaking then it's going to be a overly long, boring, wall staring, whispering and overall tedious affair. This appears to be a vanity project for her as she works her way through the Belfast police force one colleague at a time as if this is supposed to portray a strong, confident and professional female, unfortunately it comes across as if her characters lines were written by a disgruntled feminist who has obtained her views from watching loose women ( ITV midday programme ). If her character were a male character this series wouldn't have seen the light of day.Bad casting throughout. Main character and wife are not on the same level. I'm writing this review whilst trying to stay interested in series three but I'm really struggling as Gillian has become so irritating I just want to skip through her scenes. Devoid of any emotion of depth she fails to keep your attention as she stares smoulderingly at inanimate objects and whispers her lines and what is it with the 3-5 second pauses before she says anything? So many English actresses could've done a much better job.Plot and any sort of sense dissipates the longer you watch, especially as I enter series 3 as I'm watching Aisling Bea, who coincidentally resembles the killers victims, is left alone with him in the hospital after the shooting, I can see no police presence, they've all just gone home.I believe the bar has been set high in recent times and this just falls short of the minimum requirements.

A few blemishes: Anderson's aristocratic hauteur grows thin at times as does her moody posing and dramatic speechifying. Yeah, but: it's still terrific, brilliantly acted (even by Anderson, despite the cited annoyances), believable, terrifying and human. Seems like a brilliant fusion of story, evocation of place (Belfast), documentary accuracy, workplace reality, and the demonology of the truly evil. Even as you love Paul (Jamie Dorman) and yield to his charisma, you're thinking,, "Get this ------------ off Planet Earth please."

reviews.review_title: The most Pathetic Series I have wasted hours on
reviews.content:
I just have one question: is police so dumb and incompetent as shown in the series. Does Police really wait days watching the criminal and accomplices destroy and burn all evidence. And when all is burnt; they make a mess of the arrest. And that too when it is evident from very early on; who is the killer...
A series that could have been a 1 hour show is stretched to 3 seasons. They as well could have shown breakfast, lunch and dinner that each character has.

Who from her own stupidity that came from not listening to police to begin with made me feel the opposite of empathy, on her closure. She was a walking talking cliché owning a dildo, obviously fitting any cat burglars profile.The clever vixen cop was not so clever. Excuse me officer who is that, eyeballs bulging, another cliché. Stopping her job, to here have my hotel room number, few scenes later and the sex scene. This obviously comes while the victim is being murdered. Often acting a bitch to anyone else. Interested only in personal gain immediately after her choice encounter we see this nature which didn't use particular logic, must be cliché of a hunter.The killer is choker who actually funnily enough enjoys getting choked again a cliché of fetish but not a killer. He is a family man who leaves his young kids at home while he stalks. The kids don't phone the police being home alone for hours. I guess he didn't think to teach them yet. While the biggest cliché of the male juvenile he is a sex doodler often drawing women in a perverse manner obviously the makings of a serial killer.The police stupidly carrying guns to a burglary and will draw firearms with an innocent inside the house, then blaming the cat that must be because they are Irish. Or even call the person they have thought to investigate for clarity, when they always take down telephone numbers.If you want a cereal killer show which puts you to sleep or causes you to wake up getting a cup of coffee for breakfast. You must be as pretentious as those that when programming have prided themselves on a higher grade of viewing when it comes to complete and utter fiction.5 out of 10

Storyline is good enough, season 3 is predictable but not dragged, overall 6 stars. But both Gillian and Jamie are great, I was amazed by them, especially Gillian. I simply adore Stella, she's so convincing, human, you can feel her thoughts behind her mask, you are getting to know her more and more as the story develops. Paul is cliché but Jamie is a star. Thus 8 stars, +1 for each start of the show.Special thanks to Gillian ❤

I don't understand what is fuss about series?
Plot is just so so and acting by Gillian Anderson is just appalling.
She has no facial emotions, her face doesn't change, her pout is a fish pout and whisper. I can't really see her as leader neither charismatic or sexy, it just looks like desperate aging woman, full of botox and sleeping with younger guys. Thats all.
Movie could be better, but it could be shown all in one season, just too extended and boring third seson.

I suppose I felt guilty giving it one star. Soooo I watched it again with my laptop switched off. Okay ... TBF until the last episode it just about fell into the word entertainment with huge reservations.Like I made tea and coffee several times and missed nothing. TBH the running time could easily have been edited to half. It was unnecessarily long and drawn out with VERY little in the surprise and thrills department. The last episode was doing okay; until the end. A completely ridiculous finish in-so-far as the writer or the directer .. or even the producer; simply ran out of ideas on where to take it. I sighed, yawned and then realised ...IT WAS ON BBC2. Had it been any good it would have been on BBC1. So after suffering it one more time, would I watch the third series. NOPE, not a chance. I'm sure I'll have some paint to watch drying.

Her role and acting are just incredible and I have never seen such a strong and convincing character, Gillian Anderson steals the show with witty lines and plays hunting games with an elusive serial killer .

reviews.review_title: The BBC's crusade against "Toxic masculinity" in all it's glory
reviews.content: The irony that George Orwel's statue stands outside broadcasting house is only a testament to the fact that once upon a time they truly were the trustworthy "Aunty" to the public. But the woke agenda has infected the entire rotten thing now. It's no longer two legs bad, but ovaries good, testicles bad! The Fall had so much potential. and i really wanted to like it. There is literally not one single male character shown in, The Fall that is not flawed one way or another. Yes you would expect the serial killer to been viewed negatively. But the stereotypes for the rest of the male cast range from misogynist, drunk, lazy, inept and stupid to uncaring and violent with a few more thrown in just in case we don't get, the subtle message. The women of course are smart, sassy and professional the only time they appear flustered is because a stupid man had done something stupid and they have to pick up the pieces. I should have known from the first episode when they two police officers a man and a women go rushing off after receiving a phonecall about a dead body in a house. They arrive and the man who is built like a rugby player is told by the women to comfort the women who has found the body, he dutifully provides the gentle touch to the women while the slightly built women goes into the house alone to tackle a possible serial killer. Of course the lead character hears about this amazing women and instantly promotes her to work with her on the case, all with in earshot of her male partner who looks on with a, you go girl look of wonder. In another episode the wife of the serial killer decides to murder who two children by drugging them and drowning them, but is of course rescued by a passing women, while the cretinous male friend with her films it. It transpires that the women who attempted to murder her kids, is a victim of men and was forced to try and kill her two small children because men decided to prosecute her, against the wishes of Gillian Andersons charecter. The entire series is littered with this nonsense. I have nothing against showing women in positive lead roles, but good grief

A psychological thriller that examines the lives of two hunters. One is a serial killer who stalks his victims in and around Belfast and the other is a talented Detective Superintendent from the MET who is brought in to catch him.I started watching this because I like to support the original programming on Netflix. The first episode was not so great and the second was a bit lacking, too. But once the characters become more familiar, it quickly gets better as it goes. These are dense characters, which is a pleasant surprise.One only hopes the creators know when to call it quits. A story like this can only go so long before it becomes stale. Much more than twenty episodes and it would be too much.

'The Fall' is dark, gritty and gruesome look human nature. Many of the other reviews have focused on the 'sexuality, disturbing violence, blah, blah, blah' but the real focus should be on the masterful way the show is crafted to explore the fragile, damage and often unrelenting evil that exist in everyone- though in varying forms. I am sure if you have not watched the show, you are thinking 'what the hell does that mean' and those who have watched are like 'this chick is crazy' but allow me to attempt to explain.Gibson (Anderson) has the coldness and hardness of the woman she is meant to be, the acting is well and not something that needs an explanation. Her character is meant to be some sort of moral compass for the show, to expose, hunt, chase and capture the man responsible for the brutal deaths of women in Belfast. However, I find that she is not some beautiful woman in her mid-life that contains a moral compass- on the contraire; we learn that she is s narcissist, devious and arrogant woman. She has sex under her own terms, with who she wants, regardless of their marital status, keeps incompetence around her so she can manipulate, whether women or men, them when she needs to and secrets that wake her in the night. There is a name for people who act like thisand while we are meant to root for her to catch her killer, I was left with, she is obsessive, manipulative, and cunning. Perhaps to catch a killer is that to know your enemy you are best to be just like them.Which leads me to Spector (Dornan) and he is so creepy, the indifference of his idealist life (the wife, the kids, the home the steady job) is something that eats at him every day and it is evident in the way he lives in the dark, when he is alone. His character is complex, there is no obvious 'oh, you are a crazy murderer'. The audience, I believe, is meant to see him as a man who appears to have what everyone wants, yet finds that having everything is suffocating. I get that others will see him as some ruthless killer who deserves no sympathy, but they are missing the point. There is a reason for all actions and we are meant to find the why? And Dornan does an excellent job of showing brokenness, animosity, hatred, and even moments of compassion (but not where one would expect). There are no clear excuses for him, I mean he kills women for no point (so it seems) simply because he has lost control of his own life and craves it somewhere. His outlet is the hunt, the capture, the ability to suffocate someone else.Past the violence and death emerges the fact that there is little difference between him and Gibson (Anderson) except her way of obsession is legal (and we have yet to see her physically take a life, but she does damage nonetheless).The subplots are what slow the show down. I really do not care about the rich-coke-man-boy and his daddy issues, nor the life of dirty cops. If Series Two can tie all these together, that would be helpful and surprising.Overall, this is a great export from across the pond and if you can get past the imagery of death and violence you are in for a deep investigation into evil, whether accidental or deliberate.

Now this is the kind of television series I like. A nice thriller that makes you want to watch the next episode immediately. I saw the two seasons in only a week time. That's how much I liked it. The absolute star is Jamie Dornan (as Paul Spector). He completely nailed it as the normal day-to-day person and sexual predator. It was really a joy to watch his performance. It could be anybody, it could be your neighbor. I was wondering about Gillian Anderson, because when you think about her you obviously going to think about Scully from The X-Files. Her acting was not bad but not stunning either. Like I said before it's all about Jamie Dornan to me in The Fall. The storyline keeps you on the edge of your seat during all episodes. I really enjoyed it and will surely watch it again in the future.

reviews.review_title: Man am I happy i stumbled onto this on Netflix
reviews.content:
THE FALL Review
(UK TV Series)Terrific piece of television.
Great characters, gripping story, brilliant cinematography and tone, everything syncs into place in this serial killer story, the likes of which unfortunately will never attain the popularity or reach of lesser-qualified American TV shows. Dexter maybe had a better group of characters in more number, but "the Fall" does a great job of developing its characters and their various shades within a short span of 17 episodes.Gillian Anderson powers through as the ice-cold Detective Superintendent Inspector Stella Gibson, relentless and ruthless in pursuit of her prey. Anderson has made a career out of playing similar women; career-oriented, tough and no-nonsense, carving a significant place for herself in this man's world. She's more of Doctor Bedelia du Maurier from Hannibal than FBI Agent Dana Scully from X-Files here, as she intimidates men, even of superior positions, as she leads the hunt for the Belfast Strangler.Jamie Dornan, a polarizing choice to play eccentric billionaire Christian Grey in '50 Shades' series, proves that he is not just another pretty model. He turns in an excellent performance as the intelligent serial killer who is a slave to his needs and desires. Unlike the usual pop culture serial killers like Hannibal and Dexter, he is not an invincible opponent who eludes the police and stays ten steps ahead of everybody. He has the façade of a family man, yet he clearly loves his daughter, and has more than passable affection for his son. His choice in wife seems to have been calculated, but he is unable to entirely keep away from the normal range of human emotions. Ultimately, it is his inability to keep his twisted desires in check that starts to wreak havoc in his life, and catches the attention of Gibson.Other characters, even given less screentime, are etched out beautifully, showing the capability of the actors playing them and the strength of the writing. I wouldn't describe the other players here. It is not because ultimately they are not the main attraction of the plot. In fact, because of the strong screenplay, the moments given to side characters become crucial in the storyline. I would want the viewers to find out for themselves and enjoy the show more.Direction: 8
Screenplay: 8.5
Acting: 8.5
Music: 7.5
Overall: 8

reviews.review_title: It's not as good as I'd hoped
reviews.content: I really wanted to recommend this because it has some good points like the camera work, production & characters and some of the acting. I love the overhead camera work and the juxtaposition of events that are occurring at different locations. Some of that direction and editing is very clever. Also the portrayal of the killer is exceptionally well done on the part of the actor, the script and the director. It's quite a unique take on the traditional way a serial killer is portrayed.Unfortunately it's let down by a couple of major issues. One is that it's TOO SLOW. Yes, I know it's trendy to say this is supposedly a good thing because it's intense and builds slowly etc but the truth is, it's not good at all. It's boring, full of irrelevancies and makes you want to skip bits. I would love to find a decent quality British murder/mystery series that wasn't excruciatingly slow and dull in between the interesting highlights. I always feel like these shows would have been better done in half the episodes with a lot of filler & sub- plots removed. Anyway, another problem is Gillian Anderson who just doesn't carry the show well. Her acting is wooden and uninspired and she seems to have only one expression - vaguely puzzled with a tinge of angst. I'm pretty sure that's how she looked all throughout the X Files series too. Some of her scenes had me almost nodding off to sleep they were so dull.Another problem is that the series is VERY DARK. Not just "Dexter" dark but deeply grim and creepy and disturbing. I don't mind dark but you need something to pull you along when a show is this depressing & violent. Like characters you relate to or some humor or anything that provides a little light to off-set the constant bleak darkness. This is just a lot of horrible people being horrible to each other and terrible shocking things happening to everyone, whether or not they even relate to the story being told. None of the characters are particularly likable either so it's not as if anything that happens makes you care about anyone.And finally, the finale was rubbish. The plot had been developing reasonably well until that point (it IS an interesting plot despite all the flaws) then it's as if everything fell apart. The clever bad dude started acting like a complete moron, the police didn't notice astoundingly obvious things that happened right in the police station and Gillian's character got freaky & weird with nail polish for no apparent reason. And there was absolutely no pay-off or resolution or even a hint of where this might go next. There was no cliff hanger, no answers to the main plot questions and there were a million other unresolved sub-plot issues that I'm not even sure I cared about anyway. It was all terribly disappointing and I felt like I wasted several hours for nothing. I hear there will be a season 2 but I'm not sure I can stand watching it just to see if it gets better or anything ever gets resolved. Especially when it's as unrelentingly dark as this was.

This show is amazing, and even stands out in the British market where there are so many great shows. Gillian Anderson plays her role masterfully, wiping any traces of Dana Scully out of my head. Jamie Dorman is a wicked mastermind villain.The show is a slow burn at times. This seems to be a recurring complaint these days. I can't say I've ever had a problem with the pace of a well written show.Definitely recommend.

All 5 episodes of "The Fall" were great. Well into the 5th episode you wonder how this suspense thriller is going to be resolved. But sadly, it is not. This is one of the worst endings I have ever seen in this type of 5/episodes, 5/days mini series format. When its over you just say to yourself, "are you kidding me". You couldn't wrap this thing up? If you sit through 5 episodes of a thriller, you are invested in the outcome, it seems to me that it is incumbent on the writers, producers/directors to not do that to your viewers. The ending made me angry, and sad at the same time. To begin with this thing is a creep/fest, it will creep you out, so how does sitting through something that is creepy make any sense? At the end the guy gets whats coming to him, there is a resolution,... except here, there are no resolutions. Watch it and judge for yourself.

reviews.review_title: Excited to see the next season
reviews.content: So far I've only watched the first three episodes and I'm looking forward to finishing season 1 today. I love the show so far. I like the slower pace and the focus on various story lines. My husband came home when I was in the middle of episode 1 and he was confused as to why we already knew who the killer is. He thought that it couldn't possibly be good since the 'mystery' was already taken away but he ended up watching the next two episodes with me. Even he got hooked. I love that we know who the killer is right away because we can see what he does leading up to the murder and try to find the signs in his life that everyone else is obviously missing (I would miss them too if I didn't already know that he's a serial killer!). To me this show exerts a different kind of terror because he seems like so many other people. He even seems respectable on the surface with a good career (as a grief counselor!) and a wife and kids.I wish more shows today were like this. I've had a hard time lately finding a show that I can really get into but I'm already hooked on this one and looking forward to the next season.On a side note other women must be more trusting than me because when we watched a scene with the nanny I told my husband that there's no way I would hire a cute 15 year old nanny and leave her alone with my husband!

reviews.review_title: Great series thanks to the female lead
reviews.content: Gillian Anderson is just brilliant in this tv series. She carries the whole thing. Great actress and so beautiful to look at. Loved her posh accent, too!I would have given the series a 10 rating had there not been so many inaccurate medical facts & behaviors. They needed a better medical consultant on the film.Otherwise, I found the series riveting.

Started off as a good tv series, however should've been much shorter. Became painfully boring and infuriating the longer it went on. So many plot holes and irrational decisions by the characters. Could've been a much higher rating.

reviews.review_title: Slow, unrealistic, poorly written and acted
reviews.content: The series starts promisingly, but it soon loses its mojo.The plot develops at a extremely slow pace, as if it had been extended deliberately. The police are utterly incompetent, in a ridiculous way.The main character is supposed to be a feminist liberated woman, but she always wears high heels, tight skirts and silk blouses. She is portrayed as a sexual predator but she whispers like a submissive sexual worker.It is annoying. I can't believe people can finish watching season 2.

What I want to say is in fact a slow placed
serial killer story told in many episodes but with full of criminal elements and great actors. Jamie Dorman or Gillian Anderson played perhaps their best roles so far. It was full of suspense and until the last parts never boring. The soundtrack was scary. I didn't watch the last series because there were more and more large extended and in my opinion unnecessary scenes that could have cut. Check it out anyway and enjoy it until you want to see. 7/10

Do not waste your time on this series unless you want to spend hours imagining that Ms Andersons acting will ever get better. The writing is awful in the last of the episodes year two and I feel watching paint dry would be comparable. There is no spoiler here because the whole series ends as a spoiled mess. What I wonder is what producers for year two were thinking after this ended because I can imagine it was contempt for their own work. Imagine watching someone holding on to a cliff and then everything goes black. This will give you a small glimpse of the entire show. The story year one was actually interesting if you take out a few actors, specifically one mentioned earlier in this review.

I normally find serial killer dramas fascinating and really thought the first series of The Fall showed great promise. However, the second series has proved that more is not better! Gillian Anderson has become a 2 dimensional character whose USP is a silk blouse and frequent glimpses of classy bra; she can't meet a female friend for a drink without an unconvincing lesbian near-encounter; we know at some point that she will have a regrettable sexual experience with the killer; and we all want the young girl (who is displaying the normal confused experimentation with her burgeoning sexuality by trying to attract an older man) to meet a nasty end. There is no realistic portrayal of 'strong females' - instead they just play 'mean girls' who show no respect for any men they meet (the guy in the bar who comes on to GA's friend is not a creep but they take his drinks and dismiss him, although they are professional, successful women). There is no team in the police squad - only GA wafting about arrogantly with all other characters poorly drawn. The one other potentially interesting female police officer has suddenly decided to go back on the beat (and will no doubt be killed off by our serial killer at some point) following a locker room one sided conversation with GA changing, mistily, into another silk blouse while doing 'smell the fart' acting. Scott and Bailey does this so much better and more convincingly and we will now be switching off!

reviews.review_title: There is no life out there...
reviews.content: I decided to watch "The Fall" for two reasons. First, after watching about a dozen or so similar American products, I was curious how the British could do it. Second, I used to be somewhat of a fan of X-Files and wanted to see how Gillian Anderson did it in her second series (the first after X-Files). Boy, was I disappointed...I watched three episodes and could not quite get what was the crucial, vital difference between 'The Fall' and its American 'sisters' such as 'The Closer' (based on a similar idea), for example. And finally it dawned on me: THERE IS NO LIFE IN 'THE FALL'. None whatsoever.Characters in 'The Fall' are not just 'cardboard' or 'one-dimensional'. They are plain empty, hollow, zombie, walking dead. Robots. Add to it utterly boring and highly improbable plot - and you end up with a total disaster.Gillian Anderson is just Dana Scully who quit her FBI job, changed her name, citizenship, got the job in London Metropolitan police and made a meteoric career. And got transformed into something quite alien, mechanical, robotic and totally inhuman in the process.The serial killer - whose identity we happen to know from practically the very first moments - has one disastrous flaw as well. There is no evil in him. None whatsoever. Zero. Zilch. Oh, he tries to portray himself as evil very hard. To no avail. Which makes his character totally unbelievable.Boring. Improbable. Lifeless. Awful. Horrible. Total waste of time and money.

reviews.review_title: Another binge-worthy series starring Gillian Anderson
reviews.content: If you've read my review of The X-files you'll see I am very enamored with Scully's character. While I can't say I feel quite the same love for Stella Gibson, I do have the same admiration for Anderson's acting; I imagine that Anderson puts a great deal of herself into the roles she plays; every word and action is so real that disbelief is suspended .....episode after episode. So that the fiction comes to life on the screen seemingly due to the expertise and effort of Gillian Anderson's acting prowess. It is remarkable, in my opinion. To see Gillian Anderson again play an investigative cop type role is very satisfying because (again, my opinion) while so many crime dramas seem to almost be a P.R. vehicle, Anderson plays a character (in The Fall, much like in The x-files) who has admirable skepticism and highly evolved critical thinking skills....and of course obviously the writers are to thank also for the credible dialogue and screenplay, but still.....what I'm trying to say is Anderson plays a sort of "rogue" cop; one who isn't interested in "playing the game," or using her position to feel powerful and do harm, etc. etc. .....she actually cares about justice and the feelings of the people involved in her investigations, but at the same time, just like Scully, Stella Gibson uses logic, reasoning, etc. The Fall is superb. It is abjectly riveting. I have to admit I love the Irish accents (of many dialects!) in the show; but Anderson plays an Englishwoman for her role as Stella Gibson. She is beautiful, smart, skeptical, heartfelt, thorough, strong, brilliant~ Gibson is, just like Scully in many ways...*******SPOILER/ CHARACTER ROLE OF ANTAGONIST********** The man playing Paul Spector, Jamie Dornan, is nearly as frightening as "Friendo" fiend from "No Country For Old Men," Javier Bardem in his role as Anton Chigurh; it's mesmerizing. The length and subtlety of the investigation into the murders committed by Spector shows Stella Gibson with remarkable humanity, remarkable intelligence and compassion, and yet superior strength of mind. A great show to binge. You'll be addicted right away.

Gillian Anderson is back in action in this awesome TV series - suspenseful and dark. Gill has some real attitude this time which I really love. The direction and music were on point! Check this one out

The psycho killer and the plot is so good, I was hoping this was going to be the best UK cop show since Line of Duty, BUT the feminist narrative spouted by the main character is SO heavy-handed and SO relentless, and the older male cop character is such a doofus it's often like watching TV commercials aimed at young women that make men look like idiots. "Maleness is a mental disorder," the viewer is instructed!

Wow!Just got done watching the entire second season (finally!). This is an excellent series that keeps you at the edge of your seat every episode. The actors are intense and each plays their role to perfection. We don't have to guess who the bad guy is and this is what makes "The Fall" an instant classic. We get to see inside the mind of a sicko and the authorities that are out to catch him. Bringing in the family adds to the suspense, as we all know what's going on, but they are oblivious. It is slow at times? Yes, but that adds to the allure of this excellent series. I don't rate everything I watch, but this time I have to. Binge watch away!

Quite a mix between the first half of the three-season arc and the second half.On one side we have a superb, well-acted suspense thriller and on the other side is a bungling misfit of police who couldn't solve the mystery of their own shadow disappearing in the night.Seasons 1 and half of Season 2 are excellently scripted, flawless, and I was on the edge of my sofa the entire time. Easily deserving a 9.6, it was so good.The second portion of the series is a marathon of police blunders and downright unbelievable faux-pas. Just a few...Spector was the prime suspect and could have been brought in and held numerous times while they did a "legal" search of his residence. Instead we are offered up a clandestine search, whereby the keystone cops fall through the attic. Really?When police are investigating Spectors' possible crime site, Agent Gibson sees a vehicle (Spector inside) approach the scene, turn off its lights, back up/reverse down and then turn around. She isn't concerned one bit and he slowly drive away. Only precious minutes later does she realize something was odd.When Spector is being escorted in the country to help locate one of the victims he is handcuffed to the lightest, skinniest officer in the entire police force.Numerous times Spector is allowed to roam down the halls of the hospital and psych wards without any restraints.How has he healed so fast from critical gunshot wounds?Why is the injured Spector placed in the same hospital room as one of his victims? Great plan team!Why is he assigned a nurse who looks exactly like all his victims?During interrogations, Spector is never handcuffed although he is a multi-serial killer. Of course, he uses this "lack of proper procedure" to assault Gibson and her fellow officer.After this assault he is calmly taken back to the psych house, unsecured, where after a bit he promptly attacks staff.Why is a regulation pool table inside the rec room of the psych patient's hospital? Didn't it occur to anyone that pool sticks and balls can be used as weapons?
