Yes, they were.The list goes on....I'm starting to second guess my 7 rating now.In closing, the Producers need to issue an apology to the entire Northern Ireland Police Department for unfairly portraying them. Not fair.

reviews.review_title: Shouls have ended at the end of season 2.
reviews.content: Season one was brilliant, easy 10. Season 2 started getting worse episode by episode. They had all the evidence, they know every aspect, they even have his confession of crimes, and they still talk about difficulties regarding the case? No, the case is closed, the murderer is jailed, its game over. Season 3 i cant even explain. Its completely different show. Its a shame.

Slow. Disturbing.
Sorry your review is too short.
Slow and disturbing.
Disturbing and slow.
Season one was passable, but gave up at the end of season 2. Annoying characters, slow storyline and twisted and depressing in parts.

reviews.review_title: Dark must-see for dark soul searchers
reviews.content: By the time I got to the third season, I was feeling a bit tentative. I was worried that the show, though exciting up to that point, would fail to deliver in this season. But it does.One thing, not a spoiler, but the third season starts out very slow. I hope that if you know that going in, you might be more patient than I was. Many things in life are more effective when they're allowed to build slowly, even excruciatingly slowly. By S3 E6, I realized that the writers had outdone themselves, going a completely different way than I'd expected. I confess that the nature of evil, and nature vs. nurture, what can and cannot be healed, what is the limit of experience, what is love - all these questions, when framed in a serial killer/detective format, are really just extreme philosophy 101. These questions are cute in a movie like Steve Martin's Parenthood. What is the meaning of life? All fine and grand, but for some of us, life went dark early, and the answers that Friends (the series) gives us are wanting. We are not slaked. The Fall brings these questions out in stark relief, extending both black and white to their maximum contrast, and yet with an infinity of gray behind every seemly clear interpretation.
There is a really very very simple reason to never watch this, or anything else ms. anderson is in: SHE WILL SUCK THE LIFE OUT OF YOUyou've been warned!

reviews.review_title: Disappointing, boring, could have been done in 1 season
reviews.content: I heard so many people saying how they loved this show, I liked the first few episodes but then was bored to the max. They could have done it all in 1 season imo. There were no shocks or twists, only good points were Gillian & Jamie's great acting, the story was very non enthralling

Not sure about the English accent from Gillian Anderson, nor for that matter the character. It sets a scene and it draws you in but then it gets dark and in some scenes, quite uncomfortable to watch. The whole scenario then has many sub plots and these, mixed with the main story are long drawn out boring interludes. Slo-mo scenes of Gibson taking her regular swim are totally irrelevant and add nothing to the action. How Jamie Dornan's character, Spector, manages to break into the victims homes to recce the joint before commiting the crime the next day, without neighours noticing and not even causing any damage is a bit far fetched. How he washed and dried the bedding in a night is pretty good going too. The violence is brutal and graphic also, and not from Spector but from the other storylines too. The hotel room where he unscrews the socket to hide the memory card had a lot of wire to play with, unrealistic in real life in my experience. The scenes where Gibson is having or has had sex give nothing to the story and merely waste time. Three series and six episodes in each is too many, this could have been done in half or one series.
One of the best series i've ever watched.There's everything in it: crime, suspense, fear, love.Mind blowing as well.I loved Gillian Anderson and I discovered another face of Jamie Dornan.

reviews.review_title: Incredible Acting battling cheese fest writing in season 2/3
reviews.content: Incredible respect and hats off to Anderson and Dornan and the supporting staff and direction... Seriously they carried this thing on their backs despite a cheese fest of writing ensuing very late season 1 fwd. The fascinating character portrayals are well into the "Breaking Bad" league...Unfortunately late season 1 early season 2, 3... The story just gets flooded with stereo typical cheese that turns this into a love/hate for me. I loved watching the main characters as they are deeply fascinating. BTW this is DARK (ALL CAPS) intended.I can't count how many times the writers put Dornan incredibly unrealistic situations that would embarrass any law enforcement agency or mental health facility.It just reminds of the old horror movies/scooby doo "hey lets split up"... I I can't count how many times law enforcement/mental facilities left this guy uncuffed and under supervised and free to do what ever he wanted and/or ridiculously supervised by 1 person incapable of stopping Dornan if he chose to go violent.Each time they tried to milk that it just became more eye rolling and cringeworthy thus negating all of the serious character work, drama, and tension created by the characters. It was mixed emotions.. I truly enjoyed Anderson's character and found like that character needed a series of her own (With better writing mind you)...Overall Mediocre with acting/character brilliance...

The first series of this drama is a taut, suspenseful addition to the cop vs serial killer genre. Boosted by strong leads, it brings the viewer into a world of secrets, betrayals and fundamental character flaws. The second series drags, weighed down by desperately trying to fill 6 hours of TV. The final is dire, little more than an extended episode of Holby City with some police procedural elements thrown in. Cliche after cliche builds and subplots are left hanging.Gillian Anderson does her best, but ultimately her character comes across as a slightly more preachy version of Prime Suspect's Jane Tennison. Somehow monumental lapses of judgement and appalling conflicts of interest are brushed under the carpet until believability is lost. I found myself wondering at times whether her character had first been written as male, with a few speeches and an awkward scene or two added when it was decided to cast Anderson.Jamie Dornan's never been the strongest of actors, but he does well with what he's given. Again cliches abound and while he does his best Hannibal impression he never quite pulls it off.If this had been condensed into a single series with the writing tightened up it would have been a great drama. As it stands, it's a cliche ridden mess after the first series. Sadly the use of a cliffhanger means just watching that one series won't give you the conclusion The Fall so desperately deserved.

reviews.review_title: Good thriller, but season 3 was uncalled for
reviews.content: The Fall is a good TV show overall about a London detective that goes to Belfast to help the local police find the culprit of a series of twisted murders.It's not a mistery to the viewer who is the guilty party, we follow his perversion from day 1. But that doesn't mean the show isn't riddle with tension and confrontation.What also adds some value to the show are the flashy camera angles and cinematography in the first few episodes, which are less common in these type of shows.But the one the two main characters, detective Stella Gibson played by Gillian Anderson, really steals the show in my opinion. Her voice and speech is spell-biding throughout, and make for a complex character all in all - seemingly cold, yet passionate but still with a practical view when it comes to romance and intercourse. Outside the portfolio of cliche detectives we see day in, day out on TV.The only reason I give it a 7, rather than 8, is due to its 3rd season.It seems the writers team changed all together or simply ran out of ideas.Without giving it a way, the first episode of season 3 seems like an episode of ER, which outweighed focus on medical issues. And throughout the rest of the season, the story is much less plausible in terms of policing and prosecution procedures.Despite the compelling characters, that stained a bit the show for me.They would be better off wrapping it on season 2, but overall worth a watch, especially season 1

reviews.review_title: Series One. Very Good. Series Two? Was ok but now at ep 4 and it's getting very stupid.
reviews.content:
For one Stella, OK I know she's an independent sexually liberated woman, but how many senior police officers go to work in skin tight leather skirts? And her whispering dialogue. She's hardly an assertive police senior officer. Not Vera that's for sure.
But also security. The ease at which Peter (Paul?) goes about breaking into people's houses? But worse still, I'll never stay at the Belfast Hilton. Breaks in with ease, lays about on the bed (she could walk in at any moment.) Then when she does arrive where the xxxx is he hiding? Her boss PC comes in and leaves, she's obviously changed her clothes, Peter wasn't in the wardrobe. Was he in the bathroom? I doubt it, she must have had a pee.
Then she goes on her laptop. It must have had a password? How come he managed to change the screen wallpaper?
Then we come to the baby sitter. She's a teenage psycho obviously too. Easily breaks into his place. Is followed by the police. How how come Stella wasn't immediately contacted and they go and ask her what she was doing?
The body in the woods. Face down, 'it's a female aged 20 - 30, that's clever, guesstimating the age of someone without seeing their face. (It was covered in mud anyway.) Let alone the fact that if people hang themselves from a tree one, they need to be able to get up to fix the rope and two, they need to stand on something.
But funniest of all was when they decided to place listening devices in Target One's home. Two or three big vans, scaffolding and half a dozen blokes in white coveralls go into the house in daylight. I doubt any of the neighbours would have noticed or mentioned it to them. Not exactly a covert operation. That was totally stupid. And as soon as I saw a bloke 'getting a power supply from the loft' (really?) I guessed a foot was going to go through the ceiling. BUT ALSO , how come they didn't notice his secret stash just tucked inside the loft hatch? They'd have trodden on it as they climbed in.
Still watching S2 ep 5 it just gets worse and worse. Baby sitter goes to hotel, police move in to arrest her, knocking on the door? She's destroying evidence for Paul. 'You're under arrest' the officer say (but for what? And where was the 'and anything you do say. etc.
But WORSE, Paul is running (under survellance? Really. Pathetic.) and bumps into tattoo man and wheel clamper. Punch up. Police arrive. Bit of shooting. Paul is alive on the ground. Does the police office leave him there and say, hands behind your back and cuff him? No, helps him to his feet, he's still not cuffed just standing nicely beside the officer. He's a multi murderer, violent and very fit. What kind of police training do they have in Belfast. This is absolutely PATHETIC.It's all going very stupid now. Especially the baby sitter part.Up to this point I thought a well written clever drama and I enjoyed the fact it was set in Belfast.
I could have picked a few other holes, like when he ran from his stabbing. No CCTV in Belfast. There's other stuff too, but the ease at which he strolls into the Hilton, gets into her room and lays around AND THEN HIDES, was all a bit too much.

The acting, casting, script and tension is first class. All of the cast are top professionals and believable. In the main roles, Gillian Anderson counterbalances Jamie Dornan brilliantly. You'll be pushed to find one smile from Jamie and there is a danger that if you are not of strong disposition, one can become very sombre watching this and even depressed. One or two twists in an erotic sense are surprising and at least unusual. John Lynch in his paranoid senior policeman role echoes his instability and edginess from Sliding Doors.It's dark drama and certainly not boring. Towards the end, one was worried they would run out of able bodied actors with the riots, shootings and pure violence.Glad to see Stella Gibson survives appearing as a strange cross between an iceberg and hot coffee.She was best of great cast.

This is one the most compelling crime shows I have seen in long time. This is a pretty realistic show that has two parallel plot lines of good and evil. On the good side is Stella Gibson a senior investigating officer tasked to investigate a murder, she's an incredibly capable officer, on the other hand she's a pretty cold character, lives alone and sleeps with her colleagues without the care if they're married or not. On the bad side is Paul Spector a serial killer targeting young professional brunette women and poses their bodies sexily, on the flip side he's a devoted family man with a wife and two children and works as a grievance councillor. The way these two characters contrast each other is perfect, the differences stand out but it's their similarities you feel; they are hunters and they are obsessive. They are rarely on screen together which doesn't matter because their obsession to learn about each other is fascinating that when they are finally on screen together it feels well earned. Gibson and Spector are like the real-life version of the yin-yang, the black and white circle that represents two sides of a whole with a dot on each side that represent that each side has a little of each other in them.The theme is established in the first bits of dialogue comes from one Paul's victims where she talks about the differences between needs and desires. Like food, water and air is what we need but love, recognition and praise is what we desire. When she's asked if sex is a need or a desire, she says "Well, both if you're doing right". The show essentially explores the main characters desires that they don't distinguish it from needs, especially their personal sexual desires; Stella desires to sleep with her colleagues and seeing a case to the end and Paul killing the women with the ritual he applies is his sexual desire.Gillian Anderson is excellent as Stella, very convincing as a high-powered London detective, it's very easy to forget that she's actually American. Since her character is usually stone-faced and cold, the role requires her to give a subdued performance yet she has a lot of expression in her eyes. Jamie Dornan is fantastic as Paul, very subtle and unpredictable that a lot times makes the audience feel very unease watching him. For those who watched those dreadful 50 Shades films and think he's a bad actor need to watch to this to see what real talent he is. Other stand-out cast and characters include John Lynch as Stella's self destructive superior Jim, Bronagh Waugh as Paul's unsuspecting wife Sally, Aisling Franciosi as Katie a teenage girl obsessed with Paul, Colin Morgan as Tom a young detective whom sleeps with Stella, Archie Panjabi as pathologist Tanya, Valene Kane as Rose an ex-girlfriend of Paul, Niamh McGrady as Danielle a devoted PC and more.The show is slow paced but is mesmorising and disturbing, which relies more on atmosphere and psychology than violence or gore. The violence is there and at times is very difficult to watch, it's the build up to it though that keeps you on edge. Scenes where characters are looking around a room or looking at the computer for example all take time but keep with you invested with a haunting musical score.Unlike a lot of TV series' where each season typically has a different story arc, this however has the one arc that flows from beginning to end making all three seasons feel like one long season. The ending to the series does wrap up story, however doesn't end in a particularly satisfying way, which is fitting though for the tone of the show. There may be some things that were left unresolved but as one of the closing lines say, "That's Disney, this is the real story".

OMG...where do I start. Slow. I have read all the reviews and wondered....what are they watching? This is no Prime Suspect. Bad acting, bad scripts and no redeeming value. I have watched all the episodes in order. Again, I still don't understand what is going on. And GA's really BAD English accent is an insult to all! I have read that so many of you think this is her break out....sorry, not even close. No acting here, just phoned in the character. Someone, please tell me why this is a great series????? If this is to be the next Helen Mirren....well, not even close. I am so disappointed and still trying to figure out the plot!!!! I will seek internet help to figure out what is going on....perhaps that will clear up the mystery!!!Bad, bad, bad!!!

Very well acted by the two leads, and yes, Gillian is hot.It's nice to see a drama set in Belfast for a change, and I suppose the 2nd series will be in a Scottish city. I hope it isn't Edinburgh because, although I love that city there needs to be a change from the usual British sites (London, in particular).Ms Anderson has shown great form on UK dramas: she was terrific in Bleak House. I cannot understand some of the criticism over her British accent. It's not at all false, and she has spent half of her life here, including her childhood.There were glaring faults in the plot. How the killer could be so careful on one hand and then utterly amateurish on the other beats me. And the ending was ridiculous. Still, I'm hoping they will take note and make the next series more believable.

1st season was just about OK.
After that it's 12 episodes where absolutely nothing happens. Good if your struggling to get to sleep otherwise avoid like the plague.

I'm not scoring this, and I'm not really writing this review for other people. Instead, this is in case years from now, after I've forgotten I gave this a try (I watch a lot of TV and sometimes forget I've seen things), I could look here and see why I didn't keep with the series.The beginning episodes is slow moving but intense, because you are spending a lot of time with a woman who it is immediately made clear will soon be murdered by a serial killer.While some people love serial killer stuff, I don't, and seeing this woman go through her life knowing she would be murdered and most probably tortured and raped just freaked me out. I just couldn't take it.Now, I read a review that said that while the first ten minutes suggested the series would be disturbing, that ultimately it doesn't delve into that end of things. Perhaps that's true. I watched about a half an hour and that creepiness was still there by that point, and I stopped so I wouldn't risk seeing the woman's death.I didn't really watch enough to have a strong feeling about how the show would turn out. It's slow-moving and has a chilly, antiseptic quality, but that could be good. But serial killers are just not something I can enjoy, so I'll pass.

The entire season was a slow burn until it all exploded in this minute of violence and passion.Some superb acting here by all in this scene.I have no words to describe my emotions...electric, incensed maybe?By far the best season, MINUTE, so far of The Fall.I'd give it 11/10 if I could for this 1 golden minute of cinema.Thank you to those who created this minute.

reviews.review_title: Just OK and too long and slow
reviews.content: This is one of those shows that makes me think there are a lot of fake reviews on IMDB. It's definitely not a 10 or a 9 or even an 8. It's just okay. The casting is good and it's clearly a well-made show, but it is really drawn out and repetitive. I've watched two seasons and am not sure I will bother with the next. Really the whole thing could've been done in 6 shows rather than 12. The guy is a serial killer and they spend a lot of time showing him committing similar murders. We get the idea and the repetition seems like filler. Similarly, when an unlikable character is in the hospital, there are long, drawn out sequences in the operating room. It isn't suspenseful, it just feels like they dragged it out to use up time. It would've been nice to see more investigation and less slow, drawn out filler. Plus it was weird the way the Gillian Anderson character started out as a tough, smart character in the first season and devolved into a teary-eyed, whispery wimp in the second.

reviews.review_title: Gutsy! As real and flawed as it can be!
reviews.content:
The Fall is a great character study drama and not a thriller.
Also, inorder to fully appreciate the essence of the show, you have to watch all 3 seasons.
If you are in a hurry and expecting another edge of the seat thriller similar to silence of the lambs, you will have difficulty in relishing this lenghty and brooding story. 
Lets talk about the name of the show itself. Its essentially the fall of morality in protagonist and also the fall of basic police standards. Its surprising to see the lack of police detectives in NI and those who are present are just happy to do it as a 9 to 5 public sector job with no urgency and focus. They dont anticipate, act or adapt to a real response to catching a killer on the loose.
The Show also shows off a wide variety of abusive elements including exhibitionism, fetish and pervertness not fully connecting the real transformation of abused turned abuser track.
Gillian's acting is more of a tired police supervisor who stalks young police officers and looking to appreciate her own dress and useless introspection. She acts rather slowly to everything instead of upping the ante and doesnt
look to be qualified at all. Also her tactical decisions look to be half baked and lack professionalism.
I had given 3 stars to the show but upgraded it to 9 star just to appreciate the efforts of superior production values, some spellbinding performances and for its graceful handling of sexual acts.
Coming to the performances, i rate the acting of spector family Paul, Sally and Livie top notch. They are so believable and impactful.
Jamie gives us his best performance to date with his split avatar exhibiting rage, anger, remorselessness and also surprising care and agony. 
Hospital scenes are realistic and brutal. At times, it is frustrating to watch the ineptness of the police crew but in sum total after watching the show, there is a satisfaction of experiencing the fall, rise and the fall of a flawed character amidst modest surroundings.

I came across this quite by accident, and what a brilliant series. Series one and two are real edge of the seat stuff, series three different but still needed making. How a seemingly normal bloke can descend to the levels that he did is quite scary. And Gibson, lonely and flawed, brilliant performance from Gillian Anderson, you get to feel quite sorry for her hard but really quite vulnerable character. Plenty of backdrop stories running parallel with the main hunt, this is no whodunnit, as the character and his fetishes are laid out in detail in the first episode. Slow, yes, but it needs to be, if you want a shoot em up or an American style wrapped up in an episode then this isn't for you, but like a lot of BBC crime shows it spends time to draw you in and keep you there. The third series is a little different, but it did bring the series to a definite conclusion. If thoughtful police drama is for you, then don't miss this.

reviews.review_title: The best TV show I've seen in ages.
reviews.content: "The Fall" is a crime drama that follows an investigation into a series of murders involving young business women in Belfast, Ireland. Season 1 begins with Metro Police Superintendent Detective Stella Gibson (played by Gillian Anderson) heading up a group of local detectives determined to track down a serial killer by the name of Paul Spector (Jamie Dornan) before he has a chance to strike again.The Fall is a top-flight mystery that taps into political tensions in Northern Ireland and the troubling undercurrent of violence against women with skin-crawling intensity. It's intelligent, well-written and beautifully acted with compelling performances to boot. You want this monster caught, and yet every time he trips up, you wince. Nobody does intelligent ice queen better than Anderson, shaped by the heroine's feminism and unapologetic sexuality. Those looking for an atmospheric, brooding, slow-paced psychological study will find many rewards.

It is very slow all the way through the show ,then it has quite a few side stories and irrelevant dialogs that dragging forever,you can get out the room for a while
And come back without losing anything.

reviews.review_title: best thriller I've seen in a while
reviews.content: Absolutely fantastic. Dark, creepy, well written, and feels so realistic. If you love crime thrillers this is a must see. Gillian Anderson has a strong female role which I loved. I couldn't find any flaws. Simply perfect.

reviews.review_title: Gillian Anderson is immaculate in this
reviews.content: Gillian Anderson is brilliant as is her male counter part. Cinematographer and producer / writer could've been better at points but all in all this is brilliant, led by 2 great actors

This actually gains steam as it goes on, and by the end of the first season, you're just dying to see what happens next. I actually thought this was just a mini-series and I didn't realize it wasn't going to end until when there was around 10 minutes left of Episode 5. I'm glad though, both the leads are excellent in this, Anderson especially. There's so much more story to cover and now, knowing it wasn't supposed to be a miniseries, it heightens the rest of the show to another level in terms of the potential and what could happen next. Jamie Dornan is gorgeous, my new crush! I'm sorry, it's the truth. So unbelievably alluring.

reviews.review_title: First season great, Second pretty good, Third pointless
reviews.content:
The first season was a pretty good cat and mouse game. It's focused on the crimes and exciting.The second season was a little slower. The evidence is all coming up roses, but they have to get the arrest just right. Honestly, stop here and save yourself 6 hours.The third season is all boring aftermath. Police inquiries. Hospital visits. Lawyering up. Children wimpering. Press conferences. Internal Affairs. Childhood psych profiles. Reopening cold cases. Amnesia. Dreams. No real reason to watch.My main criticisms of the show:
1. Bizarre coincidences. One example: he identifies a victim at random, later goes to the zoo, and happens to sit down right next to her on a bench, where she tells her sister loudly "Unfortunately my back door lock is broken."
2. Incompetent cops (other than the genius protagonist). One example: He walks into a park in a blue jacket and walks out in a black jacket (without sunglasses, hat or any other disguise) and the cops at every exit can't detect him.
3. So slow. How many stilted dialogs and long walks down hallways and staring into the rain? Every cop meeting and dinner date is just GA pontificating. very. slowly. and. quietly. and. everyone. hanging. on. her. every. word. I like to picture that in every meeting, after her 15 minute soliloquy, they all roll their eyes and say "Ok, let's start the meeting and make some progress."
4. Her boss is a spineless whiny dope who plays no meaningful role whatsoever. Not even sure why he's a character.But the first two seasons are still quite enjoyable.
I Always Like Gillian Anderson She Stunning and a Great Actress her voice turns me to jelly The Falling Will Be Rated One of the best Crime Dramas Ever in Years To come

Could not get beyond S1E1. The story starts off with little context and just got progressively worse. One has no idea who any of the characters are. The scenes are randomly sequenced which makes it confusing. Eventually the viewer realizes that this will be the usual "cat and mouse" battle of personalities. Just seemed too silly to invest a lot of time to watch!

It went so well until the half of 2nd season. The start wasn't great either but it was good enough. Then , terribly written story. And the ending extremely bad. I really expected more after how it began. Very disappointed. The way they found everything on him - extremely bad. Why did he agree to give away rose location. I thought he has a plan or something - it was going that way. But shot him out of the blue, even that scene was bad directed. How can he get injured that bad although the detective was first on the line - to say so. Then he loses his memory and they find , just like that, another crime to charge him with and all other evidence on him. Like they won the lottery. Bad, very bad turn of events I was expecting something smarter.

reviews.review_title: I deducted 3 stars for the final season
reviews.content: I would have easily given this 8 stars for the first 2 seasons. It was well written, well acted, fast paced and intriguing. But the final season was so bad I had to deduct 3 stars. It was slow and overly dramatic and so clichéd. I was cringing the whole way through. Wish I'd just stopped at season 2. Heck, wish THEY'D just stopped at season 2.
This story will fascinate you. The two leads are great and the procedural nsture of the story is more than enough to keep you watching

reviews.review_title: Season 1 & 2 ok, Season 3 is just plain stupid
reviews.content: How do police allow a 3-4 criminal walk free w/o being heavily guarded, especially when he has demonstrated enormous strength? How are police staff so stupid to be in a room with an unguarded serial killer? How is the hospital staff soooooooooooooooooooooo stupid as to assign female staff to a confessed serial murderer of women, especially that staff that looks exactly like some of the victims. Just too unbelievable to comprehend.

So, in a nutshell, there is a lot of promise to this show and I wouldn't say avoid it. But be aware that after S2 it takes a sharp left. Having captured the killer, there begins a slow crawl into the psychology of Spector. Many say S3 is disappointingly slow, but I'm glad I stuck with it since it has some very provocative moments and actually wraps up the story. While I initially was curious to see Anderson in a new role her constant appearance on the camera became grating at times. Her wardrobe nor expressions ever change; that cigarette-fatigued voice almost like nails on a chalk board. I kept with the show more for Dornan and Morgan (Merlin). S1 & 2 are definitely gritty and shocking; however, it's absolutely nothing like Hannibal Lector, as one review claims the producers were going for. I see no resemblance. Perhaps this is only the 2nd macabre show they've ever seen. In fact, if it had been written and directed in the US, as Silence of the Lambs was, Spector would not have been given such leniency in the psychiatric facility and none of this would have even happened. This is a man accused of horrendous acts of torture upon women and at least one male killed, yet he is free to roam around and interact with the other patients. In particular, more than one person was convinced he was faking amnesia and yet there were no armed guards present in the interview room. In the US, Spector would have not been roaming free but if he had he would have been their very first concern when the other patient started a scene. I mean, it's not the 60s; professionals are more than aware of criminals and deviants staging distractions. And don't even get me started on the lack of security or protocol in the woods looking for Rose. But all of this -the expectation that the viewer would play dumb-was a set up for the events of the show. Despite the maddening stupidity we are required to believe as human oversight, the series itself is worth the watch if you like the tension and mystery that is gripping and surprising. But be prepared to have a lot of questions, most of which can be answered by the viewer's understanding of Spector. Like why did David lie for Peter, actually going to prison in his place? Well, he may have been endebted but I'm pretty sure we're expected to read a bit more into their relationship when we consider how others have become so enamored with Peter/Paul despite that he has no feelings for them in return. And why did he kill Billie in the psyche ward? I think it was to give him relief from the meaningless life he was trapped in. Why didn't he escape rather than kill himself? I believe it's because he realized his life was worthless since he couldn't be a good father, because of his statement to the shrink. I'm glad I watched the whole series. S3 does start very slowly. But then, the series itself has already accustomed us to many drawn out moments. So, it's par for the course. This series won the Edgar Allan Poe award.

reviews.review_title: Superb - one of the best serial killer stories
reviews.content: The Fall is superb, and is a highly gripping and intense thriller. As with the best serial killer stories, the thought behind the character development is intelligent, and very astute in its understanding of the darker side of human psychology - with clever references to existential philosophy and psychoanalytic theory. The narrative never dips in quality, or distracts itself with unnecessary deviations, and it builds into the most incredible crescendo. Ending the penultimate season you wonder where the narrative can possibly go, but the final season exceeds expectations to quite some degree. Also, it is worth mentioning that the actors do a brilliant job with a complex and sensitive subject-matter.

I just saw this on Netflix having missed it when it first aired and wished I had missed it again.
The plot holes galore are too many to count and the total stupidity of many of the characters throughout are completely ridiculous. With any amount of common sense from at least a few characters the villain would have been caught within a few episodes. The writer just made everyone appear idiotic so as to drag the whole thing out into 3 unnecessary series.
Complete waste of time.

It was all wrapped up in Season 2; A few more episodes could have neatly wrapped up the family impact, the Detective's stories, etc.
Instead, we are forced to go thru a 3rd season, where the killer has amnesia after being shot. I can't take another season of a bland Gillian Anderson attempting to keep a dead case alive.
I do not even know what to say about season 3. The first and second seasons were excellent..but season 3 seemed pointless. Like me writing these unnecessary words.

After sitting through the first four installments of The Fall, I couldn't help feeling that this effort suffers from one of the key things wrong with television today. Someone comes up with a premise for a 60 or 90 minute "Movie of the Week" and then the Network Program Directors decide to stretch it out to five or six hours (or, even worse, a weekly series). Another good example of this was New Zealand's Top of the Lake with Elisabeth Moss. This one had me begging for infomercials. The Fall could have just as easily taken place in The Wax Museum. All the energy, so far, has taken place in the swimming pool! I don't know if it was the Director or the Actors or a bad sound crew, but all the whispery, sibilant dialogue has been like fingernails on a blackboard. All in all, this could have been a mediocre episode of Silent Witness.

I came to The Fall in search of great drama after a post Breaking Bad hiatus and some interest in the Wire. Little I did i know the Fall would exceed expectations and both of these American dramas. I sat down to watch 1 episode and ended up staying up half the night to watch half the first season.The Fall is brilliantly shot. It's slow, careful and deliberate direction syncronise with the plot and leading protagonists. Gillian Anderson is mesmerising.Very few thrillers leave you affected as your eyes leave the screen but the Fall achieves this. For those that struggle to be captivated I dare you to watch this and defy you to look away.

reviews.review_title: A good show badly let down by Season 3
reviews.content: This show starts well with a compelling story line, good casting (Anderson and Dornan) a interesting setting in NI and well thought out characters. The main issue with it is that the story substantially completes itself in the finale of season two before continuing for another six episodes. The finale of season 2 felt like the writers were finishing it whilst leaving the door slightly open for a continuation of the story. This was most unsatisfying and it could have been nicely finished in just two episodes.Season 3 is a significant quality drop and the story meanders about and gets sillier, with redundant plot lines, characters and an eye-rolling tedious amnesia sub-plot. Hopefully they won't make any more.

Interesting crime series that starts quite well and get extremely slow and boring... they drag the solution of one single case over 3 full seasons. In many episodes nothing happens. 3rd season is just a slow dark poem.

Ok this is an old series fir most of you but I've only just caught up on it and still on series one .It's a great atypical british tv crime series with a twist or two led brilliantly by the lead of Gillian AndersonBinge series like this help is all get through this bizarre year we are living in - will update the review once I get to the endPad.A 8/10

reviews.review_title: "We live law to ourselves. Our reason is our law." Paradise Lost by John Milton
reviews.content: There's quite a bit to admire in this series: The performances are vivid and motivations are clear; the setting itself, Belfast (in decay) adds both to discovering a great city and a perfect setting for a crime of misogyny; the cinematography, editing and direction are often interesting and appropriate.What sinks it for me is the length. Much could have been consolidated into a 6 part season. An example is a lengthy procedure in an emergency room that may be accurate in its detail (and not insignificant to the plot), but the intricate detail--for most of us--is meaningless.You won't waste your time--if you've got the time--watching a BTK serial killer wreak havoc in Belfast while the police stumble and complicate the situation due to political infighting in a competitive work force, and daunted by a killer, the likes of which they've not seen before. Gillian Anderson, as an outsider, is called into lead the investigation. She's a very self-possessed woman who quashes any trivialization of her gender. She's a great character pitted against the principal, Jamie Dornan, who objectifies women to such a degree he can render them into corpses so he can "play" with their bodies before he discards them. The depiction of the crimes is useful but often hard to watch and, in some cases, unnecessarily specific and cruel. Dornan does a good job slipping in and out of his dual roles as a "straight" family man employed as a grief counselor then as night falls, a horrific threat.There are several subplots. Belfast's attitude towards women (rigidly defined by the Catholic Church) is notorious. I'm not sure these subplots bring anymore clarity to the proceedings; although the neighborhood "thug" climate and anti-police/authority attitude rooted in Northern Ireland's political history and "Troubles" adds dimension to a city under siege, not only by a serial killer but by general policing which the public resents.Some secondary characters, notably Aisling Franciosi, a 15-year-old babysitter whose own personality traits have landed her in the perfect job: caring for the killer's children while he's off killing and torturing women. Her sharp perceptions put her miles ahead of Dornan's wife (the always superb, Bronagh Waugh), who at one point is labeled stupid and incurious, allowing her husband full rein at coming and going during all times of the night without even one follow-up question to "Where have you been?" A daughter of the killer (Sarah Beattie) adds a desperate humanity, illustrating that collateral damage of crime can be profound.This is a big series and a large production; so, the opportunity for gaffs and poor decisions in its creation are inevitable. But there's nothing ruinous, other than the overly-detailed depictions of the crime can border on arty pornography.There's a long scene, placed perfectly in the drama, between the two principals, who proclaim their "philosophies" that's really quite masterful. It's those moments that make the series worth watching and easy to overlook any stumbling. And as always, spending time watching Ms. Anderson work is welcome. She literally brings meaning to walking down a hallway or turning a doorknob and entering a room.

Gillian Anderson plays some so-called sexy cougar detective in this show. Her one-time lover says "you have no idea the effect you have on men..." Problem is: if you want an actress to play that role, she should be sexy herself. But Anderson's forehead is freaky flat, she NEVER smiles and has ZERO sex appeal. A Botox overdose failure. Why cast her in this role? Bad choice. She struts through this entire series as if every man should be melting in her presence. Really? To top that off, her acting is atrocious. It is like watching someone read a script. I will re-watch a few episodes of X-Files to see if she was always such a horrible actress. I was quite young when I watched it, so I wouldn't have noticed. Overall, the show might have been good but Anderson killed it.

reviews.review_title: Do not rate a series after the first episode!
reviews.content: What a shocker. First series was intruiging and had me gripped but boy did it lose itself completely in the second. We couldn't bring ourselves to continue. It just became too unbelievable. I don't even want to spend my time listing the plot holes and criticising the poor writing. Why have people reviewed this after watching one episode?! The rating on this series misleads people into watching it. Don't bother wasting your time.

First season is great, exciting and well thought out, while the 2nd is terrible due to the main character making mistakes that he would never make based on his intelligent and well thought out and cautious actions and there are way too many "accidental" and too coincidental events that make it painful to enjoy. And finally, the 3rd one is so boring that there are no words to explain... utter boredom all through the 6 episodes.It's a mystery how they were able to ruin a great first season with the following two... just sad.

This TV series was horrible disappointment for a number of reasons.1- 5 hours of watching the same incessant thing over and over with no resolution to ANY issue. I never expected that. 2- A septic actress with a lousy British accent and a drip of a personality. She couldn't act her way out of a paper bag and was as boring as a snail in my backyard 3- continued, unnecessary bad shots from overhead for arts sake. 4- too frequent scene changes that are short and abruptI enjoyed the backdrop of Belfast and the fact it did not deal with IRA type issues. It was refreshing in this sense. They should have focused a bit more on corruption within the police rather than just the serial killer.Jamie Dornan is great as the serial killer. I certainly will not "FALL" into the trap of watching series 2.

reviews.review_title: Good.. but they really milked it
reviews.content: I think this all could've been one season or 2 max. Eventually we reach a point where we see them doing medical procedures which is definitely not what you'd watch a detective/crime show for. They drag out so many scenes that could've been less than a minute and some scenes were very unnecessary and incredibly boring. I kept trying wondering "why are we seeing this" a lot but especially in season 3

Very slow indeed in my opinion. The story was very slow to progress and I didn't find it suspenseful or scary. Looks like I'm in the minority but I'm not a fan so far. I can only hope it's one story per season or I'm doomed.

reviews.review_title: Superb acting by G.A., interesting cast, human behavior drama
reviews.content: Interesting and inviting use of wardrobe and color filter changes to match emotions of characters as they reveal bits of themselves throughout both series. Main characters dance without touching, the dance of mind and strength. G.A. portrays the vulnerability and power of a woman with confidence, heart, and focus. J.D. is excellent choice for character, refreshing and not type cast. Unlike so many American films, we have time to attach bits of ourselves to each character, drawing us in closer to the stories that surround the lives of those whose lives are dedicated to helping others and themselves. Hoping for a third series.

reviews.review_title: Well written but bleak and depressing
reviews.content: Seasons 1 & 2 are very gripping and move at quite a pace. They're both very dark but not as dark as the final season gets.Season 3 slows the pace down and for a while I thought the writers had lost it but the ending is far removed from Hollywood clichés and does not pander to the mainstream.Very good series overall but has the same bleak feel as Threads TV movie (1984) did.

Intriguing at first but downfalls along the way. Season 3 was unnecessary. Unrealistic, irrational, and biased in every way. However, some great performances by Jamie Dornan and Gillian Anderson.5/10 barely!

reviews.review_title: A review from someone who has watched all 3 seasons...
reviews.content:
I did read many IMDB reviews on here before starting to watch The Fall and it would seem most reviews were given after the first episode or first season.Let's break it down...
Season 1 - a slow burn with intense moments and an excellent potrayal of a serial killer.
Season 2 - still a slow burn, some questionable character developments or plot add ins, but still found it mostly enjoyable
Season 3 - you really do have to suspend your logic for this season. I was invested enough in the 2 main characters to see it through to the end and the last 2 episodes I enjoyed. But the plot itself was pretty ridiculous and whilst I'm not in law enforcement... I find the lack of competency pretty questionable and it felt forced as to give the third season a plot. If season 2 ended differently I don't think they even needed a 3rd season.
The entire show is a slow burn and it is frustrating that after season 1 it goes a bit down hill. But I still found it better than most things I watch on Netflix and I have patience for slow shows.I did find some of the filming rather indulgent and without a direction that I understood... For example the numerous close ups of Gilllian Anderson's character doing next to nothing or maybe buttoning her shirt etc. I started to wonder what the intention of these shots were because whilst some gave you real emotion, many seemed more sexually or physically motivated.Regardless both leads were amazing throughout all 3 seasons. If the plot had gone differently and been more believable then my rating would have been an 8 or 9.

reviews.review_title: Gripping but goes on a bit long
reviews.content: If "the Fall" had concluded after 6 or 7 episodes I would have judged it as one of the best crime series I've ever seen. No criticism would have passed my lips apart from condemning the quality of the soundtrack, which has muffled and reverberating voices and some other sound effects similarly distorted. What is the problem, are there no competent sound engineers anymore? to return to the positives, I found Gillian Anderson's beauty riveting and the elegant way she dresses provoked my (woman's) admiration. The policing seemed fine to me, at least in the early episodes, and the villain is convincing enough to provoke full attention and ample suspense. To my surprise the series went on and on past the point where it could have been wound up, and in the process the tale became rather like a soap opera. The footage of Anderson looking thoughtful and melancholy became very repetitive. The behaviour of other characters started to go over the top in terms of emotionality and irrationality. Some of them surely needed to be told to take a pill, or two! The motivation of the villain is progressively explored, but in this respect my engagement is limited. I think people who commit savage crimes although they know the difference between right and wrong should just be locked away, not have a lot of people pore over them in an effort to understand their motivation, and in the process provide them with opportunities for further violence! I watched through to the final episode, although with a sense of diminishing returns. Still superior viewing, but spoiled a bit by padding and straying over-the-top.

This really is a poor series, It was painful to watch at times. Gillian Anderson is so plain and wooden that her part very quickly becomes boring and irritating. Series one was half decent but very quickly goes downhill.

Good drama, started strong, Very good acting from everyone, especially the Irish cast, it was good to see some familiar faces. There are the plot holes but once you accept them and try enjoy it it's a good drama. Also I think it would of been better in two concise seasons, nobody believed he lost his memory and the third season dragged but overall I enjoyed it.

reviews.review_title: Too clever for it's own good
reviews.content:
I agree with many reviewers, Seasons 1 and 2 are far superior to the last season.
The main problem for many with season 3 is pace, but I feel this is appropriate, and helps dredge the depths of the main characters.
However, as the series progresses, it becomes increasingly replete with implausible situations that are both infuriating and make a mockery of the otherwise worthwhile attempts to present reality in a different light.
Pity. There was a lot of potential here.

reviews.review_title: the best mini series in history
reviews.content: I rarely rate a series so high; I was sturck by how amazing both the writing and the directing were. G. anderson is simply a piece of work. it gets obvious comparisons to helen mirren's previous series in the 90's: 'prime suspect'. it is similar to that in that it has a world class actress in a lead usually reserved for men. that is not the reason i like it, but such acting is rare. anderson is in the upper echelon of actresses in the world and it was a treat to see her performance.I've read that the american audience might me less enthralled than the audience from the crown. I am american and I can say I believe it transcends that. don't laugh, but for americans i suggest watching it with english subtitles on, as the irish accent can be difficult for some if one is not use to it.regarless of subject matter, i would highly recommend it solely based on teh strenth of anderson's performance. It is that good.

reviews.review_title: ... when someone murders people... it's disappointing when they beat proper punishment
reviews.content: ... through the first ten episodes of season one then two, it mostly all works fairly well... then all kinda falls apart at the ending, episode six of season two... just several plot-lines converging making little sense & poorly enacted.. once you reach them they stand out sorely immediately, dropping the show at least a notch, possibly two... still worth watching, but they really should have come up with better... having not yet fully-watched season three.. many reviewers posted that only season one was truly worthwhile & that season three was the worst of the three... think in any event that with a very good first season series, they missed their chance to tackle-discuss increasing violence against women... it's really now at crisis levels & productions like The Fall could better bring it to mainstream-attention-discussion... there are LOADS more abusers than serial-killers... season three does somewhat redeem the overall production... helping a bit to repair damage from what might be seen an awkward ending season two... yes, the series requires lots of patience.. for one crime story & characters to run through seventeen full episodes is a lot... yet the hundred thousand reviewers to date have got it right... it is that good a series with some of the finest work of all involved.

I was totally into what I thought was a 10 rating series despite hating such plots, then series 3 came around, and now I feel as thou I'm being tortured by remaining faithful to this amazing series due to the attempt at humanizing him starting in the 3rd series.And because of that I can't keep going forward with this in the manner I did with the first 2 series, but instead I fast forwarded to the last episode where I experienced the most wonderful feeling of release like no other ending before.

reviews.review_title: Gripping, but gradually loses the grip with each episode
reviews.content:
Fantastic plot and ideas, really gripped me for season 1. Then season 2 seemed to drag, in the annoying way when you know as the audience what's happened and what is going to happen and you wish it would hurry up. Then season 3 was pointless - the storyline didn't progress at all in the last few episodes, just unnecessary detail was filled.
It wasn't bad and it was entertaining, but it could have been reduced to 6 episodes in total. And I can't work out if Anderson's acting was brilliant or woeful. Hard to say.

reviews.review_title: How not to lead a major crimes investigation
reviews.content: This series started out well and as time progressed it was clear the writer lost the plot trying to stretch out the series. This is not a topnotch crime thriller as rated by many, but a bland analysis on how not to lead a major crimes investigation. The series is an insult to police women and women in general and policing in Ireland. There are so many holes in general policing practises and procedures. The character portrayed by Anderson is shallow and detracts from what could have been a good story. The second season degrades from thriller to frustration and quickly becomes a snooze fest. Jamie Dornan's acting in the series is very good, but is not enough to elevate a series with trite plot.

reviews.review_title: Superb psychological thriller with a difference makes this addictive
reviews.content: I love psychological thrillers and this one did not disappoint ! The story was gripping the acting first class ,I binge watched mainly due to wanting/ needing to know what happened next! I would have scored it a 10 but felt it was not perfect as a 4 things that happened were very questionable such as a small child waking in the middle of the night because she couldn't sleep discovering a strange man climbing the stairs to her house reacts by watching him and then calmly asking him who are you? I seriously doubt regardless of age any child who do that! More likely to scream and run and wake there parents. I also thought depicting a scene of a bright white light with a deceased persons voice calling and the opposite side darker with a living voice calling suggesting a person teetering on death was a little uneeded ,the handcuffing of a serial killer to a policeman rather than handcuffing both his hands was strange and lastly after beating up 2 officers to be returned to an open centre mixing with a lot of individuals would never happen if returned he would be confined not allowed to roam freely? So for those 4 reasons it loses a star!

reviews.review_title: Jamie Dornan's look/demeanor is very fitting for this role
reviews.content: I normally don't watch any type of crime drama shows so I'm really enjoying it. I don't think it's slow-paced at all as other reviewers have mentioned.I hated Fifty Shades and thought Jamie Dornan would be well-suited in a serial killer role so when I stumbled upon The Fall I decided to check it out. He pulls it off quite well.I think Gillian Anderson does a fine job. I wasn't a big fan of The X-Files but it was ok. I feel like it was on so long ago it's pointless to compare. Not sure why so many reviewers are being so critical of her.
I gave this a 6, but it was a sloooww drama. Gillian Anderson had 2 expressions, probably because of all the Botox. And the ending was unsatisfactory. Sort of wondering what all the buzz was about.

reviews.review_title: It had my very impressed but some continuity problems I am afraid.
reviews.content: Well I enjoyed it but it had me scratching my head and I think the continuity slipped up. I love Gillian and although she came under criticism for talking in a whisper, and presenting as a strong bi-sexual woman, a misogynistic theme, well it was.I watched the DVD series several times, as I wasn't sure who was responsible for killing DS Olsen, and Olivia seemed to age incredibly in the third series. Also Spector was supposed to go to Scotland. Well Belfast is across the Irish sea from Scotland, and you can't drive or get a train there. If he went to Scotland as was suggested, he must have lied.But it kept my interest throughout, and I thought the acting was good, but the script had some continuity problems. After all one has to say ' it is fiction' or 'just a film' but the time period was set over say four months from Sarah's murder, and Olivia must have grown a foot at least. The ending, well it was not a trial and retribution series. Paul/Peter was going to win and escape Gibson's wrath, and he did. Destroying Katie, Sally and all those that he influenced and murdered. I don't know what happened to Liam? Does anyone or his mum Sally, who should not have been charged with interferring with justice. She came clean in the end, but trying to kill herself and her children, bit like Medea. But it is only a film.

First off everyone involved was on point by conveying their characters thoughts, facial gestures, and lines. Kudos to the writer for this masterful psychological cat and mouse creation. This gives the story a slow moving process but it all works as the story builds up to the last episode that made my eyebrows raise. I wasn't sure if i was left hanging with a i watched this for what, but the ending sat with me. I thought back later to those moments between serial killer James Dornam and Detective Superintendent Gillian Anderson and the supporting characters who were watching their personal relationship unfold over the phone, transcripts and personal journals being read, and observing their interviews. Key words, key comments, key looks, surface as i recalled -- this is a psychological thriller. Read between the lines. The Fall title means many subjective levels as a observer, the interactions of two main characters and how justice or injustice prevails. Wish i knew of this series sooner.

reviews.review_title: Excellent engrossing drama..poor detective and police work.
reviews.content: Gillian Anderson is more a therapist with a sexual urge on the side to keep her going. She feels emancipated having sex when she is in control - a kind when a star detective gets after solving a case. She is cold, slow and deliberate towards the victims and always alive, refreshed with men around her, and attracts an odd women too. Therefore much of the story revolves around her living her life and the killer is on the loose. She gets off elsewhere while is the case is running rife! The twain have never met - not even in mind...yet. After a few episodes, there aren't many substantial leads that this so called 'SIO' has. This is drama at its best - I have to give credit where credit it due....but hurts my intelligence to watch it. While I prefer and still watch Euro crime drama a lot more to American ones - this is is overrated. Having Anderson as lead was a mistake, IMO. Daring close ups reveal the wrinkles on her face - showing experience, none of which have boiled down to the story line..more on to the bed! X-files was enough with pretend-police work. She should use her talents elsewhere instead.I had high expectations, but this one seems to deliver little less...Maybe, just maybe if she gets off more solving murders...it would turn me on!!

Loved it. I think I've watched it for the third time already (over a stretch of time of course). Sucked in right from the first episode and the slow pace is such a welcome relief from other series in the same genre and yet still so engaging. The background of the somewhat raw and grim city of Belfast is very fitting. I really liked the last season where you have some thrilling scenes of dialogue between the killer and the detective. Those were so well acted with there facial expressions and you could just feel the suspension. Great acting performances.

reviews.review_title: The third season is quite a dip in quality
reviews.content: Still kept me in suspense because I felt like there were endless possibilities for things to really happen yet unfortunately they didn't. Those opportunities were not capitalized on and the season ultimately felt slow and a bit wasted.

Even this probably shows pretty realistic police work it's just lame... They better would have told this story in a 90 minute TV movie instead of expanding it over 3 seasons in a show. No recommendation if you prefer to get entertained or even thrilled.

The first two seasons were good but eventually lost steam in the third season. Also, there are loads of unbelievable things which happen like how Stella drove past a murder scene then asked to be introduced to a young policeman so she could eventually sleep with him, and then the same happens at another scene. Bearing in mind she already slept with her a male and a female colleague. Eventually her sexual endeavours mean nothing for the plot and you wonder why they included that. I failed to connect with her character if I'm honest, she was very cold but tried to convey empathy, which was hard to recognise as she just seemed a bit empty. She tried to show authority by acting calm but didn't turn out well.And the girl who falls for Paul, she got treated like crap and yet got obsessed with him, just didn't seem believable.And the when he goes to visit his victim to do therapy, surely she would remember him?!I've seen a lot of women liking this series and I think it's because of Jamie Dornan. Do the maths.Overall a decent series but it dragged on for the third season and it could've been just two seasons. Also, I was almost expecting it to have a serial killer for each season and conclude with each but was annoyed to think I would have to wait three seasons for the ending.

The first season is terrific, good story, great acting, Gillian Anderson is wonderful. The second season is ridiculous and silly. The serial killer just comes and goes as he pleases, several people should be very suspicious but aren't and he practically confesses to one woman and shows her a sketch from the newspaper but she just smiled and shows him her driver's license. I didn't bother watching the third season.

reviews.review_title: One of the best in the genre !!
reviews.content: "The Fall" is unarguably among the best web shows or movies on serial killer that I have watched in over 3 decades. Luckily I saw this series very late, that is after watching Netflix's Mindhunter's 2 seasons, I have to say that, Mindhunter was the theory lesson and The fall practical examination. One has to appreciate the fact all elements in making of a serial killer are well crafted and presented beautifully together in a classy way, 3-4 years before Mindhunter. I have watched only the first two seasons at the time of posting this comment on The fallThis show is for binge watching at its best; it's at once compulsively watchable and intelligent, well-written and beautifully acted with compelling performances to boot. Excellent Cinematography sets the tone for this dark show. Screenplay is very engaging and authentic but is guilty of slowing the plot many times. Music is equally fine, eirre and subtle suiting the mood of The fall. Costumes, make up and production design go overboard to make The fall as authentic as possible. Editing could have been a little better to avoid such a slow burn show that tests our patience. Good acting performances from most of the actors definitely goes the distance to make the show a intriguing watch. Jamie Dornan as Paul Spector, a rumpled-handsome grief counselor, dad, and husband who has some extremely alarming extracurricular activities steals the show with some really good acting.Overall, if one is interested in serial killers, The Fall might be a blessing as it is highly accurate to the core. But one has to have tremendous patience to go through this series as it is horrendously slow at times but the eventuality of a proper spectacle in return, kept viewers like me going. The Fall is definitely a very good reward for all viewers who exhibit good amounts of patience. Should have been 9 stars but I have to take a star out for its slow burn screenplay.
Excellent story line with a cast that delivers much more than expected. Without doubt one of the finest, gripping tv shows I've watched in a while!

reviews.review_title: Good crime drama. Too much Misandry and weak male characters
reviews.content: Overall, pretty good crime drama. Well acted and strong story. However, lots of cringy moments with preachy misandry. Gillian's role is basically a "flip" of a mysoginist. The other elements of the show are worth a look.

reviews.review_title: Men are evil. Women are genius with big brain
reviews.content: Eh, really enjoyed the spector character although too much gloomy scenes around the family. It seems Anderson's character just banged every male in the office. Show lost me when they whinged on about misogyny and further dragged it out with evil men. So evil. Hate men. Must make tv program about evil men. Grrrrr. Men. Woman better. Men touch no no square. Women make unicorn. Women make world go better. Women solve case. Men go durrrrrrr.

reviews.review_title: Great, if you like dark thrillers
reviews.content: I really liked this series. You don't often get a lot of character development with secondary or tertiary characters. The script is very realistic and gives full details for all of the characters. This show will satisfy you if you want a gritty, realistic plot that explores the minds of both the police and the criminals. As explained in the final scenes, this is NOT Disney. This is how police and criminals behave in real life.It is not Hollywood either, the series takes a while to build up to the ugly conclusion. Each character is flushed out and you understand their motivations and fears. As an American viewer, I really liked the locale, being in Northern Ireland, with the beautiful accents and some characters teetering on the edge of violence, the plot is a powder keg of personality explosions.Don't watch if you cannot tolerate scenes of sadism and brutality.

No doubt someone will turn this into a sanitized American miniseries: that means no nudity and watch the language. Gillian Anderson is the cop called in to take a look at a murder and she is the first to suspect it's a serial killer. Her Stella Gibson is somewhat stereotypical now: older woman, ambitious, sexually active and aggressive with a past like a bad male stud. I get a kick out of her continuous wardrobe malfunctions: cleavage and material that shows her nipple impressions clearly. Not really a spoiler to identify Jamie Dornan, prior to his big break in 50 Shades, as the killer as the plot isn't who he is but how he gets caught. Lets just say he is a rather twisted and warped killer who leaves far too many clues around his house for his young daughter to have access to. Add in a bunch of crooked developers, incompetent cops, and a very clueless wife and you have a four part series stretched out to an over long 11 episodes.

reviews.review_title: S2 is fantastic, the others, meh.
reviews.content: I'll get straight to the point. S1 was ok, but slow, though I appreciate you can't ramp straight to the action. S2 was fantastic, lots of twists and turns that kept you on the edge of your seat. S3 however, was disappointing. I didn't even like the ending, but the main reason was that they really stretched out the few events that happened, with many plot lines lacking climax. Give it a go, but watch S3 while you're multitasking, it won't hold your attention!
Far too much male on female violence for me. People find it to be entertainment, I find it to be disgusting.

The Fall is a superb thriller. It's genuinely sends shivers down your spine throughout pretty much the whole show! Gillian Anderson and Jamie Dornan are phenomenal as DSU Stella Gibson and serial killer Paul Spector. The acting is amazing as is the writing and the incredibly intense score. Definitely worth watching if you like e your crime thrillers!

The lead male actor is great, but that's where it stops sadly.
Mostly moves at a glacial pace which doesn't work as you know the killer and can assume he'll be caught in the end. After season 2 it becomes death by a thousand cuts
The underlying Irish (Catholic) 'bashing' is a bad cliche which doesn't help the series's cause either.
For something that promised so much, it delivered only a great performance by one actor.

Dark, compulsive viewing. Great cast and excellently put together.Jamie Dornan as Paul Spector is a terrifyingly calm and methodical serial killer and we are under no illusions as to what he is from the very start. This reminds me of the superlatively good "Cracker", where the viewer also learned from the outset who the culprit was but got the chance to sample the murderer's twisted fantasies and complex motivations through the superbly written and directed action and dialogue in a way that 8 seasons of Dexter did not quite achieve even despite having Dexter's voice-overs to clear upWhile Dexter was great I am trying to get across how much more gritty, dirty and realistic good British drama can be than its less demanding and more accessible American counterparts and The Fall epitomises that perfectly.John Lynch plays the police chief with the beautiful brooding tragedy that has been his trademark for several decades and Gillian Anderson plays the beautiful but cold SIO who is as cold and unempathetic as the killer himself.It should also be pointed out to previous reviewers Stateside that Anderson's well spoken southern English accent was flawless as it is in all British dramas that she does.I would have liked to see a bit more of Robbie Coltrane "post-match analysis" but in a way the ending, while not to many people's taste, was refreshingly different at least and I look forward to the next series with relish.

I think this series is really good. I suppose I could leave the review there. It's good! Everything about it is good.
It's quick enough paced. Some parts have you completely gripped. The acting is top notch by all the actors. Folk moaning about the accents don't actually realise that the actors apart from Anderson are English/Irish anyway. So they're not putting on an accent! Never mind saying the accents are poor. Jamie Dorman is not American! Anderson's English accent was passable although I do agree she whispers a lot. I loved the cold no frills macho personality to her. Jamie Dorman is creepy sexy. Plays his part so well. You like him because he's hot. But you hate him because of who he is. The teenage baby sitter is annoying which I guess means she plays her part well. Loved the backdrop of Belfast. Wonderful city that I've recently visited. Well worth a watch.

If THE FALL had been concluded in one season and Gillian Anderson didn't act like a Valium whispering she bot, this could have been a classic. It does generate actual terror and fear during the first season. I did not want to stop watching because I mistakenly believed each season would focus upon a new story. Sadly, it's all for nothing because the series drags on for three seasons. It's pure rubbish which should be highly recommended for GA groupies. Five stars are for what could have been. Jamie Dornan is seen shirtless most of the time. There's a token lesbian kiss and series one is recommended for people who like slow burn television with no result.

reviews.review_title: Too slow to love but decent cat and mouse crime chase
reviews.content: A decent show, but it could've been condensed into shorter episodes. It dragged out and a fair amount of scenes were painfully slow and very long.The main plot is pretty good, although I didn't care for some of the side plots. It's an intense story and some of the scenes are fairly graphic. I wouldn't recommend watching this show with family or in a public place for that reason.

The Fall is a crime thriller set in Northern Ireland. A serial killer pursued by a driven female lead detective brought in from London based on her experience and expertise in leading investigations into serial crimes. Both key characters have issues. The killer is obsessed with a specific type of woman whilst the female lead detective has an obsessive need to bed younger men who fit a certain profile. Its a disturbing drama. It not only looks at the crimes but also the fall out for those touched by them. The family of the serial killer, a young girl who becomes obsessed with the killer and to a lesser degree the families of the victims and the police seeking to catch him. The main theme of this drama, for me at least, is the nature of obsession. What drives peoples predilections in a specific and often self destructive direction? The acting is top quality. Gillian Anderson does a great job as they tough female lead detective, whilst the killer, played by Jamie Dornan, is both charming, cold and calculating. Its an excellent series perhaps only let down a little by some of the rather inexplicable gaffs made by the highly intelligent killer. The sexual merry go round that revolves around Anderson's character also seems a little implausible at times too.Eight out of ten from me.

Amazing series with superb acting by the 2 main leads."Cat and Mouse" tension over all 3 series.The musical score adds to the tension - All characters are played superbly well.Anderson is a revelation and keeps the tension going.All 3 series are great with a good finale.

I just rewatched this show for the 3rd time and still found it very realistic and disturbing. It's undoubtedly one of the best crime series that have ever been made.The show demonstrates a very in-depth psychological analysis into a serial killer's mind which is not often a case in a crime drama. It makes the killer resembles our real life but somehow his background story and the portrayal makes this character more compassionate.Some people may argue the third season is a put down of the whole series but I beg to differ. This season may be in a different genre and pace than the previous one but it is very essential to tell the background story of Paul Spector in order to explain his motives and behaviour. Also, this season creates a moral argument for the viewers whether is it worthy to spend so many resources to save an evil monster? It definitely develops a new perspective to watch this show.

reviews.review_title: Way Below Average British Detective Series
reviews.content: My wife and I have watched a great number of British detective series. The Fall is not one of the better ones. Stella Gibson is one of the most unlikable lead detectives we have seen. Gillian Anderson's wooden acting with the long pensive stretches where she just stares at someone or something doesn't help. Jamie Dornan is miscast as Paul Spector, the serial murderer. He is too perfect as a father, grief counselor, and husband. He looks like your standard issue, handsome male actor with no menace or dark side. You'd never know how cold-blooded and evil he really is. The attempt at mind games between Spector and Gibson isn't believable. There is no way this series deserves an 8.3. We give it a 5.0. Don't waste your time (we watched series 1 & 2; couldn't stand to watch series 3).

reviews.review_title: Good except for the lead woman detective's whispering.
reviews.content: The blonde detective in charge drove me up the wall with her mannerisms especially the way she talks so low in a whisper to everyone you can't hear what she says. I didn't appreciate that one bit! Or the way she took every new young policeman in her office home to her bed. She hit on every single young male detective who was assigned to her department. Why couldn't we have a lead detective with morals who followed protecal about no interoffice relations? This lead detective is a loose woman who has issues with men & behaviors that give her a bad reputation. Realistically this wouldn't be tolorated by her boss. She also ridiculed men & would say things to them like the thing men fear most about women is being laughed at by them. Besides her the other actors were just fine. The serial killer was fantastic! He made the show! I think the ending could have been better. It was unrealistic because a real serial killer would of made a break for it & tried to escape a psychiatric hospital once he had the chance! And he most definitely could of escaped.

reviews.review_title: Could have been so much more
reviews.content: I was intrigued by the first season and carried on. The Paul Spectre actor was very good, and you could feel his intensity. Gillian Anderson, on the other hand, tried way too hard to be a smouldering vixen police detective and it did not work. Throughout the series, she just came off as inauthentic. Why would any detective wear 5 inch heels at a crime scene or when interviewing criminals with breathy voice tone? Please.The last season was way too ambiguous and didn't come to a satisfactory ending. I give it the five starts for the Spectre actor, the photography, and the other actors who did a superb job.
The worst ending ever, left me with the feeling that I'd wasted time watching the entire series when the writers conjured up an absolutely pathetic conclusion

reviews.review_title: It seems Gilian Anderson fells herself...
reviews.content: Knowing her performance since the first appearance as Dana Scully I had high expectations for this new psychological-profile series with Ireland as background.Sadly watching it had its downsides. The depiction of actually all adults as corrupted and burned-out, emotionally abusive and selfish-hypocrites was just one too-dark streak in my opinion.The camera and lighting is crappy, reminding more of found-footage than professionals at work. Everything is dark and gloomy, dirty and derelict in its own way. Everything is actually UGLY.The great specter, the serial, is another narcissist, craven brute babbling about introversion being identical with ignoring reality, which is NOT true and neither does it make us powerful.Lolita-Sex, as specter had that teenage pseudo-p*rn girl seduced and indoctrinated, didn't free me from the impression that the aging actors just wanted to take-out their frustration about lost youth on a younger generation. For me it failed because that female teenager is such a misbehaving foolish-c*nt that i care neither about her breasts, nor about her unleashed sermon.This is no skilled new NOIR, nor is it it anything special. 'Those who kill' had at least a purposely chosen dark humor about it (in the US version) and the Danish or Swedish original was a solid crime series instead.
