'True Detectives' was, at least in season one, more authentic about police investigations.I wondered before how a country being afraid of product-placement can manage to be utterly careless about using prison inmates or patients of psychiatric institutions as actors. It leaves a sickening impact to any mature audience after all.One aspect of the freaky touch is that is recurrent. People in denial actually admiring and near worshiping the serial instead of hunting him down and locking him away. The jolly and hard-working Irish I met in my real life have never made such a bad impression. But then, this is just my view and it is against the onslaught of high-voters...But to give you a hint: ANY really good series is repeated in pay-TV before it is dumped into German Free TV. 'The Fall' was not even a Free TV weekend special, but a simple working day filler. ;-)

The writers made the police look like idiots. Why didn't they release his name earlier? Why hadn't they checked out the farm house earlier? I had all of those questions while watching the show. VERY slow paced and incompetent. Even the head inspector. I thought why didn't she tell them to get in the car after finding the body. I thought he was going to escape in the forest.

I liked it, it was very well written. I just feel that it became a bit of a war on all men and all of their behaviour.Its good that you addressed some very important behaviours, predominantly with men but come on, by the second series i think every male character was displaying toxicity. Not accurate and i did end up switching off part the way through series two.

reviews.review_title: Contrived pretentious...difficult to believe the ratings
reviews.content: I watched about 4 episodes. That's 4 episodes of time that I will never recover in my life. Amateur questioning by various interrogating officers, pace so slow and glacial that you get bored the middle of an episode several times.I cannot imagine what kind of people actually enjoyed this enough to actually sit and watch all series and to give it 8, 9 or inconceivable 10 ratings; wow. These must be the same kind of people who have little imagination to watch anything more inventive.

Season 1&2 were thrilling,so much that I had to binge watch all the episodes. Season 3 , with the 1st episode ,I knew it was done just to drag the story . There was not much substance in most of the episodes in S3 . Lot of new characters added, lot of hospital scenes, felt like I was watching Greys Anatomy. Nevertheless ,the series as a whole ,was a good watch . I wish it had ended with S2.

All the tension is drained out now that Spector is captured, and so the writer toys around with psychobabble to elicit interest in motivation. Boring. So they bring in a sleazy lawyer to get him off, and he promptly allows his client to plead guilty to a crime recently discovered. So then they decide to let him saunter around unshackled. Didn't they see "Silence Of The Lambs?" Without anyone to play with Andersen's character's flat affect gets flatter, and our interest in her diminishes. For a moment there they tease us with his possible escape, now that might have saved it, but no.
This was brilliant. Both Gillian Anderson and Jamie Dornan were excellent. Season 3 was a tad drawn out, but still entertained. Had me hooked.

Fantastically well done game of cat and mouse in an intriguing police procedural thriller.Has some excellent twists and turns and Dornan really shows off some serious acting chops. Would be great to see him given another chance in something substantial on the big screen.Anderson's portrayal is brilliantly delivered but her 'breathy' delivery becomes increasingly irritating as you get through the seasons.Gripping and twisting tale that seemed to then suddenly pull the parachute (and just end in a bit of a cop out) in the final episode that doesn't really deliver on its otherwise clever narrative and until then excellently convoluted tale.

Loved the entire series, the pace is engaging.
Loved the editing especially, how they cut scenes at similar actions. The music, the cast, everything. Just felt the Burns's character was a bit *better*

Beautifully played out over 3 series (I watch during the course of a week), the tale was very believable and compelling; the actors and actresses. Placed brilliantly.Usually I struggle to commit to long term series, but this one just grabbed me and so very pleased I watched it until the end.On a negative note - Stella's monotone voice began to grate after a while, but hey - just me!!!

"Female is the fundamental human form".
An extreme political opinion propagated through the series. A score of five makes sense for a series insulting half the audience. Good job writers, you really showed those male monsters what's up.... ROFL.

reviews.review_title: Compelling but season 3 was a big letdown
reviews.content: Season 1 and 2 were addictive to the point I'd binge on them. Was watching on Amazon Prime. But then it got to season 3 and I couldn't understand why they opted for such a drab storyline. It was really quite unbelievable all the way through and the end is so unbelievable and unsatisfying.Worth a watch though.S03E01 and S03E02 were very visceral 'Casualty'-type episodes. Some have said it's unnecessary, but, while very different from the rest of the seasons and episodes, I thought they were well filmed too and offered a really clinical take on things.
Just absolutely great acting from everyone but how they catch the serial killer is extremely stupid.

reviews.review_title: Would have scored it a 10 but.....
reviews.content: Each season is a little too long. Had me intrigued though and didn't see the final ending coming at all...Gillian Anderson is actually British not American and speaks English- so, you haters need to stop criticising. I loved her in this and she was brilliant, don't think she smiled at all....pure ice queen and her and Jamie Dornan were sensational together on screen.

Hey Writer, can you make a 3 season series out of this 90 minute thriller? - Sure, bro! Hold my beer.There should be three episodes where we see Stella Gibson sleeping in real time, just to get a reel feel of the story.And I would add an extra season where she goes to the farmers market and buy fruit (like bananas, peaches, apples, mangos) and vegetables (like spinach, broccoli, cucumber and carrots) and then she should wait for the bus for 25 mins as her car is under repair and meet a Mormon missionary who would tell her the FULL STORY of his church.Yeah I think I missed these things.

Well-written, well-acted psychological thriller. The layered and nuanced storyline was excellent. Anderson hasn't really been on my radar since her days as Scully, and she turned in an incredible performance. Her interrogation scenes with Spector were almost Shakesperean. Well worth the investment of time.

reviews.review_title: Waiting for Season Three, but here is my opinion thus far
reviews.content: I watched seasons one and two and I have really enjoyed them. My only question about the actors is Gillian Anderson. She is meant to play a strong sexually self aware woman who feels she should be able to have casual affairs in the manner she imagines men to have them but does she really have to be so uptight and cold. She may as well been riding B.O.B. for the sort of sex she was having.Otherwise I don't mind her flat affect and her painfully slow delivery of her lines, I think it is to help her keep her accent consistent, it fits with her character as a woman who figures to play the man's cop game if she manages to shred all emotional response.Jamie Dornan in the role is great, he is strange and erratic and has an appropriately off putting personality that keeps you on edge. When he does the mirroring thing with his superiors it comes off as really strange and and aggressive though he is mainly passive with other people except when he is with a victim. How he acts in season three will be interesting.Another reviewer mentioned the fact that they were filming in Belfast and they needed to show a bit more of the city and other places and I agree and it is great to see the actual streets of Belfast and hear the language and the accents. That is one of the things that intrigued me about the show because I had never seen a show like it filmed in Belfast without it being about the Troubles, though the tension does linger and the show does not shy away from that fact and lets it play out organically.I recommend anyone who is interested in police procedure and British and Irish television to give The Fall a look.
The scenario was good , but extremely slow and boring , it was hard to finish the whole 3seasons.

reviews.review_title: Don't be deceived by the great reviews based on the first episode!
reviews.content:
The first few episodes are good. The acting of the 2 main characters is not convincing but everybody else is just brilliant. Then I spent 2 and a half seasons waiting for something to happen.
Based on how uncreative the whole thing is, I know 3 stars is generous but I did enjoy the first episode and it's always great to se Scully again, even in such a bad role. Hats off for Mr Lynch, his acting was superb.
Amazing psychological twist. I'm ar Episode 3. Hope they don't screw it up.

This started off ok , well acted and produced. But wow is it drawn out, I am into this genre but at the start of season 2 I totally lost interest. My wife lasted till season 3 but fell asleep and gave up on it. To be honest I do not care how it finished.
Gillian Anderson must have been at a loose end. She plays the lead investigator who tries to sleep with the whole police department, great way to get the respect of your team. That in itself made no sense.

reviews.review_title: It should have been called The Wall, because that's how interesting it is.
reviews.content: I'm confused, is this a show about how stupid the police can be?This guy would have been locked up inside two episodes.I have only watched season 1 and I can't see how there are more series. They have got him haven't they?Talk about sloooooow. I'm falling asleep trying to watch this rubbish.Gillian looks great though.

I rarely give anything a rating of 10. I could pick holes in it technically and give it an 8 or a 9 or whatever but that would miss the point.
This is one of those rare occasions when you think you know what you're looking for, but something else comes along, and it's perfect.

In the same fashion as so many other excellent BBC dramas, ("Downton", "Broadchurch", "Selfridges", "Call the Midwife", so on and so forth) this show is/was... well... excellent all the way around. Superb acting and directing; this show - once again, like a lot of other BBC offerings - has a terrific blend of sophisticated camera work, music, and everything else that goes into quality film making. The plot kept me guessing and I enjoyed the way it went off into several sub-plots while the main crux played out. Spotted it on Netflix and sure glad I perchance gave it a shot.(Question; Why just 5 episodes and more importantly - will there be more?)

reviews.review_title: Weak but still better than Chernobyl
reviews.content:
Season 1 was interesting I give you that , because its Scully as a détective !! With that interesting killer, when I saw that I had to watch this show !! And because its new and because there is so few episodes ( 17 ? ) The first few episode ( Season 1 ) are correct, season 2 drop in quality but remain watchable but man Season3.... Season 3 is the Worst Season of any Seasons of any TV show i have ever watch ( except Chernobyl) ... Boring af, absolutely nothing New happen, you Can stop with Season 2 because nothing else will happen. Poor Gillian Anderson who used to play in the Greatest show ever and now Whisper all the Time in that Bad show...
6.5/10 for Season 1.

Spector (J.Dornan) vs Gibson (G.Anderson) return for Series 3 of the acclaimed crime drama The Fall and what started off as a slow burner has quickly turned into a fiery concoction of tension, darkness & eeriness....Back on form you could say! The next episode screens tonight on BBC2, however, if you're new to The Fall we'd highly recommend you start with Seasons 1 first.For fans of: Happy Valley, Luther, The Killing, The Missing, Broadchurch.Geek fact: The naming of the characters along with some business & place names are legendary guitars (Gibson, Spector, Burns, Stagg).Like us at fb.me/inanutshelluk

reviews.review_title: Very Well Made and a Fairly Original Cop vs Serial Killer Show
reviews.content: Gillian Anderson really led this series as the Inspector who led the task force to hunt the serial killer played by James Dornan. None of the leads were cardboard characters including Dornan who played the killer Spector. He was a devoted family man and a perceptive grief counselor who in his spare time liked breaking into women's houses, playing with their underwear then returning later to kill them. It was a smart, very psychological and trendy writing that covered all the hot button topics related to that genre and the motivation of the killer.But honestly what wore me down was the overly procedural aspect of the show where much time was spent on the minutia of modern bureaucratic police work and even medical emergency care. It gave it realism but honestly was over done. But the biggest drag was the feminist all-men- are-scum aspect to it. It blatantly made almost all the men, including her superior Inspector Burns, look brutish and incompetent. It also had one doctor openly say that women are stronger and need to take over, though he may have been jesting. But it really ended up getting all preachy in a grating SJW way. Then towards the end it started getting sloppy. The killer attacks Inspector Gibson and her young male assistant Tom Anderson, kind of a fey guy, in an interrogation room. Then the other cops just pull the killer off and then ship him back to the criminal psych center instead of at least charging him with a serious charge of assaulting police officers. Then the idiots at the psych center let him go on like the rest of the inmates, instead of isolating him, until he caused brutal finale of the series. Then there was a previous incident when while in custody, the killer took the inspector to a location where he left a kidnap victim in a car's trunk in the woods. Instead of detailing a unit or two to block off the access to the woodsy area where they had him, a car with another nutcase with a gun, who had a beef with the killer over his wife, drove in and shot the killer and Inspector Anderson not fatally. Of course, the female patrol officer and part time assistant to our intrepid inspector, since the males are so useless, finally put this idiot shooter down.The Northern Ireland Belfast setting was also interesting too. Whatever its faults, this show was a million times better than the similar in vein "The Killing" with its stench of a million red herrings per episode

reviews.review_title: Exciting till you see the season 2
reviews.content: I gave it a 6 however to be more precise i would score first series 8 and the second maybe 4. I need to admit that i did not make it through all 6 episodes of that one... my wife did quit after seeing the second one and i gave up after third reassured me that it all goes from one absurd to another and the story goes nowhere!What an opportunity wasted! It is clear for me that this particular story had enough potential for one series, and it should have ended right there.The producers could have followed the pattern of drafting another villain for 2nd series, copycat maybe that would be more devious and cunning then the one portrayed.instead they chose to follow up with same guy, adding just some semi-superpowers that allow him to fool the whole police force and poor Gillian that is left with just the surprise on her face...My advise for you viewer is to see the 1st series, and then drop the idea of going for the 2nd - there is just nothing there and what is even more frightening is that they seem to think 3rd one is a good idea
Gripping, insightful, interesting, incredible acting, they show you all aspects of all the different stages of investigations. An absolute must watch!

The Bitter Joy, The Stumbling Mistakes, The Retribution characterize the feel and vibe for the three seasons of the Fall respectively.It is a series, which starts slowly, phlegmatically with an intriguing atmosphere and unfolding of events, then gathers speed, but to the wrong path, until crashing with glorious sadness.My above remarks may seem strange as I rated the show a 9, but make no mistake, my unique rating all goes to the superb performances by Jamie Dornan and Aisling Franciosi, by some of the supporting cast (mainly the daughter with her shiny and believable acting) and to the active cinematography.What I did not like in the show was the script and storyline. Do you start a show on the subject just to have the serial-killer make those blunt mistakes, those pathetic choices and make him go head-on into the arms of the investigating force and then going on with his failures and bad choices?If it was the goal of the creator and writer(s) to create a dark parody depicting a serial-killer's self-destructive journey, well, he succeeded brilliantly.Also, as far as it comes to Gillian Anderson, as hard as she may try to be professional (she nearly succeeds) and put up a good acting play, she just does not do it right IMO, because of her uncharismatic presence, her too blonde hairs in comparison to their root color, her wooden acting, her constant state of mental fatigue, slow-motionness as if she bears centuries of weights on her shoulders and her self-imprisonment creatively in her very personal ivory tower.
She had similar problems in the X-Files, with the difference and to a lesser degree because she was then younger and a little more petulant, did not have to play practical lead roles and was almost constantly in the shadow of David Duchovny.On the soundtrack and music, nothing very specific and memorable to hint about. What wanted to be and show itself as suspenseful soundtrack moments just added to the overall depression and void.Watch it for the two actors who shine in it. Jamie Dornan and Aisling Franciosi.
Her fate and the debilitating effects of her true undying love got to my throat and clamped it hard...Darkly recommended...
The pace is too slow. Everything else is great. The show is full of surprises. The second and third seasons are more intriguing.

It's hard for me to rate any BBC-related crime procedural below 7, so it's worth watching, but I found this one tedious. Sorry, but if Gillian Anderson says this is her favorite role maybe it's because the camera lingers on her blank face and her ridiculous blond mane for minutes at a time while the viewer is supposed to feel... something. I was told in a writing class once that if the story has no likable characters, people may not like the story. I didn't find any characters I cared about in this series except maybe the almost pornographically portrayed victims. The frowning upon priest pedophiles, wife abusers and male sexists in various episodes is very morally instructive but I have to wonder about the show's underlying premise that women are turned on by a serial killer.

Forget light fare like Silence of the Lambs or Mindhunter. If you want a proper serial killer yarn, this is the stuff.Every episode, all three seasons, bleak as hell, and it gets worse. Then worser.Thoroughly enjoyed this, and Gillian Anderson is looking hot.

I really enjoyed the first season of this show - the casting, the dialogue, the plot development, the photography, the creepy & foreboding atmosphere. The second season also started off well, but then things got awfully bogged down. I fully expected the story to be finished by the final episode of that season, so I felt badly cheated when it ended on a cliffhanger. Nevertheless, even after the long wait for the third season, I still found myself curious enough to see how everything worked out. Unfortunately, the third season is the weakest of all. It's excruciatingly slow in pace, with many long silent takes, supporting storylines that go nowhere, and what seemed to me (as an American) to be absurd lapses in procedure. Maybe things are different in the UK, but over here a confessed serial killer (especially one so physically formidable) would not be allowed into an interrogation room without being well restrained. (Not to mention what happened afterward at the psychiatric facility!) Now that I've seen all three seasons, I still think this is high-quality long-form TV, but for me it can't compare with such other recent thrillers as The Bridge (original Danish/Swedish version), the first season of True Detective, or the ongoing Icelandic thriller, Trapped. One final point: I notice a sharp split in these IMDb reviews about Gillian Anderson's performance. Like many others, I was somewhat annoyed by the increasing breathiness of her voice over the three seasons, but I still find her a riveting presence on screen, and her name at the top of a cast list will still be a major draw for me.

reviews.review_title: One of the best and most chilling tv dramas ever. A triumph
reviews.content: Dark, moody, menacing but never formulaic, The Fall takes you inside the mind of a murderer and it's gripping stuff. Gillian Anderson, plays an icy yet vulnerable female police chief and Jamie Dornan is the family man who has a deadly double life. Both play their parts beautifully, never over acting or over stating anything, just delivering believable and charismatic performances in this cat and mouse tale. Because of the subject matter, it is very hard hitting and may be upsetting for some viewers of more delicate natures. You will never see a better thriller, and although I have seen comparisons to the also excellent "Hannibal", this is a bleaker, very British tale of the psychology of murder that would give nordic noir a run for its money - even Krister Hendriksen of Wallander fame, turns up in this as a Swedish head shrinker! Scary, adult, uncompromising and compelling drama. Although Season 3 has a slightly different tone, all seasons are stand out. The little girl who plays the killer's daughter is one of the most convincing child actors I've seen for a long time. Highly recommended.

reviews.review_title: TYPICAL BRITISH DRAMA TURNING FROM REALISTIC TO ILLOGICAL
reviews.content: English TV drama writers dig major impossible circumstances, just to make room for drama strong enough to make the audience forgive them. In this case, the police irrational decision create a surreal non realistic balance of forces between the criminal and whole metropolitan police so the conflict escalates.

reviews.review_title: Spoiled for me after the end of the first season.
reviews.content: I was really enjoying this series up until the end of season 1 where something happens that I can't really understand. Peter goes in for questioning at some point because he was seen on CCTV with his daughter and he gives his statement which is all entered in the database of the police. At the very end of the first season in the phone call between Stella and Peter, Stella bluffs in calling the caller Peter while she is not sure of his name yet, he doesn't answer to that as she rants on about what will happen to him and his family and throws the phone in the water. What bugs me is that why didn't Stella look through the database of the people questioned in relate to the murders if she thinks the killers name is Peter? And they even have a drawing of his face.. it seems very unlikely to me that no one in the huge team working on solving the murders would think to chase this. While she follows every tiny lead that she can find but not this obvious one.. it makes no sense to me and it has made the series a lot less appealing because I'm looking at them struggling to resolve this case while it could have been done a long time ago.I will still watch it till the end because the acting is quite good and I am hoping they will redeem somehow.

reviews.review_title: Great start trailed away to ridiculous
reviews.content: I don't understand the acting technique where actors talk more softly to emphasise the intensely of the emotion. In the strongest scenes their speech gets quieter and quieter until almost silent. Gillian Anderson has mastered this technique and it drives me crazy! In series one she spoke like a normal person but by series three she was unwatchable. I didn't make it through to the end I found it just too annoying.

I rewatched this show and may have even liked it more the second time. I thought Jamie Dornan's character was extremely captivating and very nice to look at. And Gillian Anderson played her part to perfection as well. I think... no, I know it's the best show I've seen. I've never seen a show about a serial killer that gave you such insight in to both sides of his character.He was a very loving, caring father while a monster at the same time. It's not until the 3rd season that you really find out why he carries such anger.I thought the show was brilliant and I know I'll watch it again at some point. I really wish it received more acclaim, I would never have heard of it if my daughter hadn't told me about it.Those of you who didn't like seeing a woman take the lead, sweet nights and all, I'm sure had no problem when men did it on screen forever. That's the norm. This was original in every sense of the word.

One of the best shows which built on similar real events which basically relay on two different stories..but still reflect the events, the experience of the crimes which happened.Also, Even the show was too long for the story, but its attracts you in so weird way.

reviews.review_title: Engaging but has serious pacing problems
reviews.content: The plot is engaging. However the pacing is extremely slow. I enjoy deliberately paced movies and series but this is a bit too slow. Nevertheless it was still atmospheric, tension filled, and engaging. Third season was unnecessary and seemed like they were stretching the story and plot lines for no reason other than to have 3 seasons. With judicious editing they could have told the same story in a single season and made it more engaging.

I fail to understand why so many people rated it so high... It's dul, l its boring, it's so slow.. Will make you sick.There is a drug track which is uncalled for..There is a one night stand just to give the lead lady make a profound dialogue later on about it.
From a country, when the benchmark is broadchurch... This falls sort... Way way below.
My feedback to all those who have just watched one or two episodes and reading this review to know more about the series to make up their mind..Trust your mind and stop wasting your time right away..

reviews.review_title: Many, more eloquently than I, have commented, but ...
reviews.content: I found the demise of Paul Spector and the sharing of Stella and Katie, although unfulfilled, most fitting. While we might have wanted him to go to trial, and his anamnestic state revealed, his attestation of his real persona was sufficient. And that even Ms Wallace would no longer support his defense speaks to his, how shall I say? evil. I am still puzzled, however, by the meaning of the scribbled note on the 20£ note, and who gave it to Spector in the first place.

I've just rewatched this series again on Netflix having watched it on the BBC when it was originally broadcasted 7 years ago (season 1..)Gillian Anderson is faultless a long side Jamie Dornan, especially in the first season.. and the only reason I'm giving it an 8, and not higher, is because season 2-3 are a bit long winded and kind of drag on a bit, but overall a very good series..

reviews.review_title: Worth a look if you overlook the silly bits
reviews.content: Not sure this needed to be 18 hours but it was worth a watch. Not keen on the emotional Gillian Anderson scenes that were simply not realistic and Spectre would never have looked like that after having assaulted her. He would've been twisted up and shown the realities of life in the cells. Tiresome scenes of people waking up from nightmares could also have been left out but on the whole not bad.

It takes a little time but step by step the story becomes more involving. If you're not catched by ghe first three episodes gibe the fourtha chance ;)First of all I'm stunned by the acting of Gillian Anderson. The X-Files actress seems at the first glance a bit bald and boring - but more and more it becomes clear, thats its a perfect painting of an lonely, focused and passionate detective.Jamie Dornan is wonderfull. No words. A murder and a family father.Finally, you really have to watch all three seasons to have the whole story :) season 1 and 2 are great, season 3 is not the best...

I totally missed series one of this excellent drama. Gillian Anderson holds this together like a conductor within an orchestra. I watched it out of sync, from episode 3 of season 2. This meant I watched from the police perspective. At this stage I even thought the villain was being picked on by the authorities.Then watched season 1 and the first two episodes of season 2. Now watching from the villains perspective and knowing his responsibility. Finally watching the last 1 episode in-situ. Looking back on this order of episodes it could not have worked out better as this maintained the suspense that season one would have revealed. Jamie Dornan will now require a much bigger price tag for his services after Fifty Shades of Grey. 10/10. I am surprised at how BBC2 got to be involved in such an excellent drama and intrigued as to where season 3 will go.

Excellent writing, Gillian Anderson's best role, Jamie Dornan a bit wooden at first but really displays great acting after mid second season, great thrilling series which maintains amazing suspense throughout. Direction is a bit questionable, the killer seems to have luck on his side a few too many times, breaking that realism it is so good with most of the time which is a shame. It teases you thinking he's on the brink of getting caught through his nonchalant attitude. You do question the purpose behind certain things. The greatest mystery is the rapid aging of the killer's daughter at the start of Season 2 but overall, a great show! First 2 seasons were fantastic, 3rd season makes the show more into a medical drama, loses its momentum and the appealing suspense. Such a shame, writers appeared to have ran out of steam. A waste of what they'd achieved the first 2 seasons!

reviews.review_title: Season 1 is best, 2 is good, 3 skip.
reviews.content: Very good but Season 3 is way too slow. It looks like they let go the police advisors since many of the correct law enforcement protocols are gone. The show lost credibility due to unreal scenarios.

I liked season 1 and 2 but season 3 was so bad that it killed the show for me. Police making bad moves, no security at all. This would not happen in real life. It's obvious that the makers of the show did not know how to fill 6 episodes.The first 3 episodes are somewhat like a hospital show. In general it was boring and slow.

Really good yarn of finding and the means of dealing with people who do evil things. Jamie Dornan does a brilliant job and is consistent in portraying his character through 17 episodes. And Gillian A does a good job as a determined cop. Bit slow in parts compared to US-produced crime series, but the twists in the storyline keep you enthralled. Endings of series 2 and 3 are unexpected and jaw-dropping. And the editing with the switches between the characters and locations is well done. And the pace makes the series more realistic. The breathy delivery of lines by Gillian A and Jamie R in spots is a bit annoying some times - getting lessons from the Kiefer Sutherland school of acting. Strongly recommended.

reviews.review_title: You may hate Mr. Grey (50 Shades), but you'll love Jamie Dornan
reviews.content: Only very minor spoilers:We decided to watch this, before ever seeing 50 Shades, which made some people (incl. us) thinking Jamie Dornan is a horrible actor. The Fall seemed like an unknown series with few reviews at that moment. In a time of exposure, it's a relief to watch something you haven't formed an opinion of yet.The Fall keeps no secret. Witin moments it's clear that Jamie Dornan is a stone cold killer, and it's up to G. Anderson to catch him, but not without having her own flaws and forming some sort of a bond with the handsome killer.The contrast is amazing. Dornan is a sick psychopath, with a seemingly functional private life. While on the other side Anderson is a amazingly competent investigator, with a dysfunctional private life. And without slowing the series down, or putting to much emphasis on flash backs, you have a whole season of development. By the time season 1 ends, like in Game of Thrones, you will not be the first viewer to fall in love with the attractive, fearless and in the same time vulnerable and human character that is Jamie Dornan.Sex may not be a main item, but as Anderson and Dornan draw closer, the (sexual) tension is palpable which will make you wonder how much they feel for each other, and what will happen if they meet.With much success the series builds on character development, relations with each other, but also with supporting characters. While the hunt for victims and the killer continues without getting too slow.Without giving too much away, it will take a 2nd season before we get to the confrontation between the adversaries who may have so much in common. And that confrontation is what everything builds up to. Both are gods among men and stand above limitations, morals, laws, boundaries and feelings. That confrontation will be a let out for every moment of tension that has been building up since the 1st episode. That moment people will realize that Anderson is not Scully from X-files anymore. But also that Dornan is an amazing actor, able to steal the whole show with his penetrating soul stare.The only downside of the show is the end, which is sort of a letdown. But the biggest lesson besides having a near perfect 1st and 2nd season, is that we have a new leading star, great in all modesty, and rises above the mistake that is the earlier mentioned movie. Fun fact is that his character in FSoG3 will be more like his character in The Fall. Some people do learn.

I started watching The Fall during the Covid-19 pandemic and to say that it was a huge mistake would be an understatement. My mental state during the pandemic was made worse by this over-hyped show, primarily due to the ridiculously slow pace at which it moves ahead. The whole series could have been compressed into just one season, which would have perhaps made it exciting. But instead, it stretches on for no reason at all. It makes the Irish police look incompetent. They have all the evidence and live location of the killer, yet they simply fart around for 3 episodes before finally arresting him. The male protagonist is not too convincing as a serial killer. The dude has fewer expressions than David Bekham and does not really invoke the fear that a serial killer is supposed to. The writing is very average, and the transformation of some characters is unconvincing. Screenplay is extremely dull and made worse by lack of expression and the slow progress in storyline. The show tries to leverage Gillian Anderson's brand a lot, but her character too is not very well written. A unique, engaging soundtrack would have given this show a little excitement but it's also as dull as it's other aspects. Unless you have a lot of time on your hands, or getting brain-fried is your idea of a good series, I would not recommend The Fall.

reviews.review_title: A beautifully written and well acted drama
reviews.content: The Fall follows a serial killer in Belfast and the police force trying to catch him.The series has a definite Scandi Noir feel to it from the beautiful greyscale cinematography and elements of harsh realism that get under your skin. There are no cheap Hollywood horror tricks, no suspenseful string refrains or CGI. The acting and screen writing speaks for itself in its honesty. The political and sociological themes are extremely well addressed and add a fascinating element to the examination of human nature, which ultimately is what the series is about.The show is masterfully scripted, shot and the acting is on point. Both Gillian Anderson and Jamie Dornan perform their lead with effortless grace and conviction, but what truly surprises is the incredible standard of the supporting actors. John Lynch as Jim Burns, Bronagh Waugh as Sally Ann Spector and Aisling Francioci in particular deserve a mention.

For the first season, and most of the second I was prepared to give this series a 10/10. I thoroughly enjoyed the slow pace and the gradual unraveling of the story line and the mysterious portrayal of the main characters psyche. I liked that it wasn't overly dramatic and that Spector, despite being an abhorrent psychopath, was shown in a strikingly human light at times - not overly vilifying his character added to the realism of the series in my opinion.
However, with the conclusion of the second season and the entirety of the third, the quality of the show went downhill, with the final episode of the show being a complete and utter mess. Seeing as the series was drawn out over a long and slow 17 episodes, which could have easily been condensed into a more action-packed format, you'd hope to get a satisfying end which would justify the build up. This didn't happen. Instead, you get a conclusion which leaves you thinking whether the writers even knew where they were going with the plot until they got to the end and realised it was time to wrap up. Such a disappointing finale to what started out as a great psychological British crime drama.
The decent 7/10 rating is solely due to the great first and second season, the third would have received a 2/10.

I feel like this is so different from every other police force drama the narrative is so detailed and time has been taken to make it so realistic. The way the script is written in every scene is so detailed specifically in season 3 episode one when rose is found and detective Stella has a conversation with her husband as how he should help support his wife through her trauma rather than fight her, dialogue like that has never been done before it's a resolution to a real life experience and is something I will use in my life.

..but this was a thrill from start to end! The suspense, the story, the incredible details, all of it. Topped up with outstanding acting performances. Gillian plays this so naturally and immerses the viewer into the story, her emotions are perfectly visible, she just rocks this. No other actress could've played this better.The bad guy, very impressive performance, he gets everything right, the expression, the play, the hunt and the fantasy, just wow.Altogether, a fantastic show. I've seen some reviews say series 3 was unnecessary, on the contrary! It actually ends the story in very fluidly.

In spite of a couple of things that personally didn't appeal to me, this was a good nail-biter.First off, I can't watch Sully with a Thatcher English accent and bleached hair.. it creeps up on me throughout the show and I find it distracting.The other thing, especially in the 3rd season, the time spent on minutia was nearly unbearable. It could have been tightened up quite a bit, made in 2 seasons and not missed anything. But that's me.Otherwise, the plot, twists and turns were excellent. A good mystery. Great acting. I do recommend it, be prepared for boredom and lags but unfortunately you've got to pay attention or else you're bound to miss a clue to the next bend in the plot line.

Had we never seen "The X-Files", we would probably have not doubt that Gillian Anderson in "The Fall" (and also in "Sex Education", for that matter) is a genuine British actress. But besides the acting, it's the character she plays, Detective Superintendent Stella Gibson, that impresses the most. Anderson is totally in character, through every one of the intense 17 episodes, and her interpretation of Stella Gibson is that of a strong and determined woman coping with a all-male environment. A role model, indeed. Despite it first aired a decade ago, "The Fall" is worth watching at any time, if not even repetedly: it's well written, well acted, it has a consistently strong storyline and is void of any cheap tricks. The best series seen since, to name one, "Better Call Saul".

reviews.review_title: Maybe I Should Have Tried Harder
reviews.content: I tried to watch this, got up to episode 4, I believe. I kept hoping it would get better but it didn't.

First off, already wrote my review and at my last sentence the site that has been wiggy totally wigged out and lost it completely! Kinda like The Fall! You invest much time to have it all taken with a bad ending!! Also Gillian Anderson was completely annoying with her over the top monatone voice! It was bad and the ending even worse! Seriously all that time and it looks like Paul is gonna escape, that was when it was getting good but no, we will just have him hang himself. Killer is dead by his own hands, show over! They should give us an alternate ending after all we endured to give us some sort of climax making the loss of our time worth it!

Jamie Dornan is convincingly creepy and sociopathic in this show, and Gillian Anderson puts up a strong performance as well in her attempt to catch the serial killer. The writing is superb and it keeps the audience on the edge of their seats as the show draws to an end.

reviews.review_title: Keep this guy in cuffs and chains! (SPOILER ALERT)
reviews.content: This is a fine piece of filmmaking, almost like an art film. Gillian doesn't seem to have aged much since the X-Files and her performance in this is strong, as are all the others.The 'pace' and story development of this series is slow, noticeably slower than other, similar vehicles, but I liked the pace . . . it added to the vibe and feeling of the film and the way it somehow felt similar to an 'art' film. The story takes place in Belfast which is a treat for me, as an American, as it provides a window into another culture, particularly the police and social and family culture there. The 'accents' are charming (to my ear) and I had no problem understanding what the characters were saying.There was sense of REALISM to this drama that is perhaps *unprecedented* in my 55+ years of watching films. It has almost a documentary feel to it at times. And it is not predictable, like many other similar films are.Perhaps this is the actual case, but I find it difficult to believe how lax the police were in protecting themselves from the main villain of the movie (Paul). For example, when Paul was interviewed in police custody, he was not in any kind of restraints AT ALL and did what I thought *was* an easily predictable outcome → he attacked others -- more than once. Also, he was allowed a certain amount of liberty/freedom that was hard to believe would be permitted in actual life. When Paul is in the hospital, with gunshot wounds, the police are not in the room with him or right outside his door . . . they are off somewhere down the hall. One nurse even ordered the chief detective to leave Paul's room. The police did not monitor what Paul said or did while in custody at the hospital. The nurse (the only one ever seen caring for him, who seemed to be falling in love with him) even slipped him a note! What?! He could easily have killed his nurse or doctor before the police showed up. If this *is* actual practice (in real life), I hope they discard it and treat a guy like this like they did Hannibal in "Silence of the Lambs". They didn't take ANY chances with him . . . Belfast police took all kinds of chances with Paul, even after he severely assaulted two police persons. I found this laxity annoying in an otherwise excellent production. However, the film did educate the viewer as to how otherwise precise, and orderly and meticulous and efficient the Belfast police were/are and this was a pleasure to witness.

The first season is a 9 star - well worth the watch. It starts slow, but pulls you in in with strong character development, fine acting and good direction. The writing and pace of this thriller is extremely well done. However, I found many issues made it difficult to suspend my disbelief in the second season. First off - Gillian Anderson's aloof, whispery persona began to wear out for me. I found myself wanting to tell her to quit being such a drama queen and snap out of it. I didn't find her character as believable. Secondly, the writing seemed to weaken throughout the second half of the second season. The dots weren't connecting as well. Finally, I thought the final 2 episodes seemed, rushed, sloppy and wrought with lazy writing. (Spoiler) How did they get the video of the babysitter though the peephole? It was only an eyepiece being used. Sending an investigator alone into the forest to find the victim is ridiculously unreal. And why un-cuff our suspect (hands behind back) then cuff him again to one hand just to stand in the middle of the street. This made no sense except to set up the murderer at the end. Overall it was an enjoyable romp with a very disappointing finale.

I saw the great ratings but so I watched a couple episodes, it's solid but not great so far anyway. Not sure why people are so taken buy it. I've always found Gillian Anderson very captivating but if she wasn't in it to hold it together it wouldn't be average in my opinion. I'll watch a couple more and change my rating if it does something special

reviews.review_title: The complexity of both lead characters is brilliant!
reviews.content: I wondered whether to start to watch the first series with all the surrounding hype for Jamie Dornan aka Christian. (50 shades) I get fed up of people watching things just because they fancy the main character. You have to admit though Jamie deserved the awards. Here he was playing an ordinary work - play with the kids bored husband in a broken city and then not long after he's probably the sexist onscreen actor in recent times. He's not all about looks this was very good performance.Gillian Anderson also plays her part extremely well. A London police worker who's sent in to Belfast to help solve a case. The case of course escalates and they have a serial killer that nobody can seem to slow down.BBC/Northern Ireland have done greatly well here and so it was no surprise the show won awards.The police seem a bit slow, a bit careless and at times some of the acting lacks a bit of quality and urgency. The inclusion of a 15 year old girl was a little bit desperate and in my view it didn't go well together. All in all though a brilliant overall show.

reviews.review_title: Brilliant series just watched on netflix
reviews.content: This was very well played out and outstanding acting all round dorman who plays Spector is brilliant and Gillian Anderson is great too, only wish there was more like this great psychological thriller

Should have been an 8 part 1 series show, the first season was extremely good. The second just became so implausible it was ridiculous, not even going to bother with the 3rd. Seems they got most of the way through the first season and decided they had a hit and decided to string it out and sting it out and string it out. And I'm an avid English drama and comedy fan from Australia so I do get there shows.
A genious serias, acting, actors etc etc but why so difficult to stop when it is needed??? The third season is a disaster!!! Regretted millions times I started watching it(((((

Absolutely great premise, brilliantly acted by all the cast with the exception of Gillian Anderson. She spends the entire 3 seasons whispering. Maybe she thinks it makes her sound sultry but no investigator would talk without power. Also the interview process is completely ridiculous. They break every rule and as such regardless of the outcome they have blown any chance of a conviction in the real world. And just to add insult to injury when Gillian Anderson goes into the woods.....come on people......She would have had to have a full forensic team and armed police with her. Jamie Dornan was amazing throughout, as were the rest of the cast but in reality the case wouldn't have been handled like this and if Ms Anderson whispered any more I'd lose the will!!!!

reviews.review_title: near death experience messed up the show
reviews.content: I would've rated this show with a 8 or 9 in the first place.The show is all about a serial killer who could be one of us, and the police trying to catch him. Good police work, good psychological work shown here. BUT... the chapters where Spector has a near death experience and talks about it, (or should I say an X-Files type experience) blowed away all the seriousness of the series. What the hell were the producers thinking when introducing this? What is the use of wasting time to show that Spector goes to the light and fights back? Whats the value of it in the story? And in another chapter his nurse questioning him for more than 20 minutes about this as if she was some educated person in the subject? I was at the edge of my seat until these chapters made me loose my respect for the show. First thrilling and captivating, later cheesy and boring. To me, producers did this to fill up space in the plot, because they ran out of ideas and thought this would be an easy way to add up time in the end. I'd rather watch one less chapter than miserably wasting my time looking at how you could destroy a good show. Instead, you could have finished the series one season earlier when Spector was shot (btw he recovers from a major surgery in no time, just like Wolverine could have). He ended up dead and unpunished anyway.Shame on you, this could have been a memorable show. Excellent acting, sloppy way to extend time.

reviews.review_title: actually a good show, with one little problem
reviews.content: I appreciate Gillian Anderson play, she deserve being cast in more relevant shows. In general I also liked the way the script was written. I can ignore the little stupidities inherent to most shows which present facts or behavior that in real life will never ever happen, just for the sake of justifying some outcome or another needed to push the main story in the desired direction. These things have nothing to do with fiction, they are just dumb solutions to push forward when the imagination is lacking. Still I am not really bothered by these, they are much worse and upsetting in other shows.What I cannot enjoy is lingering one subject forever without an end. It feels all their work is focused on one thing: the hope a new season will bring even more income. This just ruins an otherwise very decent show, and it ruins it for good as it becomes more obvious episode after episode.I watched the first season and first episode of the second season realizing that they classically delayed the outcome of the first season into the first episode of the second season at the expense and frustration of all viewers just to make them come back as they did not trust their work enough that viewers will come back without.I watched then few more episodes, then I checked the summaries of episodes in season 3 and as suspected the bad guy is not caught still, probably again in the hope they will get funding and more money with a new season, but that did not happen any more, and my guess is that train is gone. It will never happen.A metaphor for this show would be a sweet nightlong love making night where none of the lovers finish.If you guys think the outcome does not mater and all it matters is the journey, by all means this is a show worth seeing. But you were warned: this journey leads nowhere.

reviews.review_title: Gillian is wonderful, Jamie plays himself
reviews.content: I have seen Gillian Anderson in a lot of stuff and I'm old enough to have watched her grow from a newbie TV fad into a fine actress. She plays this detached icy woman with all stops pulled and makes you still care for her. It's a dicey road at best to make the audience empathize with you and yet feel your aloofness and selfishness mess up other people around you. She is fab. I think Jamie Dornan is good as the sociopathic killer although I've seen him in other roles from his early years on and I can't help but feel he rides the wave as a pretty model boy who depends on his photogenic face and body for most of the time. It's obvious the cameraman was in lust with him in this one. I've never seen so many close ups of sensuous body parts in my life. It's as if the filmmaker wanted us to feel like we were making love to Jamie. I'm personally afraid of handsome people--too handsome that is. I think they are undeveloped, not necessarily their own fault. They've been fondled from birth and told by a million people how wonderful they are even if they just flushed a toilet. They feel and act 'special' but it's that quality that makes them stiff and unreal. This works as a sociopath but not so much in roles calling for human qualities. I think Jamie is most likely just like this character in real life minus (hopefully) the serial killer tendencies. It's his lack of acting ability that makes him so convincing here. He's most of the time on a runway walking in his tight little muscle defining outfits changing a lot and even enthralled in an attic with a mannequin (how Freudian). This part might have been written for him.

This is one of those series that you must take your time to watch & enjoy, if you are not someone that has the patience for the story to unfold bit by bit and then sink in , then it's not for you.
The characters are portrayed beautifully and the each of the actors do complete justice to their roles. The screenplay makes you feel, the whole thing is happening around you.
The 8-year old daughter of the serial killer is the key angle that makes you connect with the serial killer. No suspense about the serial killer, but it's about the plot used to nab the serial killer.
Excellent and very engaging.

The acting, dialogue, action, music, and cinematography, were all good. But I personally had complaints.Season one started very slowly. When it took off, it was good. But after watching all three seasons, there are periods of annoying slowness.It takes entirely too long to capture the serial killer. He was extremely sloppy. In real life, he would have been caught before season one ended. The only reason he wasn't, was because the writers didn't want him to be.The police chief is portrayed as a pathetic douchebag who hires detectives to do a job. Then blocks everything they want to do, for no reason ever explained. It's as if the writers said, "We need more conflict and tension. I know, let's make the police chief inexplicably annoying, whiny and difficult. And if anybody asks what his motivation is, we'll just say, "To add more conflict and tension."There is no reason a violent psychopath would be left alone with a female detective in an interrogation room without constraints or a guard. And there is no reason the same violent psychopath would be left alone in an office with an eldely psychiatrist without constraints or a guard. (Really? Were we supposed to be surprised when the inevitable occurs?)There was a little too much emotional lingering for me. I personally don't care about all the characters' emotional growth and challenges. Normal people can handle things. Everybody isn't an emotionally incapable weenie. Movie and TV show makers constantly feel the need to try to appeal to oversensitive sissies. Leaving people of normal mental health to roll their eyes in aggravation.I personally was impressed with the acting. Especially Jamie Dornan (Fifty Shades of Grey) as Paul Spector the serial killer. He was terrific. And Aisling Franciosi as the babysitter. But all the acting was good. Even the supporting characters.

reviews.review_title: Terrific show ... glad I found it
reviews.content: In some ways, I think we're in a golden age of TV, with movie actors unhappy about limited and stupid roles in film working out their craft in well-written dramas like "The Fall". I just started watching this a few weeks ago, but I'm hooked and I hope there's another season coming. Gillian Anderson is amazing in this. Her accent sounds good, the acting is great and the other major characters are all lending genuine quality. This one goes down in my book along with shows like "Banshee", "the Good Wife", "Suits", "House of Cards", "The Walking Dead" and other quality shows that don't insult the intelligence of the viewers, bringing adult-ish stories to the little screen. The fact that this is set in Belfast helps with the intrigue.I'm Happy I stumbled onto this show.
It could have been good if there wasn't so much unnecessary feminist nonsense. Cast is good, story is okay. A little bit slow. It's a shame all in all.

reviews.review_title: I wish it was better, even just watchable
reviews.content: An Anderson character who's supposed to be checking on local police picks up a random guy off the street and "invites" him to her room in a "posh" hotel. On her first day, and in front of other police officers. That must've cemented her credibility.An Anderson character shouts out to a policeman (by name, no less, on her 2nd day) that there has been another murder. And he jumps up, pick up a fairly thick file from his desk and runs out with her. File of what? How to drive a car?She actually says "Is your car here?". Why? Where else would it be? How does she know he has a car? And if it's a murder there must be other ways of getting there.And a super-careful baddie walks around naked in victim's house. And then another baddie, who's just been caught with illegal guns and ammo, threatens detective with "I know where you live"Poor, "lazy" writing, and acting is not that good either.

This is one of the best programs that I have watched in recent times. Suspenseful and frightening. I really like that it does not rush the story and that we are privy to the killer from the start. Both he and Gillian are amazing. They are the two sides of a single coin. Both cold, calculating methodical and brilliant. It is a dark series so those who might prefer more of the fluff coming out of the US will probably not care for this series. Have just watched episode 3 and am really looking forward to next weeks. I also like that it is set in Ireland and not in North America and lacks the car and gun chases that frequent dramas in North America. The acting is superb.

People are calling this dark, it is, but not for the reason they say. What is this style (I flatter here) of showing part of the action in almost total darkness? You cannot see the actors or what they are doing. Is it supposed to add an air of mystery? Well it does not for me. I like to see what is happening and I find it extremely annoying. This very common in 21st century TV production. The directors should be told in no uncertain terms that it is not clever as they seem to think it is.Otherwise I am enjoying the series thus far. But would a very Senior police woman go around having casual sex with a lower rank officer, she just happens to notice? That does not ring true and I am sure it is a disciplinary offence.

This is the first time that I give a rating here, but the ratings of the other users here must be clarified from my point of view!
This series is wasted time. I've never watched a series of almost two seasons and hoped that something would finally happen. But no, nothing happens! Pure boredom with psychophobic characters. That's why I "gave" the rest of the series and especially the third season to myself.

reviews.review_title: Very interesting, but far too neat and romanticised for its own good
reviews.content: I watched all first season five episodes in a row, so this show certainly did something right. A good cast, an interesting setting and a story that's interesting from the start all help.But - it suffers from being too neat, too trite. The cop vs. the killer, quite a tired concept. And everything is far too neat.This is a person that's killing people. Plain and simple. Be offended. But they go out of their way to make the killer "complicated". There's nothing wrong with that, people are people. People do bad things. Realising they are multi faceted and that there is no "100% evil" person is an interesting concept.But they almost take it too far... just making him considerate, liking children, hating abuse, troubled past, troubled childhood (they mention the troubled childhood a lot, just so you know he has issues). He's very hot. Not saying evil people can't be hot, but it's all meant to make the viewers feel conflicted. To admire him, yet be appalled. Then on the flip side you have the cop... she's complicated too, of course.... she pursues men, that's how 21st century we are here! She wants to lure him in. Because she's that kinda girl. She even painted her nails to get him! "Did she just give her number to a serial killer?" remarks a character, just in case you didn't realise that they're both complicated.... and....What's that....Could she be a clever manipulator too, just like him? Good vs evil... different sides of the same coin?Yes, they were that obvious.Then there's the mirroring, the foreshadowing, the characters talking while they show you the "other side" at the same time.He's there while his children are singing happily, not a care in the world. Do you know who HAS got a care in the world? The woman who was almost murdered. So let's splice these scenes together, because that's clever drama!There's also the secondary characters, who come and go... setup, but not fleshed out. Because they're season two. Everything feels scheduled to within an inch of its life. It's an interesting show, good performances... but it just needs to lighten up. Blur the edges. Not making everything answerable and planned. Then it could move from good to great.

reviews.review_title: The Fall is this show falling from my watching schedule
reviews.content: After all the acclaim for this show I finally started it. I got through 4 episodes but that's all I can do. I don't mind slow, but I would like SOME forward momentum. Gillian Anderson does an ok job with her accent and acting but her character is just not very believable. Why must she look like she's on the cover of Female Empowerment Magazine in every scene? Make her ability and competence known through her actions not her wardrobe. Everyone else aside from the murderer (who is quite boring himself) is forgettable and interchangeable. Overall a drab and sleepy show.

This show deserves more recognition. People are saying season 3 not good enough but in that season, we don't see Paul as a serial killer only but a troubled human being. And the ending with Paul killing himself is a satisfying ending for the show as he doesn't deserve to live after what he did.
One of the best dramas, acting, storylines, twists and turns!!!! Outstanding 😀

This is the best police drama I've seen in years. Acting is terrific, characters are complex, and the deliberate pacing is nerve-wracking. You can't wait to see the next episode but it's worth wait. Gillian Anderson is incredible in portraying a Stella Gibson, a complex character who has her flaws. Jamie Dornan is scary as Paul Spector but Spector fits the latest research on serial sexual predators, able to maintain a "normal" relationship while committing horrendous crimes. It's especially good at covering highly technical subjects (police procedure, mental health, E. R procedures, law) without being pedantic or over expository -- just professionals doing their jobs. The show doesn't always spell out terms e.g., "GCS" which turns out to be Glasgow Coma Scale. Better that way.

This series's drawn all my attentions. Can't stop thinking and longing to watch it until the final episode.
Anyway, I feel like Gillian Anderson is actually making the show so deeply seductive like no one else could do.

reviews.review_title: A fun show, but with it flaws.
reviews.content: "The Fall" follows both Paul Spector and Stella Gibson. Paul is a serial killer. He stalks his victims and then kills them, with the method of chocking them. Gibson is the detective who is put on to this case and has to stop Paul from killing another victim.The directing of the series is decent. It is comparable with the directing of the Belgian TV-show Cordon. The cinematography is very nice at times, but in episode four when Paul is fighting with someone, you can't really see what is going on due to the fast editing and shaky cam, so that was a flaw in the directing. The thing that I liked the most about the series is that they showed everything from two perspectives. Pauls and Stellas. In this way you can see the polices side, and how they try to track down the killer, but you also see the killers side and how he has his own problems. The realism of this series was fun, I love it when there is some good realism in a show.The acting of "The fall" was very well done. Jamie Dorman played Paul. He was the antagonist of the story who had the most screen time too, and I liked that they gave him more screen time than Gillan Anderson. Paul was a intimidating and scary person. Jamie was very convincing as Paul, and I think that he was the best casting choice they made. I loved his Irish accent. Stella Gibson was played by Gillian Anderson. She was very good as the detective. Sometimes she was a bit too cold, but I didn't really mind. Aisling Franciosi was Katie. Katie was the babysitter of Pauls kids. She was good too, so was the whole supporting cast, even the kids.The Story was original and good. You may think: 'Original? Oh heck no, it is just another crime show!' No it isn't. It is a well developed story with, as far as I know no plot holes, nor bad lines. The pilot was very good written and had me hooked for season one. So was the season finale, this episode was scary ans tense full. But the three episodes in between were just OK episodes. They were also a bit lengthy. So I think that they should have made some episodes shorter, so that my attention was kept. The characters were well developed, the only issue that I had with the characters was that they never gave Paul a motive for doing all these things to the women. Maybe in season two? haven't see that yet. They should also have gone in more dept with the characters, so you got to know them better, and maybe cared about them some more. I get that they chose to show more of Pauls side of the story, but I think that they should have showed some more about Gibson, it was the most 'boring' part of the series, but I would have like to see some more about her personally.Overall this was a fun show, but I think that they should shorten in the episodes. I is a dark, but short show, that you can definitely binge watch.

reviews.review_title: Finally Watched It And Was Blown Away By The Fall
reviews.content: I missed The Fall when it was on TV and have finally just finished Season 3z Without doubt one of the darkest, bleakest, violent and disturbing dramas I have ever seen from the BBC. It's a slow burning pot of anger, resentment, rage and passion. The central performances from Gillian Anderson, Jamie Dornan and John Lynch are outstanding. I cannot recall a better serial killer drama from the U.K. in a very long time. If you haven't seen it and want a tough but gripping series then I think you too would be blown away by this.

reviews.review_title: Had potential but lots of bumps
reviews.content: The general plot of the show is interesting and it's mostly well acted. That's about it because it feels artificially extended, meaning it should have been shorter. Lots of scenes really dragged, some unrealistic procedures, and does important things "off screen" which can be jarring.I did like how the show showed the hypocrisy that is placed on women by our culture and as a US citizen, I was shocked because I thought Europeans were more excepting of women's sexuality.Overall the show is okay but feels like it's being stretched longer than what its story can provide. There's loads of glaring procedure issues via policing, and "off screen" plot changes.

Sets and production = horrible
Acting = horrible
What is this trash? Nothing makes sense and the whole thing is completely unrealistic. This plays out like a poor man's 'insert a better crime drama here'. Just avoid.
All the roles seem to be miscast! Especially Gillian Anderson!

I just binged-watched all of season two(at least I think I did). It ended where a lot of you are either upset or confused. However, I liked the ending, leaves it open for season 3 and another shot at this killer. She was very concerned her hard work and risky field trip may have put an end to the beginning of her investigation, it's not over by a long shot. Anderson had on a vest, his risk of a fatal wound would be less likely than Spector's. I didn't know Jamie was from Ireland originally, makes this show all the more interesting and easier to believe.Found "Katy" to be extremely scary. Too many unanswered questions for that to be the end of it all and not a season 3. Very well written and well acted.

I stopped watching it in the middle of S2. I just can't believe that police can be so stupid and unprofessional, even in a movie: Katie lies about her being with Paul. Gibson and other policemen find it weird. What should they do? Secretly follow her to find out why she's lying - and find the killer! Nope, they prefer drawing diagrams and talk about psychological portrait in the office; The car with the killer is approaching the farm house, the killer sees the police and turns around. Nobody saw him, so he was able to escape? Nope, Stella Gibson did see the car! What did she do? Did she send a policeman so that he checks the driver and the car, just in case? Oh no, that would be so wrong in this movie. Our super-agent writes down the plate number and then guesses the right one! So don't say she's an idiot, she's smart!Dumbest movie I've ever seen.

reviews.review_title: On and on and on and on..
reviews.content: I think Gillian Anderson is a brilliant actress, deserving of greatness and under used. It's also very refreshing to see a great American play the part of an English lady with such conviction that you end up doubting her American Heritage. Utterly brilliant.But, and believe me this is a reluctant but, this is a terrible abuse of a story line, it simply goes on and on and on. After getting midway through the second series, I found myself jumping through the episode to see if I were just watching a repeat of a previous episode, then using the marvel of Netflix, checking the series guide only to find that there is a third season after the same bad guy. Holy mackerel, really? Three seasons of the same story? Please don't get me wrong, I love drawn out thrillers, I even watch the walking dead (an example of 'milking the cash cow' on steroids!) but this makes war and peace seem like a Sunday afternoon supplement. A story needs a basis, twd uses survival and human behavior to extrapolate the seasons. This just skirts the conclusion, places caveats where they're not needed and frankly draws out the plot to a state of total repetitive boredom.I dislike intently the comments about never getting that 90 minutes of your life back, but this is almost days! It's tough to be critical of the star; Gillian Anderson because she is brilliant throughout but with wooden planks around you, even the best actors can only appear as statues in a gallery. Yes, I think the so called supporting actors are dreadful, and yes I compared them to wooden planks.Had this have been three stories across three seasons I would have been glued, but one central story, with little by way of sub plots or stories, it was an "on and on and on" for me.I gave 5 points because Gillian Anderson is great, convincing and in my opinion one of the best actresses alive. Also, she plays an English lady better than most English ladies do, coupled with the fact that it's about time it was the other way, I'm tired of English actors playing major roles as Americans and I was born in England! I also believe it's a great story, it's just too much of the one story in three seasons for me.Last words:I'd recommend you watch it, then see if you feel it could have been condensed into one season without losing anything.
In the name of thriller this series doesn't justifies.This series is a shame to the genre, waste of time.Season 3 was so so pathetic that i just fast forwarded to end.

Season one was brilliant. They should have just ended the Spector storyline there tbh. 3 seasons of the same storyline was way too much! There were quite a few parts where I was getting frustrated as they didn't add anything to the story or any effect to the drama. This was right until the last moment! For example we see Gibson back at home in London and she just enters the house, picks up her letters, pours herself some wine and then opens the letter and puts it back down on the table. This whole scene takes 5-7 minutes of our time, and certainly does not add anything to the story let alone to the end of the show! They would have been better of at least changing the "baddie " in each season for example letting Katie continue to carry out Sector's work in his honour or something like that. Anything just to change the dynamic in season 2 and 3.Also there were parts that just didn't make sense. For example after Spector beats the cr** out of Gibson and another detective, he still is allowed to hang out back in the facility, and not confined to his room.Really can't justify spending all those hours watching it. If you have not started watching it yet, don't bother.

Gillian Anderson was totally miscast! Her fake British accent is absurd and sounds stupid! She also dresses and acts like a woman of the street!
👎👎👎👎👎

This has the baseline of an interesting series. Throughout the series, there are long drawn out parts that are boring. There are SO many instances of stupid acts or stupid things the characters say it diminishes the intrigue.Some of the supporting acting is good. Most of the primary acting is ok. But when the actors whisper ALL their lines, ALL the time = BORING. Not good for effect.Would not recommend this movie.

In reality this show would have been a solid 8, but the ending to me was very stretched out. It could have easily been summed up into less episodes. Anyway this show is very good and very unpredictable. You never know whats gonna happen next. Definitely worth a watch!

reviews.review_title: Way too slow, it'd been a good movie.
reviews.content: It's an interesting story, couple of twists, not all stories closed well and extremely predictable.

To be fair i only watched the first two episodes. could not watch any more of it. it was simply very boring! the story is good so far but nothing great or special. what really drives me away is the very dry approach to deliver whats happening. very dry and well... very boring in a way. its kept very realistic. for some people this might work and it could be an 8. but if you are like me you expect something else... something less... dry... i don't know how to explain. just try it for one episode. if you are bored as i was, leave it.

They really drag this story out. No mystery whatsoever since you know who the killer is after the first 5 minutes. There do seem to be a lot of people who like this so don't let me discourage you but for me there was nothing thrilling about this thriller.

reviews.review_title: A well made show on how police should not work
reviews.content: The show is well produced. The first season in particular is captivating, decent acting, especially from Gillian Anderson, good atmosphere, a bit like Luther. The problem however is the plot. The police has all the information they need on the suspect and they just let him be free for no discernible reason. It gets frustrating really quickly to ne watching long pointless conversations between secondary characters when they could just arrest the guy and end it. I didn't finish second season, it was getting too boring.
What Should I say? It picks up slowly like a wine and then grips you completely. 👍👍

reviews.review_title: Season 3 is unfortunately a lost cause
reviews.content: Season 1 is very good with an interesting storyline and good acting. Season 2 is also quite good. However, Season 3 is pretty irritating. At some points, it seems like someone was forced to write something for 50 minutes. So they just wrote anything. Not sure why they made this!

I would have given this a much higher score if it wasn't for the final series.The cat and mouse of the first 2 series was great. Thoroughly enjoyed it.
The final series was garbage. Trying to be far too clever but was just turgid and boring.Some of it became farcical in the way they let Spector back to the institution to roam freely. He's a suspected mass murderer!!!Shame the final series ruined the first 2

I could not stand this show. I've watched some creepy, disturbing serial killer shows in the past, but this was too uncomfortable even for me. It started out promising, but soon lost momentum. I tried to watch it three times and I hated more each time. Terrible plot, terrible characters. The only bright spots were Gillian Anderson and Archie Punjabi (the latter later left the show) because they are two wonderful actresses, but this was not one of their better projects.

Very detailed and agree with the vast majority who say this is well written, scripted etc, I'm always suspicious of people who give 2/10 and describe watching 3 seasons, what clown watches 3 seasons of a show rhat they find so disagreeable, it doesn't make sense

reviews.review_title: Great show with glaring plot holes
reviews.content: This is a well written and addictively good thriller- but the mistakes are driving me a bit nuts. Why didn't they look for Rose in the house she was being held sooner? Cops said they'd check it at least a day or two before they did. Why on earth was Paul allowed to the wooded area where they found Rose at all? And if he had to go to direct them why was he handcuffed to a man so much smaller than him? If Paul hadn't been shot he surely might have overcome Tom. Why wasn't Paul guarded while in the hospital? Why on earth is Rose's hospital bed so close to his? Why didn't Stella chase Paul's car when it pulled onto the site they were searching, cut the lights and backed up? This show is amazing but these silly plot holes are distracting.

reviews.review_title: Well acted but some unrealistic scenarios
reviews.content: Excellent acting from all the cast, Gillian Anderson in particular.The flaws was the unrealistic slant on security throughout. I can't believe a violent serial killer would have been given the unfettered freedom to move about that Spector was given after capture and particularly after attacking police officers whilst in custody and then following that to be left alone with a vulnerable hospital psychiatrist. The hospital for the criminally insane had less security than a high school and I doubt violent disturbed killers would be given access to glasses and mirrors in their rooms. Anderson looked remarkedly undamaged after having been punched savagely in the face three times and kicked in the body several times.
