A beating like that would have laid Mike Tyson up for several days.Still worth the watch, though the final two episodes with their many conversations of measured dialogue became a bit too slow apart from the violent scenes .

I was very intrigued by the first season.This TV production serious and it shows in the output: Here you get quality acting, a plot that is believable, characters that for the most part act and behave convincingly according to real live situation.Even if the storyline from time to time is a bit slow paced it does not matter because you want to know more about these characters and what will happen next.Season 2 has started out a bit slow and steering around nothing, but I am sure the writers have something interesting for us later on, otherwise I need to reduce my score.

I am an avid thriller watcher. This is absolutely one of the best shows I have ever seen. The acting is spot on. Watching the story play out absolutely keeps you on your toes. This is a "true" thriller. It is a story that shows us it can happen and it is a story that shows us it has happened. Not exactly, but there are people all over the world with the same ominous thoughts and intentions. We all like to think we are safe in our little bubbles. We like to think we know the people we surround ourselves with so we don't pay attention to the little things that we do and see everyday that can end up catastrophically changing the course of our lives. The entire cast is fierce. It seems as if every part was made for that particular actor. It was filmed so well. The the two main characters, in my opinion, perfect casting! I had only seen Gillian Anderson on the X-Files and I wasn't aware that she actually is British, so I was blown away on her transformation into a British Detective S.I. She is brilliant and beautiful. Jamie Dornan is absolutely amazing and I have to add..... extremely easy on the eyes. He plays his part so perfectly from beginning to end. NO ONE else could have done this part. It was made for him. This is truly the best Thriller on Netflix so far.

What promise comes from the first season is quickly extinguished by many implausible actions by all involved. This three series wonder has more padding than Joanne Collins shoulder pads. By the end I was willing it to finish so that I could move onto better things. A bang average series though Anderson is reliably good throughout.

I have been shouting at the TV for ages watching The Fall which is a mildly entertaining Crime drama. Unfortunately I could only concentrate on one thing which is Gillian Anderson and her whispering dialogue. What in gods name is going on? Why on earth can't she talk properly instead of insisting on whispering in nearly every episode. My wife enjoyed the series 1 & 2 to date and agreed the whisperererering was a bit annoying.
Nearly annoying dare I say as the TV people (Actors, footballers, pundits, politicians etc) who constantly tell me to 'listen' or 'look' Before every utterance. By default I listen and look whether it is TV or radio, it's a bit condescending to tell me to do it as well. Off topic I know but just as annoying as The Whispererer.

Someone said "why couldn't they find a British actress?"
The geographical birthplace of the actor makes no difference, especially in this instance...
Gillian Anderson grew up in the uk, then moved to the states, then back to the uk for almost 20 years, I'm pretty sure she can pull of an English accent..
I didn't bother with the rest of that review, it was clearly pants and had I believed that user, I'd have missed a great show.
Been looking for a decent crime for ages, this fills the void perfectly.
Both leads are fabulous, Jamie's bum is epic, acting is on point, Gillian has just the right amount of cold and control..the way she seems to compartmentalise human emotion is so telling without speaking, . I need some of that lol
Writing is class and it's a shame there's only 3 seasons, I think this could be up there with the Prime Suspects or Cracker...
fingers crossed for a return

reviews.review_title: Goes a bit into the weeds ...
reviews.content: I found the series pretty well engrossing but, in the third season it seemed to become just a little, well, way too much, face time for Gillian.

I watched this because Colin Morgan was in it (turned out only a minor character). This is really Gillian Anderson's show. I have some misgivings about her portrayal of her character but she did a decent job. I just feel they could've told the story in one season of 10 episodes. The show has too much dialogue and in the end has a lot of unanswered questions.

I binge watched the two series with mild amusement. I found Stella Gibson rather fascinating. She was neither threatening or deep. Rather, she was more like a detective barbie brandishing her clout and credence with her status, credentials and florid sexuality. Stella is often dressed in pencil skirts, stilettos, sheer blouses, and topped with peroxide blonde hair. This makes her look less plausible, less authentic. I guess it must be fun to be able to play an older actress who can keep up with people half her age, and this is a strong focus of the story-line. Whist Stella has some gravitas, some kind of Luke- warm intrigue, I found Jamie Dornan to be a complete drip. He has no personality, no charisma, no nothing. His character in this series is not dissimilar to any other role he has played including 50 shades of gray. His expression remains the same throughout the series. He attempts to be this brooding, threatening character, yet he never quite pulls this off, he just appears as he is, a former Calvin Klein model turned generic heart throb actor.

reviews.review_title: Should of been a case for Mulder and Scully
reviews.content: It's Gillian Anderson that makes this show more unbelievable than it already was with her ridiculous voice that sounds like she should be on late night radio! Not sure how the show has such high ratings, because the further the show delves into the minds of all these "complex" characters the more stupid and far fetched it gets.

reviews.review_title: A promising start, after that - disappointment
reviews.content: When you look at the synopsis for this show, you will automatically be drawn to it (if you're in to this kind of TV shows).Just after watching two more episodes, I realised that this series is utterly shallow. Story is everything but different, and the main actor is just not good enough, lacking character and charisma both. When you even think about comparing him with Dexter... The end is completely unsatisfying, and the way our serial killer/family man makes mistakes during his actions, make you wonder how he was not caught earlier.The only good thing about this TV show are Gillian Anderson and few other actors. Locations are solid.I had excepted so much more (mistake!), but a switch to "Top of the Lake" did the trick for me.5/10

This is a fairly good show. I found it on netflix and was like what the hell, I love Belfast and Gillian Anderson is hot so I'll check it out. Definitely worth it. It is a very well written show with very good production value. The acting is very good, although at times Gillian's character seems over the top and she ain't got much of an Irish accent. Having been there I can tell. They don't really say where she is from though. But a lot of other characters nail it, which really helps it stand out. The only thing about this show I didn't like is there are no twists and turns and most of the actors seem uppity. Belfast isn't really an uppity town. Even when I visited the churches there the ushers were telling me dirty jokes. That part seems missing, and almost foreign in the show. The story lays itself straight out there. WYSIWYG story telling. For that reason I give it a 7/10. It really needs more mystery. Love the scenes of Belfast though. I wish they invoked more of the history of the city. Would have been nice to have seen the peace walls and how they have an effect on the city. The bad guy is very well acted. He plays the dynamic of being normal and bad to a T. Overall it's not Game of thrones good, but it is definitely worth the watch.

reviews.review_title: Feels like waste of time after a while
reviews.content: All these episodes and seasons could have been concluded in a 6 episode mini series, and it could have been better.Especially starting from the 2nd season I started to get confused: Why dont they arrest him??? Nothing becomes logical afterwards.All the characters seem to lose their logic and iq after a while.You can turn it on while you cooking, ironing, eating or doing something else. If you do not do anything else while you're watching, I'll bet you will FALL asleep. That's the reason the series is called FALL.

reviews.review_title: Great start, went on too long
reviews.content: First two seasons were great, well done, suspenseful, and gripping entertainment. But it would have been far more effective if they'd just wrapped it up there. After that, just feels like they were trying to squeeze as much as they could out of a solid concept.

Great acting. Great story. Very well done overall. An engrossing series. But if you don't care for dark themes, don't watch. No spoilers BUT for those who don't like any sort of insights beyond what I stated above, stop reading. I didn't care for the ending. I wasn't disappointed. But nor was I satisfied. With such a story, however, not sure what a better fitting ending would've been.

reviews.review_title: Season 1 amazing, 2 pretty good, 3 is a snooze fest
reviews.content: The first season was so good, like the beat show I've seen in a long time. 2 was good, a good and natural progression from season 1. 3 is just awful, I can't even finish it. They should have quit while they were ahead.

reviews.review_title: Season 1 was very good, Season 2 falls of badly
reviews.content: Season 1 had an interesting story and a strong cast. Jamie Dornan does a good job of being creepy in a very unsettling way and the rest of the cast is solid. The only annoyance is Gillian Anderson seemingly whispering all the time. It's not how she speaks at all. Why in the show?Season 2 though, what a disappointment. In between the 'how can he/she/they be so stupid' and the 'coincidences do happen but that's absurd' moments I pretty much lost faith in the series. In one episode I said 'That's not Rose it will be a suicide by hanging' and later 'Watch, he's going to fall through the ceiling' and not 3 minutes later, I was proven right. Now I just want to see get arrested or, preferably, rubbed out.They should have gone the Broadchurch route and had a different story line in Season 2 with the Season 1 story percolating in the background.

reviews.review_title: Very poor on multiple levels - too many to capture in a one liner
reviews.content: I watched part of it due to the ratings and reviews. This was a huge mistake. Incompetence demonstrated by the investigating characters is staggering. Leading the pack was Stella of course. Who else would hide in stairwell with phone in ringing mode and not even reacting to silent it swiftly while it rings? I can finally relate to why the assistance chief constable is shown as a dud - lest he steals Stella's thunder. There are way too many holes, almost many in pretty much every episode. The slow pace of the series is not a negative thing in itself - it's the lack of any real story. Let's be honest - this is not some deeply meaningful dissection of the real human character, just very mediocre TV.

reviews.review_title: Well thought out Police Crime Thriller.
reviews.content: It a much longer series that I had expected, but it is well filmed and multifaceted showing a concerted Crime Squad and the interplay of the members evolved. In every part of the series your not sure what to expected. The only con I have is that some points it tends to drag a bit. The last part shouldn't have been necessary. If proper Police procedures had been followed this great big anti-climax would have never happened. It kinda made the who Police Squad, etc. kinda look like rookies.

Just finished this series, as it came on Netflix. Thoroughly enjoyed all 3 series equally. I really liked Gillian Anderson's character Stella. A strong female lead without having to be the cold and masculine type female cliche. The show kept me gripped and desperate to watch the next episode. Good solid casting and acting. Can only assume negative reviews are people who enjoy 'wham-bam done in an hour' drivvle like the CSI series. This was a good solid British police psychological thriller. I wouldn't even say it was a slow burner. It delivered episode after episode. Read one review saying season 3 was pointless. Really???? I completely disgaree. It added to the overall story immensely. Well worth a watch. I haven't enjoyed anything as much as this in ages.

reviews.review_title: As good as the genre gets
reviews.content: Simply brilliant, this is one of the best written police procedurals that has appeared in some time. Maybe nothing like it since Prime Suspect. Carefully plotted and filmed, it takes the familiar---serial killer obsessed with sex--and makes it special. It has some nods to, say, Criminal Minds, but it has the time to be far more elegantly and intricately plotted. Beautifully acted, it is also a revelation for Gillian Anderson's performance. If all you know is the X-Files, you know how wasted she was in that stilted role that required very little range. She is so much better here and so much more interesting. I was, by the way, wondering about the accent enough to look it up--to my surprise, she spent a lot of time in the UK growing up and comes by a UK accent naturally. Anyway....All in all, if you like the genre, you shouldn't miss this. It's unforgettable.

Really disappointing example of producers killing a drama by dragging it out for far too long. First series great, second series okay. Third series? Virtually all padding, no momentum, little happens that is central to the plot. It attempts to be psychologically compelling but by this time you know who the killer is, so all tension & momentum has gone. Do yourself a favour - watch series 1 & 2, then just look online to see what happens in series 3. No series 4, thankfully.

Loved the fIrst seasons, binged in a week. However the third season has several new plot points that are simply unrealistic compared to the first two seasons. I mean, im all for well-applied suspension of disbelief, but come on.

reviews.review_title: Not as good as the reviews make out
reviews.content: I have given this a 6 as an average over the three seasons. In reality seasons 1 and 2 are worthy of an 8 but oh dear the final season was so bad. Nearly gave up on it because it was so boring and as for the end oh dear!!
Too slow. As my review was too short, may reiterate "Too slow."

reviews.review_title: dexter without the character of dexter
reviews.content: Its a dexter show setup in Ireland, where the guy has no previous knowledge of crime scenes. He is setting himself up for having a s@x with minor.Because there is not much story, so to stretch it, it has been made so slow.Also, in dexter you loved the main character. In this show there is no affection for main character. He can be any killer, no one cares.Lady cop character is setup good and that is what is moving the story, rest other cops have been set at intelligence level of 2 out of 10.

Great acting, particularly by Gillian Anderson, has carried this series despite some fumbling writing at times. After watching the first two episodes of season three I'm thinking that I might give the remainder of this season a miss as the storyline is starting to get increduluous.

A beautiful icy senior detective, Gillian Anderson has to find a very truck serial murderer. An extremely fit, focused and determined and oh so very clever killer.Series production is high quality with adequate costume and set design.The hook of this show is the story. Plot twists are bountiful and will keep you on the edge of your seat!

reviews.review_title: I kept waiting for something clever to happen
reviews.content: But it just ... didn't.I don't know how else to describe this series really. I kept thinking, oh there's got to be more, someone's got to have an ace up their sleeve. But they don't. It's all very straightforward. It just feels like we're being taken through an investigation checklist rather than a story.

The series starts out strong but quickly loses its steam towards the end of the first season. Season 2 is pretty decent sans some poorly scripted character development. Season 3 is an absolute bore to watch. Incredibly slow, meandering and frustrating on the senses, I personally wished i hadn't invested time into anything past the first episode of the season. I do not recommend it even though I gave it 5.
Ridiculously unrealistic story in which the actions of all protagonists are defined by smashing incompetence, in Anderson's case combined with constant whispering. Pretentious bs.

Absolutely a great thriller. Dark and slow in the first season. But as the second season begins you are thrown into a fast paced drama, which is follwed by a mind twisting season three. Wish they took it farther, but loved the series

What really ground my gears was the lack of resolution by the end of the series. The killer was not caught. There was no closure. Each season should have closure. We got none. So I really disliked this. I feel cheated out of my time. I could have watched something else with a beginning, middle and an actual end, which is kind of important. It is excellent in its foley sound, the cinematography, acting, lighting, directing, I mean an A class type of show. But the storytelling is just way too slow. If you like resolutions in the stories you read or shows you watch, wait until the next series is released, in which I can only hope they will catch the killer. By the time the new series comes along, I will have forgotten what happened in the first one.

reviews.review_title: Uni-dimensional, a pseudo psychological thriller that's just meh...!
reviews.content:
Got taken in by the superlative reviews here in IMDB and kept waiting for the series to live up to the fulsome praise some viewers have showered on it.
Found Gillian Anderson uni-dimensional, monochromatic and so infuriatingly irritating with her supposedly ice lady expressions. She had zero inner life, had no character arc whatsoever and if being a feminist means randomly picking up handsome men who are your subordinates and sleeping with them and then not giving a damn when one of them is shot dead and the other grievously injured, then it is the most antiquated interpretation of feminism that I've ever come across.
Her carefully blow dried curls which are never out if place and those killer heels makes one wonder when she gets the time to dress up so impeccably with a serial killer in the loose. And as some other reviews have mentioned, her whispering tone, was so grating, I felt like shaking her up. 
The serial killer too is flat, boring, which is surprising, considering his brutality and his myriad festishes. Not once does one feel a morbid fascination towards him. Though in the end the writer does dwell into his traumatic past, I still felt unaffected.
The repeated incompetence of the police and then the shocking carlessness of the criminal psychiatric hospital which allowed a dangerous psychopath to move around inside freely, is beyond comprehension.

The Fall is not like any other television series I've ever seen, its more like one continuous movie. Each episode melds into the next, all the same characters in season one and two in seemingly every episode, rather than the more typical American format of different guest stars in each episode.
Gillian Anderson is superb as the lead investigator. Her English accent threw me at first, I know she's American but she puts on a very good impression as a Brit. She's the only American in the choice cast.
One scene in the second season knocked me out of my chair. Gillian Anderson's character went to the powder room leaving her female East Indian forensics partner alone in a booth at a bar. When she returned a handsome straight guy was making his moves on her partner, Anderson swooped in and tongue kissed her partner like Lesbian lovers! The guy was holding two margaritas, one for her partner and one for him. Anderson smoothly snatched the drinks from his hands, and thanked him "keep them coming." The stunned Lothario responded "but I'm not the waiter!" To which Anderson cooly responded, "then why are you standing there?"
Was it just a clever move to deflate the unwelcome advance, or are they really a Lesbian couple? There is a strong bond between the two women, how strong and deep has yet to be revealed. Absolutely delicious.
Stunning Ulster native Jamie Dornan is wonderful as the glamorous, and sexy serial killer. There's plenty of scenes of him almost completely nude.
Jamie Dornan and Gillian Anderson share the DVD cover.
The editing is totally different than any American program I've ever seen. The series is set in Belfast, Northern Ireland in the United Kingdom, and explores some very dark sexual themes that might unsettle some people.
The series is exquisitely filmed with many gorgeous scenes of Ireland as a backdrop. It is shot on location, but I would not have recognized Northern Ireland if I wasn't told that was what I was looking at.
The program has nothing to do with the sectarian conflicts we associate with the region.
I am tempted to compare The Fall to Law and Order: Special Victims Unit, another program about sex crimes featuring a powerful female lead, but The Fall is so much more sophisticated, and complex that the older series pales in comparison.
The Fall delves much more deeply into the criminal psyche, and into the lives of all the players, including the police.

An intriguing story, well told, but at times it gets a little slow. The pacing could have been tightened up a bit (pointless scenes of Stella swimming, for example). Having said that, the characters and events are very believable. Some things are implied but not explained. For example, we are led to believe that Jim Burns is a survivor of the same boys' institute where Paul was abused as a young teen. If this series had been done in the US, Paul would have escaped the hospital and died in a fiery crash or a hail of bullets after a lengthy and pointless car chase. His death in the actual series was believable. Other than the pacing, my only criticism is that Gillian Anderson wore only one expression on her face for all three seasons.

The Fall first series is excellent and I would say the ending is pretty good, but everything in between is just dire. I watched the show on Netflix so had the whole 4 series available. By the second episode of series two to basically the last episode of Series four I was just watching it with a view to getting it over and done with. I understand that it is important to build up characters and plots slowly and I am happy when this happens but in The Fall its like they have to much film time and too little plot. Additional themes are added that make no sense and then disappear. By series 4, I was basically on my phone or computer with the tv in the background.
Could have been better if Gillian Anderson wasn't in it keep walking around in silk clothes over acting Everyone else was brilliant
Excellent actors, well written and keeps you wanting more!
Yes thoroughly enjoyed , great acting , very good story top notch physcolical thriller

I'm giving it a 4/10 only for the great acting and cinematography. Beyond that I found the series highly misogynistic. All the victims being women murdered by a sick man seem to be normalising sick sexual murders. It is as if they thought 'what's the sickest most disturbing thing we can think up?' And then made a series about it. I wouldn't bother watching if you are aware and care about your mental health. It's disturbing and dark. I only watched it for Gillian Anderson who played her character perfectly as always.

I sure wish I could have skipped season 3. So was doing great till then. Keep wishing it to be over. Let t it end let it end. Can somebody explain why this violent murdering rapist gets to walk around in custody without handcuffs constantly. Yes lunacy. I don't know how people put up with this crap.

Drags on for a season too long.......all 3 seasons are around pursuing one serial killer, would have been more enjoyable compacted into two seasons. I ended up FF through a lot of season 3 to see the outcome quicker.

reviews.review_title: This whole show can be done in 1 episode!
reviews.content:
The show is moving too slow. They're showing us many irrelevant things. The story is interesting but they are just spending a lot more time to move it forward. The acting is so calm, they speak in a way that is soo calm like they don't really feel the show.
When they had a suspect, they kept watching his house in 3 different episodes, while they could just arrest him and just interrogate him. As he apparently love his family and specially his kids, they could threaten him that they will be lost as their mother is also arrested. Instead, they kept wasting 3 episodes of following and watching him; and every time they lose him they make it like a big seen!!! Come on what's is about if you are all aware he is coming back home like every time he does?
It's like they trying to show some thrill that doesn't even exist.
Also; the entire show is about the detective Gibson (Gillian Anderson) , every arrest, every conversation, she has to be the one who's doing it and has to be the one to be correct and find the answers. All men in the show are falling for her, and she picks any one she wants to have.!Boring show, although it has interesting story.

reviews.review_title: They should have ended it after season 2
reviews.content:
The first two seasons are great. They should have give season two a proper end and that's it.
In season 3 the quality unfortunately drops significantly.
Also the whole part of Katie is just unnecessary and not important at all for the story.

reviews.review_title: Men who hate men directed this absurd series!
reviews.content: Apart from blatant misandry, this production has so many holes, idiocy and silliness that elaborating here on them would be further waste of time which I suffered by watching this! Yet the most annoying and irritating thing about it is the way it tries hard to be regarded as a deep, complex, philosophical show whilst it is maybe the one of the most shallow TV shows I've ever watched! Constant contempt and defamation of men, moving in slow motion, constant whispering and a "half-baked philosophy" does not make a great series! As is the case with most BBC shows, including Sherlock, it is extremely pretentious! Instead of pretending to be something you are not, watch Swedish-Danish crime shows carefully so maybe you can learn one thing or two!

reviews.review_title: Can't understand the hate for this
reviews.content:
I simply can't understand the poor reviews for this series. Someone else here has suggested it's American viewers that are downvoting which is a possibility.
This series is instense and gripping. The characters are carefully constructed and each episode is laid out brilliantly so that things unfold at just the right pace. If you are after an intense, dark, well paced, realistic, sometimes shocking series, this ticks all the boxes.
I would say being picky the only thing that is a bit tedious is the 'frown' Dornan keeps using. Looks very un natural and doesn't really suit the character.

reviews.review_title: Good but should have ended in the second season
reviews.content: I give it an 8 based on the quality of acting for all 3 seasons, good writing for two season, and a pretty good storyline. They did show far more "gore" than necessary. Literally, guts. You see them operating on a person with a view looking right into the stomach.Gillian Anderson and Jamie Dornam are excellent in their roles. They both make the characters come alive. Gillian plays a detective who, hit on by her male colleagues throughout her career, has to fight against the double standard for women. Jaime plays a normal guy with a wife and kids who is a serial killer. That is a stretch to believe. They hit all of the politically correct cliches: no father, abused in an orphanage, mother kills herself. Mommy and Daddy issues. But in seasons 1 and 2 Jamie pulls it off.In season three there is a big drop-off in writing (Gillian and Jaime are still doing a great job in their roles). Some of the story line is silly. Aisling Bea plays a nurse who apparently is not deterred in finding a serial killer sympathetic. Arresting and the questioning a suspected serial killer without putting the killer in handcuffs, really? Teenage girl longing to be with a serial killer even after he tells her how he sees the world, really?Gillian is supposed to play a women in a man's world, a detective. Who has slept with a man who is now her boss. The boss never got over her and tells her years later he would give up everything to be with her, really?The ending is awful. Jamie hangs himself in a psych ward. Totally contrary to the character development the writers spent building in seasons 1 and 2.

reviews.review_title: Brilliant first season...but fizzles out from there
reviews.content: First season is amazing. It's dark, it's scary, gripping - edge of your seat television. Well acted, well cast and a great story line.I got the impression that halfway through season 2 there was a change in course. I don't know if there where changes behind the scenes, they suddenly got approval for a third season or just how it was edited. But this show that has so effectively built story lines methodically....perfecting the art of suspense....spends 3 episodes of the police identifying Spector, tracking him down, building towards capturing him, slowly, slowly, build, build - and then all of a sudden he's in custody in the most anti-climatic chase scene ever.And then halfway through the second season these really apparent plot issues start appearing. The whole facade around hinting to the press that the Jane Doe suicide victim they'd found was Rose Stag in order to 'draw the killer out' but then never even showing the viewer Spector hearing that information, let alone doing anything with that - the pointless lesbian kiss that felt like it was just put in there for the magazine pictures - and the just every aspect of the final episode, where in my opinion the show just got so unbelievably unrealistic and far-fetched it starts to affect your enjoyment. We all know that how it plays out on TV isn't the same as real life - but you can take the fantasy too far - and things like the police helicopter picking up on the photographer in the woods - but doesn't detect the car he got out of, or the man who was driving said car then get out and walk towards the scene, gun in hand....it's too much (and that's before we move on to Stella Gibson's miraculous healing powers reducing the effects of an assault where she suffered facial fractures to just a scratch in 48 hours).The third season was then too slow - you lose interest. There's not a mystery to solve or a killer to catch anymore and I don't think they did a good enough job of replacing that. Saying that the final episode, whilst equally gripping, was very exciting and entertaining and whilst it wasn't an ending I wanted, it did at least give the storyline closure.I also found something about Gillian Anderson's character a bit cold and difficult to warm too. Jamie Doran on the other hand is a fine actor.There are murmurs of it being brought back with a different story line and I'd be hugely interested in watching that and seeing how they would take the show forward on a different case.First season is a cracking watch - later episodes aren't bad....just doesn't live up to cracking expectations we had.

There were dozen moments where the detectives could solve the puzzle with logical understanding e.g. They could ask the living victim from season 1 or the little girl in season 2 episode 2 if the suspect was one of the visitors of this garden.But nooooooo.... They must build up 3 seasons for this story.

It could be much better show if they had only built one season. Season one is good, second season is mediocre, and season three is just a disaster. They totally ruined the image of show by the last season.

reviews.review_title: A slow burn serial that will get under your skin.
reviews.content: "The Fall" is superb police procedural/serial killer thriller built around two fantastic central performances; Gillian Anderson as "Detective Superintendent Stella Gibson," and Jamie Dornan as serial killer "Paul Spector."For a large part of the audience Anderson will forever and always be known as the X-Files' "Dana Scully," but she's a critically acclaimed actor of both stage and screen and it shows in her portrayal of Gibson; driven, deeply introspective, controlling and obsessive with her own demons, a fierce intelligence, and an equally fierce determination to see justice done.Jamie Dornan is probably best known these days to a large part of the audience for the "Fifty Shades..." trilogy, but hey, don't hold that against him! The role of "Paul Spector" was his break-out performance, and is an astonishing tour-de-force. Spector (in one scene he pronounces it 'Spec-tor' as if he's sick and tired of listening to people mispronounce it as 'Specter') is a Jekyll and Hyde character; a patient and empathetic bereavement counsellor, a loving husband and father who dotes on his children... a cruel, sadistic sexual deviant, serial killer, and homicidal maniac.Anderson and Dornan are surrounded by an extensive supporting cast who all give committed performances in service of the story, which plays out over 3 series for a total of 17 episodes; the series is made to binge watch as seasons 1, and especially season 2, both end on huge cliff hangers.Set in the Belfast of 2012 in the aftermath of "The Troubles," there's a constant background threat of violence against the police, so, uniquely for the UK, individual patrol officers on the street are armed.But this isn't an "action" show by any means, as I said above, this is a slow-burn of a series, with long, slow takes building tension and focusing on individual characters, taking the time to get to know Gibson, Spector, and the main supporting characters, both their interpersonal relationships and their inner lives. These scenes are punctuated by bursts of brutal and sometimes savage, especially for its time, violence, some of which is genuinely shocking, particularly during the final episode.This is one of the best "limited series" I've seen in years, it takes its time building the characters and the World they exist in, even the secondary characters, so they feel just as real as the environment they inhabit, and I'm sorry it took so long for me to catch up with it.Allan Cubitt, the creator and writer of the show, did say he'd like to write another story to explore DS Gibson's life and career in the aftermath of the Spector case, but said it "isn't going to be straight away." Gillian Anderson said she'd be "excited... to see what transpires in Stella's life afterwards," but 6yrs on from the final season I guess that hasn't worked out.

Somehow, I missed The Fall on its original airing, so have come across it with its recent addition to Netflix.Season 1 started out very well and it was easy to see what all the hype was about, and Gillian Anderson knocks it out of the park.Season 2 was weaker but still able to hold my attention, though it waivered here and there with one too many dragged out scenes, side stories or pregnant pauses during dialogue.Then came season 3 and it fell off a cliff. Absolutely boring, with hardly anything new added to the mix until a few snippets in the 5th episode, and then a fizzle rather than a bang for episode 6.Such a shame, as S1 was probably a 9/10, S1 & S2 taken as a whole would probably have merited an 8/10, but taking the whole three seasons in their entirety is barely scrapes a 6/10.It's also worth adding that although, as mentioned, Anderson is amazing, some of the other cast (the daughter in particular) are wooden in the extreme. As for Dornon, I've no idea what the fascination was with him, and I'm not surprised his career has hardly been stellar beyond the tacky Fifty Shades franchise.

reviews.review_title: Waste of time unless you really want to see a monster in intimate settings
reviews.content: Totally overrated. The story line is the Gillian Anderson character is "cold and steely", Wooden and mannequin like is more appropriate. I am a fan of Anderson and really like her but she was terrible in this show. The only reasons to watch in my opinion are for the outstanding performances of Jamie Dornan as the killer and Aisling Franciosi as an obsessed teenager who desires to enter into the dark world of the Dornan character. In addition to Anderson's terrible performance and the slow and boring periods throughout this one season too long show, were back stories that were a waste of time, such as an abused wife and her punk bully husband. Another boring subplot has Anderson meeting a fellow Police Officer at a crime scene and after 5 minutes asks him would he like to have sex. I guess this was to show (as she later preaches to someone) how women can be just as horny as men. Dumb scene. Just filler as was another unnecessary character a police official named Jim Burns played terribly by John Lynch. Burns is a weak man, and a pencil pushing wimp who is madly in love with Stella, Anderson's character. Without Dornan and Franciosi's terrific performances, I'd give this dud of a show a 1 rating. Anderson sleepwalks throughout the entire series dispensing what the writers apparently believe are profound words of wisdom and genius. Her alleged "deep insights" are boring and a waste of time. Let's get Dornan back on the screen! He is brilliant as a tortured Sociopathic killer. He is meticulous, cunning and vulnerable. I also liked the performance of Bronagh Waugh, who played Sally Ann, the clueless yet interesting wife of the killer. She comes off as a good person, good mother and a good wife. She didn't deserve to be married to her creepy husband. She works as a neonatal nurse in a hospital and there is a scene where she sits with a mother and her dying baby that will break the heart of even the hardest of us. It is a shame such a wonderful woman wound up marrying such a monster like Paul, the killer. I gave this series a 4 rating (out of 10)like I said, mostly for the Killer and his obsessive groupie who was his family's babysitter. If you're snowed in or there is nothing, and I mean nothing else, this works only at times.

One thing I like about British detective series is they portray believable characters. Unlike American detectives who dress in sexy garb as if they are going out for a night on the town, the female detectives in British shows are just as gritty and appropriately dressed as the men. The characters are more complex because of their imperfections. The female cops aren't all super heroes like so many Hollywood portrayed female cops. They have wrinkles, a few gray hairs, foibles and quirks. The same can be said for their villains. Even though they do evil things, they can also exhibit a more normal and even compassionate side. All the more frightening because they could be your neighbor, co-worker, or even your spouse and you'd never suspect them.This series pits two great hunters against one another. Gillian Anderson as Stella Gibson and the very handsome Jamie Dornan as Paul Spector are a well suited match. Watching these two characters, you realize that there is very little difference between the two hunters except for their reasons for hunting and their control over their impulses. They understand each other and toy with one another towards the end of the first season and beyond. This show exhibits a greater insight into the thought processes of a killer.It can be a slow paced show but well worth the wait. Just when you start to become bored, something exciting happens to pull you into the story and keep you watching. There are plenty of twists and turns involving peripheral characters that make you wonder how it will all fit together in the end. It is better and more realistic than anything on American television because the characters and the crimes are so believable.

reviews.review_title: Strong start, decends into clichées left and right.
reviews.content: Strong first season, grinds to a slow and pointless snoozefest.Much has been said about this shows' voyeurist enjoyment of violence against women. This, distasteful though it may be, is not entirely novel, nor is it much beyond industry standard.Much more controversial is the show's pathetic attempt at feminist characters. Apparantly, their idea of police work is straight from a non-stop view of every Dirty Harry movie. Hence, every single female character is constantly confusing agency with displaying either delusions of grandeur or gross professional miss-conduct. For a show with such a focus on female leads one is left to root for a handful of not brain-dead male coopers -- backs aching from carrying the investigation in spite of the ever more erratic decisions of their female bosses and colleagues.

And the villain became a poor sick bastard, with no mysteries other than a faked amnesia, who ends the show in an anticlimax sequence. My vote is 7 because of the two first seasons, they are still worth viewing. And what a strange rule from this site, that a review has to have at least ten lines? A lot of good stuff has been written here. Therefore, in my review I will try not to repeat myself, but simply to give an idea - who should watch it, and for whom it will be a waste of time.First of all, this is not a detective at all. In the presence of all the usual attributes of the detective genre, the main thing - a big secret and an exciting disclosure of crimes - will not. Here, the perpetrator and the victims are immediately known. In terms of genre, this is more of a psychological thriller. With a strong emphasis on psychology.Secondly, there is little action here, or at least tense moments that are simply familiar to criminal productions. Relative to the total timing, they are less than 10% here.Since the drama is psychological, almost the entire plot is devoted to revealing the characters, although you do not immediately understand that this is the main goal of the creators. Moreover, both main characters - the investigator and the criminal - are real psychologists. True, by profession only a criminal.As for the investigator (Anderson), she is absolutely no cop. In the course of the plot, he does not demonstrate not only the outstanding qualities of an interrogator, but even elementary mandatory professionalism. On the contrary, he makes unacceptable, sometimes downright wrecking mistakes. But, being a psychologist by vocation, he quickly and accurately characterizes the criminal. The latter gives her pathos.The maniac criminal is the main and most controversial character here. Clever, charismatic, tragic hero, creating cruelty that is hard to explain. The main attention of the viewer is riveted to his thoughts and actions. It may seem to someone that he is not brutally brilliant enough, like all sorts of Hannibal lecturers. And in my opinion, the emphasis on simple philistine character traits gives the hero more realism, eliminating the feeling of a purely cinematic monster.Yes, and the police, of whom every second character is here, behave quite believably. Both their individual weaknesses and the general imperfection of the system are revealed. This cannot but rejoice against the backdrop of most movie plots, where the cops are mostly valiant and brilliant.Also in the series there are several interesting intermediate lines with minor characters, very well embodied. In general, the characters and characters are well written here. Everything is in its place.The ending of the second (currently last) season looks a bit ambiguous. On the one hand, all the plot directions received their denouement, on the other hand, there seems to be a hint of a possible continuation. Nevertheless, there is no feeling of incompleteness, all questions have been answered.Summarizing, we can repeat that the idea is far from a detective story. Especially in its classic British sense. Relative to the crime genre in general, there isn't much novelty or twists and turns here. Smooth, unhurried psychological drama interspersed with a thriller. Interesting, deep characters and a good cast.7 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: Please God. Don't Watch. Save yourself.
reviews.content:
The old adage is that time is your most valuable resource and this show robbed me of a ton of it. I've never written a review before, but I felt obligated to do so for this piece of trash. The series was so unnecessarily slow it almost painful to watch. I heavily rely on the IMDb community when it comes to chosing what to watch, and it completely failed me this time. The entire thing could have been rapped up in 5 or so episodes. There are so many unnecessary shots and sequences that one cannot help but believe that either the series was edited/directed by an 8 year old in that it just rambles through so many useless details of a story OR the network was just milking this thing for all its worth knowing people may continue to tune in because of the solid leads and provocative subject matter. The acting by Jamie Dornan and Gillian Anderson is very strong and the only redeeming quality that makes it any bit tolerable. This is the only reason that I didn't give it a 1 and also didn't punch a hole in my wall when it ended. The writing of the series is so horrible in so manys that it doesn't even warrant my time to list them all. The most significant two are as follows. 1) There are so many errors, inaccuracies, and mistakes in the due process/police work demonstrated that one must figure the writers take the audience to be complete morons who won't even notice. 
2) Once you painstakingly arrive at the last episodes of the series, you think that they may have something and finally pull this thing together. NOPE! It just ends in an incredibly lazy way. Lots of solo shots of characters not saying anything. This is merely an attempt to make you think that maybe you didn't get the deeper message. The messages are clear and obvious early on so like I said, it's just Lazy. How anyone could rate this garbage anything higher than a 3 is beyond me. Either you have all the time in the world on your hands or you've never really watched decent film/tv. Rarely am I physically angry when something ends, but this did it.

By the end of season 4 I tired of the contrivance laden story line. I found myself silently yelling at the screen because, once again, the most basic police procedures/common sense had been sacrificed for dramatic effect. This has nothing to do with the pace of British drama, although it is slow in comparison to U.S. police procedurals. No, my issue was with the instances of lazy writing that really accumulated by the end of season 4. 
My actual rating would be season 1 and 2, ratings of 8; Season 3 and 4, ratings of 6.
Gillian is amazing in The Fall as she is in everything she stars in. The show has suspense, intrigue and . The writing and editing are top notch. A full package not to be missed!

The writing and direction of it are so patiently displayed as to leave you with the memory of it as if you indeed witnessed it. I didn't think I could handle 3 seasons of this.Sensing that Gillian Anderson would not have signed on to a ceaselessly violent script, I persisted.Boy was that decision rewarded!So many subjects are intimately covered with courageous attention to detail.This show nailed it.A more relevant score would be deepen the experience.
I got hooked from the first 15 minutes. It is thrilling, smart, smooth, interesting, and intriguing. I definitely recommend it if u r into psychological thrillers!

reviews.review_title: Great UK Thriller ... Shows how well trained we are!
reviews.content: What I love most about this show: The story is original, it does not follow the archetypal stories I feel we have been trained to expect. The story is rich with details and with normal human reactions. For example, when there is a death, people react as humans would not like often other shows have characters deal with someone's dying without any emotion what so ever.Different characters have actual personalities ... They have relationships with one another. There is detail. There is depth.Stereotypes are broken: good guys have flaws and bad guys have redeeming qualities ... Not a 10 because at times it seemed to go a little slow, otherwise it would have been a 10!!!

reviews.review_title: The Fall is perhaps the best television series that you have never heard of ...
reviews.content: When it comes to television, The Fall is as good as a television series gets. Once I started watching, I had no intention of turning off the five hours of content that comprise season 1. Even though you may not have heard of this show, it ranks up there with American dramas such as "House of Cards", "True Detective", "Breaking Bad", "Homeland",and "The Wire". Despite the compelling content, the show is hardly a mainstream event. It exists well below "the radar". At least it will remain below the radar until the world discovers that Jamie Dornan, the star of "Fifty Shades of Grey", which opens February 14, 2015 costars with Gillian Anderson of "The X Files". Dornan is the antagonist with Anderson playing the protagonist. He delivers a five star performance as Peter Spector, a loving father, philandering husband, professional bereavement counselor whose career is spiraling towards termination, and a psychotic serial killer. He is smart,physically fit, and is prone to allowing his heart dictate actions that will challenge his brain to fix when things go haywire. He supports his practices with pearls of wisdom from the Irish bard T.S. Eliot and German philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche. Anderson plays the protagonist, Detective Chief Inspector Stella Gibson of the Metropolitan Police Force who has been brought to Belfast to assist in the capture of the murderer of professional female who is the former daughter-in-law of a well-connected, corrupt member of the Belfast police board. We are forewarned that politics plays a big role in policing Belfast. The viewer must also keep in mind an adage about Northern Ireland, "To see what it was like during Victorian times, go to Northern Ireland. The laws that govern women's sexual rights date back to 1861." We are not in Kansas, Dorothy. Even though Dornan is the villain and Anderson is our hero, the audience is made aware of the many personality nuances that they share . Both characters are feisty, independent, domineering, well educated, ruthless, and indefatigable in pursuit of their goals. The difference is that Spector murders his chosen victims and Gibson specializes in catching psychotic criminals. To paraphrase Anderson's character, "Gibson is tasked with apprehending a serial killer known as "Peter". Gibson is the subject and Peter, the serial killer is the object. The act of apprehension expresses the verb function". Beyond this clear directive, the storyline is blurred by both diligent and dysfunctional behaviors occurring within the corrupt, corporal environment of Belfast. We see the charms and curses of this volatile city. If police business occurs near the infamous Shankill or Falls Roads, they must employ tactics used by the allied armies in Iraq and Afghanistan. The simplest steps carried out by law enforcement require a para-military police presence in order to succeed. The supporting cast is expertly played by a mostly Irish cast. Niamh McGrady is wonderful as Constable Danielle Ferrington, who becomes DCI Gibson's personal assistant while pursuing the killer. As the two police officials get to know each other, the show injects a splash of levity, which is needed to break the dark nature of the story. The assistant commissioner of police is played by John Lynch. Lynch portrays this tortured public official who has allies himself with dark side whenever it serves his purpose. A handful of characters who display scruples manage to keep this "house of cards" from collapsing. The six episode, second season of "The Fall" will air this fall on BBC2 & Netflix.

reviews.review_title: Season 3 Takes a Great Show into the Ditch
reviews.content: I loved the first two seasons. Great characters, great pacing, taut and suspenseful.I don't know what happened when they made Season 3 - different writers? - ran out of idea? - thought it would be good to go in a different direction? Whatever the reason, Season 3 took a great show and ran it into the ditch.**** SPOILER WARNING *****In addition, Season 3 also suffers greatly from some serious logic and realism gaps that make watching the show very annoying. I'm through the first three episodes and here's some of the major goofs I've seen:Does Spector's nurse ever go home? She's taking care of him 24 hours a day!How is it that Spector does not have restraints and/or a police officer guarding him? He's been accused of some horrific crimes, but no one seems concerned about keeping an eye on him or preventing him from walking out of the hospital.I cannot conceive how anyone would put Rose Stagg in the same hospital as Spector. But, not only is she there, she's in the next room!How is it that the police are unable to apprehend Spector's little girlfriend, Katie Benedetto, despite the fact that she walks about town freely, making no effort to disguise herself or otherwise keep under cover? This is even more ridiculous after she threw acid in the face of her now-former friend.

reviews.review_title: Four-part series stretched to five, terrible ending but refreshing
reviews.content: Warning ****May contain spoilers*** A police detective series not set in NY or LA, or even Paris or London, so it had my interest. I watched the entire five-part series in two sittings. I was hooked from the beginning. I could identify the multiple characters after the second time, something not normally easy for me.I thought the killer was eerily good. He led a mundane normal everyday life. You can see why there wouldn't be any focus on him right away, even though there were some tense exchanges. His wife was an awesome, almost angelic beautiful woman who was the perfect contrast.It was good to see so many fully bearded police officers, something not quite popular here in States, even though mustaches are quite common.I thought Gillian Anderson was a weak choice as detective. She was just lifeless. Not that she needed to shout or break down doors, but that she gets lost in mix. This was a four-part series at best. At certain points, it was really slow and you wanted it to get moving. Certain scenes stretched two long. The ending really was crappy. Unless they knew the series would be renewed, it should have been wrapped up after these five episodes.
An orgy of hidden feminism. I want this I can watch swedish politicians!

reviews.review_title: A raw and real crime show
reviews.content: A raw and real crime show. There are some powerful messages through out the show that flow with the story. Nothing seems deliberate or out of place. I enjoyed the constant conflict I felt between a legal vs a moral and ethical stand. It felt complete.

First season so good, second could be entertaining but the last one... it was extremely unrealistic. What happens with inspector Jim Burns? I suppose we have to imagine that he's related to Spector's childhood but this story would have been more interesting than seeing how Spector ends up committing suicide. On the other hand I understand that in 2013 it was a good serie.
It drags you in and keeps you there from begining to end. Great story, great acting, Gillian Anderson was superb

I'm not sure if the bar is set higher these days by other shows, but this was beyond slow and had so many unnecessary episodes and scenes, we began to question why certain episodes existed. This whole show could have easily been 1 season of 8 episodes.The score, cinematography, acting and directing was likely the best part of it. But overall, I would not recommend watching this unless you literally have nothing else to watch.

Its interesting to observe how different the UK and USA treat serial killers who are almost always psychopathic in their thinking. The USA like to analyse their characters, but the British want to brand them as just evil, in order to distance themselves from them and their behaviour. The Fall is very good drama, and Gillian Andersons style of acting, very brave, in that the poise she exhibits holds her under scrutiny for longer, which requires a very confident actress. It would have been more interesting if a psychiatrist had been included in the drama, as would have most certainly been done in the USA. As it was characters were presented purely for dramatic effect and motives hinted at without professional input.

reviews.review_title: sort of dark but, many great lessons about morality and mental health issues
reviews.content:
Sort of dark but, many great lessons about morality and mental health issues
the serial killer man had some serious issues, but the show really plays the devil's advocate and makes the viewers question, "are psychopaths born or created?" in this case, i honestly felt for the serial killer, though he did many terrible things and i feel so bad for the victims and their families as well. But this series felt very down to earth, with the harsh realities shown, and it seemed to really show the viewers what magnitude of damage child sexual abuse/witnessing mother's suicide can do. Its honestly one of the most
terrible things a child can go through, and i was so glad that the fall wasnt based on some true story. That would have quite literally broken my heart. I wish the serial killer paid the price and had justice served to him instead of him killing himself at the end. But again, the show was very realistic. We often see people who've done terrible crimes kill themselves. This show incited a lot of thoughts and reflection in my head.

reviews.review_title: Great thrilling story, bit slow though
reviews.content: Show was good thrilling TV despite no real suspense as audience gets to follow both police and criminal from the beginning. Experience with Northern Ireland accent and country was something different from rest of British or American TV. Story moves slowly though.First two seasons could be trimmed by 20% and part season by half. Incidents unrelated to main plot can be deleted. However it is just 17 hours so that's fine relief.Whole third and last season was downer for me. To much effort into generating sympathy for killer. Unreasonable and unrealistic plot incidents too. Sally Ann somehow can and wants to afford city's biggest lawyer for her deceitful husband. Gibson allows Spector to walk free in psych centre despite him punching her right then. And Katie's obsession is just random.Still I will give 8/10 for good unputdownable story.

reviews.review_title: Great, but tailed off a little near the end
reviews.content: This was gripping, absolutely gripping. It tailed off a little towards the end.But overall this was excellent and a much watch.

reviews.review_title: Wish I could give it 11 out of 10
reviews.content: Fantastic gripping series, I binge watched for 3 days n nights...watch it I thoroughly recommend xx

Ok can we start by saying I am 7 years too late.
I'm sure I am not the only one who came across this series in 2020 but BOY I am impressed.I am one too judge too quickly especially when it comes to British series, I always find them not leading anywhere, not much acting, a little annoying, storyline does not develop the way the typical netflix show does etc.Firstly the 2 main characters are amazing actors anyway. Could not have though of a better Paul Spector or Detective Gibson so round of applause for getting that spot on.In terms of storyline, I am a sucker for thrillers and this honestly had a little of everything I like in a drama. Creepiness, stalking, murder and mystery. must say this won't be one for the faint hearted, it's intense like PROPER INTENSE till the last episode.There's a part of me which makes me sad, to think I would hate the main character being a serial cold hearted killer, it made me sad, for him to fit in a world to which he was not loved to begin with, breaks my heart. It makes me reflect on real life and how you really don't know a person , with or without the sinister thoughts. Paul Spector lied about how he was treated when he was younger and it really opens so much more about the character. Worth a watch but it really does get you thinking, there was definitely a soft spot from Stella to Paul and I loved it, was never a one sided, bad guy character, I hope this makes sense!

reviews.review_title: Great set up huge let down spoilers
reviews.content: Starting third season and am really more interested in my snacks. Such a shame as it was a great set up for a long involved cat and mouse situation that took a wrong turn and dissolved into a disjointed mess. It could have really progressed well if it was better thought out. I mean honestly the sexy coroner just happens to remember a college friend that told only her about a man that attempted to strangle her in college during rough sex and low behold its him. That's just lazy writing. And all these dumb side stories that never connect like the husband and wife that were seeing paul spector over the loss of their son. That could have been tied in and played out so much better. The reporter that pops up? The sext coroner mentioned previously becomes obsolete after she rejects horny cougar stella. Again no connection. And stella.....sheesh. I mean the first time we see anything beyond iceberg tears on rare occasion is when she screams when psycho killer gets shot. Hello? Really really squandered an opportunity to have this play out well.

reviews.review_title: They must have paid a lot for these high ratings.
reviews.content:
Horrible writing, poorly executed, poor taste disguised as some sort of highly intellectual serial killer chase series.
Silence of the lambs wanna be, with a Hollywood has been and a discount Henry Cavill. And to top it all, the dumbest police in the history of TV.
Now!! the truth is out there!

This is a well acted show with a plot that kept me interested, but the long, drawn out lulls grew tiresome. They could have made the show significantly better (and a number of episodes shorter) by just cutting out long, slow shots that cut back and forth to people thinking that were likely meant to build suspense but did the opposite by getting boring, and added nothing to character development. Sometimes the show seemed that it couldn't decide what it wanted to be, there is one episode that came across as a medical drama and was completely inconsistent with the other episodes and added almost nothing to the story. Good show, worth watching, but is made better if you can fast forward the tedious bits.
I just finish the whole series., I like the story from the beginning til the final season , hope to have more tv series like this!

The show was ok, I liked the killer's story and the way they presented it/filmed it, keeps u tense and curious.I didn't like how Spector was super smart and conscious about what he was doing at first but starting with S2 he made foolish mistakes, and I'm not talking about clumsiness but about things like invoking suuuch a bad alibi or putting himself in danger. But I get it, they are serial killers who can't control themselves and so on, I ignored the plot holes because they seemed somehow human/real.As for the detective Gibson, as much as I love Gillian, this was such bad acting... or maybe just a bad character, too much of a superiority complex induced.Every other cop character felt like a really stupid kid.Season 3 was all about finale, Spector's story and how he became who he is. It was a needed touch, I guess.The finale was good, I prefer this over the killer going to jail, makes it less basic/obvious.If you like true crime shows it is worth a shot.
Very good show but the constant whispering by Anderson drove me crazy. Soft talkers......

Its very good
In the other hand very slow events
You can put the series in two seasons only

If you are more demanding than the average person when it comes to writing and directing, you probably want to skip this terrible thriller. It does a decent job at creating a tense atmosphere but that will not suffice to compensate for the blatant lack of realism. Not only the characters are unrealistic but also most situations luke crime scenes, hospital scenes. Clearly the writers were not advised by doctors or police, justice officers. If it had some form of common sense it would not be so obvious but sadly it is devoid of that too. Not to mention that it's way slower and longer than necessary. Some scenes seem to be there just as fillers, just to make episodes longer. Some are incredibly slow for no apparent reason. That could be bearable if the investigation or characters were realistic. Amost total fail.

This is a very poorly researched and written series. Police procedures are ignored to draw out the storyline resulting in police negligence which would bring criminal charges against investigating officers. Totally incredulous in every way. I stopped watching at series two episode 4. Please don't waste your time with this series. It demeans your intelligence to do so.

reviews.review_title: First series is pretty good, after this one it get's annoying
reviews.content: Loved the first series but during the next series I became very annoyed with all the whispering of this Stella character. WHY is this necessary? People don't talk like this in real life, well, in church maybe, but not in the office. Bad directing!

reviews.review_title: Soooo good season one and two
reviews.content: This series is one of my favourite of all I've seen. But season 3 destroyed that. It isn't true to the first two and destroyes all that was good. So see the first two, skip the third. It will only make you disapointed you watched it

First episodes are logic and nice, but after a while it doesn't make any sense. You can see that the writers doesn't know anything about the police in general.They know which car he is driving, series: we do nothing.They know his voice and looks, series: we do nothingThe babysitter knows everything, the wife knows... no one, doesn't do anything.It does not make any sense. It makes you just mad about the whole story.

I recently saw this superb drama. I loved the main charachters depth and the vivid portrayal of the inequality and bias towards women. The story could read as a well known tragedy but the dialogs especially between the two main charachters, demands viewers with social empathy and probably with knowledge of the basic phycological rules that drives human emotion.
One of the worst shows ever made. Slow and dark and provocating, but not interesting.

reviews.review_title: Great show with some loose ends
reviews.content: Another great show on Netflix. Enjoyed the story, music, acting. The main characters are complex and realistic, making the show like a documentary. The plot does have some loose ends. Spector volunteered to speak to the police after the video footage in the park was shown, and was instructed to write down the foster homes he was at. At that point, I thought, clever, because the police can compare the handwriting with that of the letter sent to victim's father. But they didn't, surprisingly, and nobody thought about doing it which to me is a very routine detective tool.

Loved the first two episodes but 3 is different, too slow & reflective & Gillian Anderson's constant whispering à la Bruce Willis is tiresome. The subtitles are only in Dutch & the Nortnern Ireland accents & her constant whispering are sometimes difficult to follow. They should have killed Spector off at the end of episode 2 but I guess the urge to continue was too strong.1 and 2 were excellent, Gillian Anderson is a very elegant investigation SIO policewoman & Jamie Dornan a spine-chilling killer. All the other roles are well played although John Lynch's Assistant Constable cuts a rather sad figure.

What homicide detective goes to work every day looking like she has a hot dinner date? The spikey heels, tight skirts, half-buttoned blouse and salon coiff suggest that Armstrong was auditioning for a completely different film. She looks so disinterested and bored like she can't wait to get back to a posh cocktail party in Chelsea. Every once in awhile she casually mentions her hatred of men but with the same blank expression she wears while questioning witnesses. For some reason, young cops can't wait to jump her bones even though she's twice their age. She won't even get undressed when they do, presumably so she doesn't give up the game.The guy responsible for writing and directing this mess even quotes Margaret Atwood's infamous line about women being afraid men will kill them. Well yes, serial killers are known for that, but oddly enough, this guy's wife harbors no such fear. Quite the contrary. The cop calls her stupid (she's working class, y'know) but the guy is such a milquetoast around the wife, who can blame her? He's also a lousy killer, making mistakes so stupid you assume he must have done it on purpose as a joke.From what I've read here, it only get worse later on, so try something better like Marcella or Dark on Netflix.
With a more talented and well trained actor that series could have been abs amasing.

With the recent developments in the world of media production, the audiences are getting used to high quality series, with movie directors and actors making amazing pieces. Still, it is appreciated when you see a nice piece of work like The Fall. I think the pace is optimal, takes its time to develop the story, Gillian Anderson is very elegant in her role, which I think she came to master over the years- I refer to this aura that you can also see in Hannibal. This archetype of first woman. - Not to be understood as Eve. Still she remains a mystery to us. Even Paul Spector knows her more than us. I think it would be better if we knew a little more about this woman. The fact that she remains a total mystery makes it harder to feel her pain also. But still very good. 
However, the actor playing Paul S. is just not good. I am sorry and I don't want to be like this horrible internet people who says terrible things about people but he is not a good actor. He has simply no presence, no charisma, nothing. This kind of caracter should normally stir up something in you, take up some space. But he is just all that. Most interesting or saddest thing can be happening, the world might be hit by a meteor, you feel like he will have the same look in his eyes. His most expressive moments can only be described as the facial expressions of a guy selling metro tickets to people. I think the best scene was after he was shot, dead eyes, life going out of him, that, he can play well.

reviews.review_title: A good cast; great acting by the principles.
reviews.content: The Fall is one of the best series I've seen. The acting and directing is exceptional and is more noticeable due to the lack of shootouts and car chases found in most U.S. crime shows. You can actually tell the emotions of a character from his/her visage (all too rare in dramas of today. This is especially true of the villain, Paul Spector, played by Jamie Dornan. Unable to remember the last six years of his life due to trauma caused by a bullet wound, Spector has the appearance of an innocent victim until he remembers his first murder. It can then be seen in his face that he is reverting back to the antisocial personality disorder that led to his murders.

reviews.review_title: Outstanding, except for the season 2 ending episode....
reviews.content: For anyone interested, here's my idea of an alternative ending episode of season 2: As Spector is interviewed in Larson's office in the Foley Clinic, a scene is included where Spector sees Larson unlock a personal lockbox that contains, among other things, a handgun. He is close enough to see the combination and remember it. In my version of the ending episode, Spector makes his way in to Larson's office after that violent altercation with Larson and gets the handgun and escape the Foley Clinic among all the turmoil. He makes his way back to the streets of Belfast, contacts Katie, and arranges to meet her. The police are anticipating his movements, though, and glimpse him on CCTV. Spector is confronted by Gibson there on the street and Spector grabs Katie from behind and takes her hostage. Katie breaks loose from Spector and Spector pulls the handgun from his back and takes aim on Gibson. Gibson shoots him in the chest and Spector falls to the pavement. As Katie cradles Spector's head in her hands he grabs her forearm to keep her close as he lays there, but Katie pulls away from him and lets his head down on the pavement. She stands up and slowly backs away. As she turns to look at Gibson, she runs toward her and into Gibson's arms, the implication being that Katie knows that she never meant anything to Spector after all, as Gibson had previously explained to her in conversation. There are still some loose ends, but at least this version offers a little more closure than the existing one.

reviews.review_title: Would be a 10 but for plotholes
reviews.content: A brilliantly written and filmed show. Gillian Anderson is fantastic, she provokes thought and has some incredible speeches through the series. The series definitely favours females, but I have no problem with that and find it a fair reflection of the western world.Jamie Dornan balances the psychotic and 'normal' human to perfection.This could have been 2 series rather than 3, several pointless characters such as Katie and the older cop in love with Gibson, but the 'read-between-the-lines' storytelling was masterful. Wish we found out what happens with his wife and kids after the fact.A lot of people saying they don't understand the end, why kill the other inmate? To show that he can! He planned it from before he wrote the poem in the inmates book. He controlled his own death, he controlled everyone around him, he could have fled but this way it was his choice and died the same way his mother went.

Like a number of people have already written this drama could have been done in one series. The third series is pretty non descript except for the increasingly annoying whispering by Miss Anderson. It's not a bad series but it's not that great either.One more thing to note, am I the only one who found it weird by Anderson asking her colleagues to go through her wardrobe on a number of occasions?!

Then it gets stupider and stupider. Let the culprit walk away multiple times. Why, I have no idea. I guess so suspect can potentially lead them to a woman who may or may not be dead. In the meantime he gets to kill other ones. Car drives up at night, sees the police, shuts off lights, backs up slowly and makes uturn. All while the lead investigator stands there and watches, with a car right behind her. I guess the expression follow the car never dawned on her or the writers. So many SMH moments. They probably could have pulled it off in two seasons, but had to stretch it to three, leading to so many absurd scenes.

Very realistic. What made it a great show for me was the support cast. A lot of them, but they were all superb. Gillian was the weak link though. Too slow and ponderous for a high ranking police officer. Maybe she was concentrating on her English accent too much ? Nevertheless, it was a great series. Everyone involved in the making of it should be proud of their performances.

A great series, impeccably written, very layered and with great premise. In addition to the mother, of course, being a dad, a present dad, is an important role. The role that everyone benefits from; child and society itself.
In general, the final season should be the cherry on top. But in this show, season 3 was the quit opposite. It was so expected and added no value to the previous good seasons.
This is not my usual type of series or film when similar are made, but jeez, this gripped me from series 1 episode 1. A must watch! Doesn't drag at all. Really good!

reviews.review_title: Great show for people who liked Dexter, but hated the last season.
reviews.content: Great show. I personally think this is the best serial killer show on here. But maybe needs a little less sexual content ( it kinda made me uncomfortable )

reviews.review_title: So good but just slightly too long
reviews.content: Very worthwhile watching. Gillian Anderson is superb. Series 1 & 2 are excellent. Unfortunately for me, series 3 just dragged on slightly too long. You could have condensed its 6 episodes into 3. Slight shame as took the edge of it.

First season was sort of compelling but a little silly in places. The second season descends into utter farce with completely inept police work. The show is interspersed with Gillian Anderson showing cleavage and her curves as much as possible also for added realism.

The first season really brought something fresh to the screen. The atmosphere of the series is dark, gloomy, frightening and even disgusting at some points and it may put some people off. On the other hand, being real to life, this fact may be appealing to others. I think The Fall is one of the finest and well- crafted representatives of the crime/detective genre. *SPOILERS* The plot revolves around two characters: detective Stella Gibson (Gillian Anderson) and the killer and a family man, Paul Spector (Jamie Dornan). Stella is independent, strong, highly intelligent and she functions perfectly in the world of men. She lives alone and occasionally engages in carefree and short sexual relationships with (sometimes married) fellow colleagues. Paul is also witty, intelligent, strong and independent, although living a life of a perfectly ordinary family man and a father of two. The fact that he is a father makes this other, violent side of him more surprising. During the day, he is a grieving counsellor who walks his children to school, tucks them in bed and reads stories to them. At night, he puts on his hood, stalks his victims and attacks his prey. The biggest and most significant achievement of the series is the fact that it is slow-paced and very detailed. Sarah Gibson traces, examines, reexamines, observes and discusses every new clue with great attention and care. She thinks about everything and always encourages her coworkers to pay attention to subtle details. The series demonstrates that every investigation takes a lot of time and that policemen should never jump to conclusions. For example, Gibson was always apprehensive about what kind of information should be released to the press, whether she should unbutton the top button on her blouse etc. This role suits G. Anderson perfectly and every change in the tone of her voice and every frown on her face is significant.
