When speaking she reveals that she manages the situation with ease, despite what men may think. Paul Spector is also a very well-written character and he manages to seem frightening enough to be convincing. His slowness, coolness and calmness emphasise the sense of fear. The murder of Sarah Kay should be the textbook example of an excellent forensic practice depicted on film. Detectives in white examining the corpse of a beautiful woman lying on bed were eerily graphic, frightening and real. This may scare some viewers off but, on the other hand, this is the reason why this series stands out among all the others. The second season is also good, but there are too many subplots. The nanny of Paul's children, his wife, corrupt police chiefs, a violent local hooligan who beat his wife, Rose Stagg - these are all characters that unnecessarily slow the pace of the story. It focuses mainly on the tracing and following Paul Spector. It seems that the writers were losing the track and got lost a bit... All in all, riveting but not to everyone's taste.

I'm usually fascinated by thrillers, especially murderous ones. I was skeptical at first to see the killer being a main character- and how brilliantly they pulled this off. You hate him one second, kinda like him the next. Crazy gripping in a slow methodical way. Some scenes with Stella make you want to cheer out loud. I nearly lost faith in the show during the 3rd season, but they thankfully yanked me back. I loved all the characters, actors and story line. It certainly was a guilty pleasure for me, binge watching this took nearly 4 days of agonizing delight. Loved the poetic references. Liked the way they handled the attraction and desire of an underage young girl without actually crossing too many lines. Dark and creepy...I will remember this one for quite some time.

On and on and on and on it plods.
Series 2 was pointless.
Only watched as my partner persevered with it.
Absolutely littered with plot holes, poor script writing and tedious drawn out conversations with no relevance to the story.
Guy should've been arrest and jailed after the 3rd episode.
Makes the PSNI look like the keystone cops.
Don't waste your time...

reviews.review_title: No Likable Characters, Too Much Female Nudity
reviews.content: I watched the first 2 episodes. After the first one I liked it. There is some female nudity in the first episode, which I hoped was just there to capture male viewers' interest to continue the series. After watching the second episode, I decided to quit. A major problem is that Gillian Anderson's character is not likable. Neither is Jamie Dornan's character, and you need someone to like in every show. Peripheral characters are better, but none stood out. Also, a little female nudity doesn't bother me, but the scenes of the female victim's naked body for long periods in the 2nd episode, along with a sex scene showing partial female nudity (but no male nudity), was too much. Yes, you see a tiny bit of Jamie Dornan's backside in one episode, but this show definitely caters to men. And back to Gillian Anderson, as another reviewer wrote, she needs to extend her range. If they had cut back on the nudity, and had a good, likeable main character, I would have stuck with it. The plot was interesting, but not enough.

I find this series deserves more than 10/10 I would give it 15 or more over 10. I have watched till now season 1 and 5 episodes of the 2nd season. I find it extremely thrilling and amazing. I am always excited to see what's going to happen and how the events will take place in the next chapter...
But the ending is a little bit disappointing as if Gibson has pushed the Spector to commit suicide and his escape the punishment or "Cheat the system" may be because his childhood was abused this is the best end and most reasonable one, but I find a real confession and punishment would relief the viewer and make a worth return for the efforts exerted over 11 episodes by the detectives...
This series is my favorite. Acting was very good. In fact, when the murderer died, I was sad rather than happy. Because the show is over.

All in all, The Fall is an excellent series and I recommend. it. My one minor issue, however , was the odd decision to have Gillian Anderson continually used a low whisperly (at times, raspy mumbling) voice that seemed more in keeping with someone with a chronic lung condition rather than with a hard driving, in-charge style detective supervisor.

The idea was good but execution went very bad. We can finish this entire story in 4 to 5 episodes. The screenplay is quite boring and despite they know the suspect they won't arrest him until you come to the end of 2nd season.Stay away from this and save your time

Season 1 was so good, love how story developed. But season 2 failed to impressed me. From all series about serial killer that I've watched, this is the worst. To many plot holes. The serial killer is not so smart, he just an ordinary trying to kill in series. The most awful thing is he easily found and sneaked to stela place, but when john came to stela room, she asked him why he knew where she stay, that's absurd. Not even a higher rank officer and the one who picked up her at air port not knowing where she stay, but a not so genius serial killer knew her place easily? Season 2 was poorly written, they should end the series when season 1 end.

reviews.review_title: Great but could have been so much more
reviews.content: I'm not going to delve into a lengthy review as that has clearly been overdone. Started off incredibly intriguing, good character development and well thought out plot. People complain about the dive into Spector's past in season 3 saying that it was drawn out and unnecessary. I don't agree with this, what's the point in a series about a serial killer with no context behind it? Motive explanations lead you along the path of why the deaths are happening and what could possibly drive an individual to commit such horrific crimes. The only bone I have to pick with it is the end episode started off well but ended abruptly with hardly any twists or turns that the series had previously offered. One more season would have completed the drama perfectly.

reviews.review_title: First season amazing. Second great. Third, NO
reviews.content: The first and second season were fresh and exciting. Grips you from the start and holds you every episode. It really is great. The second season goes the same way but "veers off" around episode 6The third season should never have been made.That's it. That's the review.

reviews.review_title: Great Start Followed by a Fail in Season Three
reviews.content: Seasons one and two were great. So great that I gave it an early rating of 9 stars. That said, season three seriously sucked. So boring that I can't bear to finish it. A real shame. They should have ended it after season two or done better with season three (ideally).

Like others, I thought the first 2 series were very well done, and deserving of the critical love. But wow, the third contained so many obvious errors, like the hospital scenes with no guards or restraints on him or police protection of Rose. And the cheap resolution of the whole story was so anti-climatic. What was the point of having his fellow inmate create the disturbance? He just as well could have hung himself anywhere at any time since he had so much (unbelievable) freedom. Better ending if he had escaped, and it would have been much scarier if we had seen him walking down a sunlit street somewhere following a dark haired
woman at the end. Or if the inmate who caused the disturbance killed him just as he was about to escape. The hanging was...meh.And what about Stella? No tiny indication of a better, happier, more fullfilling life, after this awful ordeal? She just goes back to her lonely pitiful world? Very unsatisfying. The series needed a little lightness along the way, and some hope for Stella in the end.

This show could've been so perfect but one major problem. Gillian Anderson is a lousy, boring, uninteresting, untalented actress. Anyone else probably would've been better. Her accent is ridiculous. Her personality is like wet sand and I spent all my time hating her performance when Jamie Dornan was doing such a spectacular job.Yes it's a bit long and drawn out and I think the story could've been concluded way before it was but I needed something to watch so...
I just cannot stress enough how much Gillian's acting brings this movie down to an uncomfortable level of suckiness. Portraying her as some kind of femme fatale that no man nor woman can resist made me chuckle.So watch it for Jamie's performance and try to get past hers.

Anderson, wooden & one dimensional.Writing full of holes.Like a girl descending into a dark basement, while we shout, don't!DNA. Fingerprints, handwriting & they overlook him?Wish I had the time back.

reviews.review_title: Great two seasons, third painfully dull
reviews.content: Great two seasons, third painfully dull. Acting is great.

I don't leave many reviews, and I don't use the word "beautiful" much... and a strange word to use in a serial killer/crime drama - but you have to credit the balance here of storytelling, acting and direction. To me this is beautiful. I'm late to the "The Fall" party, only started watching last week but I am approaching the end of series 2 fast. I can't stop watching. This is a real world crime drama that works and the realism is abject. The story is clever enough, not entirely original but what is entirely original anyway? I'm not going to go into the plot (I'm sure you've guessed it) and that's not the stand out reason I'm writing this. It's the delivery. The lighting/direction is masterful, the plot is blood drainingly tense and the acting is superb - not just Gillian Anderson or Jamie Dornan (who are both brilliant) but the entire cast including the kids are exceptional. Well played the writer(s), director and all involved. More please :-)

I watched the series as "The Fall" and I like this name more because it is more meaningful. In the series now a kind of simple, because I'm hooked on comedy. It is all the more pleasant to see such a convincing and tenacious work of the British. Only two directors filmed three seasons, although there are only 17 episodes.Filmed in a very original way from the point of view that I saw here a bunch of the same type of people who are looking for each other, find themselves in each other, doubt and give advice. The series is essentially about a maniac, but this is not a detective at all, here they give you the opportunity to listen to your own feelings and find a maniac in yourself.I liked the detail. Maybe even redundant. I couldn't watch The X-Files for a long time, so I can't say anything about the actress Gillian Anderson. I saw Jamie Dornan in several films, but now, most likely, I will remember.The series is really enough for something alive, it is interesting to watch and even three seasons do not bother at all. I recommend it to everyone who missed or, like me, did not watch the series.

reviews.review_title: Worth it, even if season 3 wasn't fulfilling
reviews.content: If you're into serial killers you'll probably love this, the first two seasons were extremely engrossing, I fell into an almost obsession with it as soon as I started but I'll admit just like everyone else, season 3 wasn't what we'd had hoped it'd be. I almost felt like it was a predictable ending, with Peter/paul being caught, no where else to go with his story, what else could he have done but kill himself to escape any punishment? Being a sadistic and morbid narcissist, that was pretty much the only way it'd have gone. Disappointing, yes but realistically, spot on.

reviews.review_title: I was very disappointed in this series. Not sure if I am actually including any spoilers.
reviews.content: Generally speaking, I have found that when a series is rated 8 or higher, that I can depend upon that series as being good. Not with this one.The best part of this show--and I am not offering this up as a joke--is the police procedures of the Belfast police department and the interactions between the various police personnel, from the standpoint of their office and responsibility. That I found to be interesting.One thing which I have observed in some series is, there is a great deal of sexual activity--often illegal or forbidden activity--found in a series like this. There is a significant amount of interaction between the villain and a 15/16 year old girl. I realize for some people, that may be enticing; but it is there and there is a considerable amount of interaction between these two (nothing explicitly shown, of course, but there are a lot of details which are discussed--particularly by the young girl.The female lead is a strong woman who is sexually aggressive. Is that not the case for every single strong female lead where there is any sort of a sexual angle?The villain is very sick and does some very sick and violent things. My own opinion is, his actions are way over the top.My biggest mistake was, not reading any reviews about this show before I got the DVD.If you are looking for a "smart thriller" to watch with your older kids...this is not it.

The first season was amazing and the second season I questioned several times if there was even a point to watch anymore. I settled on a 7 but I'd say the first season was a 10 and the second was a 3 so it kinda evened out. Based on ratings I won't even bother watching the third. What a bummer! Did they fire the writers??
Entire show was thrilling except for the last two episodes. How it ended was so disappointing, felt as the writers got sick of story and put any idea came to mind.

Damn, was this shot in real-time? Its slooooow. I swear most of the first episode is watching someone drink a glass of wine, a cup of coffee, looking at the computer, or a combination of these. He's no Dexter or Hannibal, pretty sure he bores his victims into suicide. I did have one thing in common with the killer, I choked myself repeatedly for 40 minutes. Sorry, but the last good thing to come out of the UK was Dog Soldiers in 2002.

This TV series is a complete disaster. They could finish it in just one season, there are so much unnecessary details that could easily boredom you! You feel the producer had money and didn't know what to do with it except wasting on this TV series.

reviews.review_title: The first season is a champ
reviews.content: It is a procedural, but one that puts a strong woman much more in your face than any other I have ever seen.
The serie could be sum up in 2 season, the story loses its interest half way through. I can tell that the start and the ending is good though.

I really enjoyed this show,it got me right from the very 1st episode.
I binged watched the whole 3 seasons in a couple of day,highly recommended.

You cannot blame gravity for falling in love," said Albert Einstein. However, who is to be blamed for falling in shadow and darkness? When you start watching a crime series, or a movie, you do not really want to know who is the killer straight away. The catch is to solve the case with whoever the investigator is. So why would the producers of a Northern Irish TV series decided to show us the killer in the first episode. Isn't all about solving the case? The producers of The Fall", a TV series that premiered in mid-2013 decided that the path is the goal. When Superintendent Stella Gibson, perfectly played by Gillian Anderson (she is fluent in British English!), comes from London Metropolitan Police to Belfast to investigate serial killer case we already know the guy – we saw his face, we know his oeuvre and his means for torturing his victims. Peter Paul Spector is one of the first characters we see and from the very beginning we know – he is the perpetrator.How clear is that – the Good (Stella) will try to catch the Bad (Paul) with the help of the Ugly (Jim Burns, Stella's ex-lover and her supervising officer at the Police Service of Northern Ireland). So why would we watch it? Obviously, because it is not about the who" but about how", not how did he do it", but how will she ever catch him".The lines drawn at the beginning are deceiving. Many shades of grey come to the light soon enough to keep the viewer interested and attracted by the story. We take this fall together.Two main characters – Stella and Peter – are seemingly opposed but down this path we took together we start to seen not only that each one of them has this other" side but also that they have so much in common. Firstly the oppositions: Stella is a woman, she is cold and distant, doesn't have a family, work is everything to her. Her aim is to keep the city clean from the evil. Paul – a man, a family man, what is more – a counselor, an empathetic and placeable psychologist. Fair enough, opposite characters in a common case. However, what kind of woman is Stella? Focused and determined, perfectionist and authoritarian. She will not miss any clues or spots. However, she has a weak point (or is it?) - she likes men, and she treats them as objects. The first man in the series she wraps around her finger falls for her despite being a father and a husband (he will pay a high price for his sins...). She uses her victim" as a toy, and she does not like decomposing the issue into prime factors.Wait a minute...objectifies, uses the victim, well controlled and perfectionist cultivating rituals – this perfectly depicts our beloved" Peter Paul.Moreover, there's the rub. Only (s)he who knows the dark side can follow and catch the doer. Because technically (s)he is a doer too. Just the repercussions and the against-the-law" issue are different. Still, we all know that the law is established by men, therefore, it is limited to whatever is considered illegal by the men themselves. What is within the margin of the error goes.Stella and Peter are very similar indeed. They both cross certain lines. They are both very erotic, but each one in a different way, and voyeuristic. Because again, it is not about what" but about how".It takes two series for Stella to get finally to see and catch Paul (he has the advantage of knowing and observing her, and that lets him being one step ahead) and eventually (SPOILER!) despite having him at a gunpoint she fails to punish him properly. Moreover, that is how she get her punishment. Maybe if he was more focused and less disturbed by his deviation he would be more careful. However, then why would she even chase him? British crime has its history if it comes to solving criminal cases with Agatha Christie's Mrs Marple and Hercules Poirot. The latter has successfully solved the case depicted in Murder on the Orient Express" - Poirot gives two solutions. Which one is real? Does it matter? Id does not because what is important is why would the crime be committed in the first place.In the end, it is all about understanding that we all have committed dark deeds. That we all have been falling for our darks side. Just sometimes these deeds are against the law.Read more on www.visualandwriting.com

reviews.review_title: Sadistic over and over and over
reviews.content: We get the point after seeing 3 brutal murders by a serial killer of his cunning depravity and duplicity. Why keep showing this with more victims? More focus on the investigation would be interesting. Stopped watching after 4 episodes. Disgusting!Shouldn't be on PBS.

Unnecessarily lengthy, just stretching the story to make it a long TV Series. Could be effectively summed up in one season of 4/5 episode, relevant things are only of around 4/5 hours.Moreover, no strong plot, logical reasoning.

Oh my but this is just very, very good. Whilst not a 10/10 like Broadchurch, in my mind the 'gold standard' of TV, it is simply excellent. The psychopath here is beyond chilling, at times quite uncomfortable to watch. This is one of those shows that leaves you talking about it after each episode. 'How can she not know?' The back drop of Belfast and the relationship with the UK is also very well drawn and a reminder of the push-pull between the two. It adds to the story quite brilliantly but might be confusing for Americans.You want to keep watching and keep watching, in this regard it equals 'Breaking Bad' but it is the details that the Director nails. When the victim see's the psycho take off his mask and knows right there that she is going to die, it is chilling to the bone.Watch it. Brilliant.

I watched it till the end more out of curiousity rather than being entertained, the main character was good. However, the female officer Gibson was a real puzzle, her voice was irritating far too soft and mild for an officer. The first season was good and kept me interested but the rest was a disappointment. I think the whole thing tried to delve into the mind of a psychopath and why the main character did what he did, at this point there was too much chatting and not enough acting. There are quite a few irritating characters I dont know whether they were suppose to be irritating or just bad acting. Worth a watch but no big deal.

reviews.review_title: It should have been a single season
reviews.content: Season 1 is a truly great British crime series which I even dare compare to Luther. It keeps you at the edge of the seat with the story, atmosphere and location. Belfast surely adds a layer of flavour.I was really looking forward to see the next 2 criminals/cases in the following seasons. That's why I was unpleasantly surprised to see they decided not to wrap things up when they easily could.If you notice that season 1 had 5 episodes, and seasons 2 and 3 have 6, it makes you think that the series was originally intended as a single, 6-episode season.Dissapointedly we move to season 2 which drops the pace by 80% and is full if irrelevant scenes, close-ups, prolonged silences. Through these 6 episodes, the story gets minimal movement.And then comes season 3. You can make a drinking game out of the first episode,for every time someone says sistolic or adrenaline. It's a poor ER episode which adds zero value to the show.My recommendation is reading the story for this season online, in 5 minutes, rather than wasting 6 hours of your life on this.

Writers based serial killer Paul Spector on real life serial killer who called himself BTK. They center the story to the enigma how man can kill and torture random women and conceal their aberrant behavior from their family and surroundings. But thats where they went wrong, They didn´t research the subject well enough. BTK Dennis Rader and Ted Bundy who Spector resembles strongly, couldn´t hide their deranged mind from their surroundings. Most important ingredient in murder is hate and it showed. They either terrorized their neighborhood or vanished when pleased. Double life is not easy. Thats why Spector is not plausible. Serial killers are abusive, haunted and hollow men who contribute nothing to their surroundings, they are simply destructive parasites. I don´t see any of it here. Disturbing side is that Jamie Dornan seems to agonize beautiful young women in his every movie and female audience love it, because he is hot. So how in earth that goes with obvious feminist agenda? I hate slasher movies about beautiful women with senseless violence with shallow motives and consequences - I thought feminist did too. And all these unnecessary erotic imagery combined with autopsy photos. This kind of fathomless horror leaving behind destroyed lives has to be dealt with decency and dignity for victims (even though they are fictional), act of murder should not feel like porn.Otherwise camera work, slow pace, Anderson character, stupid men, absence of shootings and car chases were good.

One of the strongest, darkest psychological thrillers I've watched in a very long time. I was absolutely rapt as I watched the slow but steady character development during the early episodes. Gillian Anderson's character is a strong, intelligent, independent and determined woman, a highly skilled investigator, and unwilling to compromise or change. Her antagonist and suspect is also of strong intellect, highly obsessive, filled with hatred for, and a need to overpower women he sees as intellectual and status equals or of higher intellect and power. He is torn between his family which traps him and his obsession which controls him.The programme is well worth watching. In fact, it is a must-watch.

reviews.review_title: Not so impressed with the series
reviews.content: I have to say I was rather disappointed when watching the movie series, as seeing the user reviews and the rating my expectations were really high.Instead I have found an average screen play: the pace was too slow and sometimes took too long until it built tension, while other times it built tension and nothing happened. Also, developing some of the characters took too much from the focus of the plot and did not improve or benefit the overall story.I also thought the way the main character behaved was not realistic, was too caring and mothery.I did like Gillian Andersons's acting and some parts of the series. I also liked that it was a short series and I finished it quickly.

reviews.review_title: fasten your seat belt and go to sleep
reviews.content: 3 series to listen to SIO drone- all the intrigue of a pudding cup.

When you start it you just can't stop!!!
Simple and very well made Northern Irish production!!!
...
But I had to come back here and edit this comment to say that 3th season is deeply disappointing...no script anymore... should have finished at 2nd...just to much "Greys Anatomy" episodes and a very ridiculous ending!!!!
We have just finished watching the fall, it was really compelling and kept us on the edge of are seats, really well made not a very nice subject matter but it was really realy well done.

reviews.review_title: Ugh, but why did it end this way
reviews.content: Season 1 & Season 2 we're the most captivating episodes. Such a gripping and exciting story, I tried to hard not to binge watch this series.The writers brought an amazing thriller and set the stage for what I thought to be an incredible twist in the story. Great character build, and Anderson is super sexy and a fantastic detective. I am however, extremely disappointed with the way the final season ended.. I expected so much more.I had my own idea of how this show was supposed to end and I expected it to all make some more sense than this.Excellent show but disappointing ending of an incredibly written show.

reviews.review_title: Slowest series I have ever seen
reviews.content:
I have never fallen asleep so many times during a series.
It is just too slow for me. And so silent as well.
The extra start because when it's on, (mostly during s1) it's quite exciting and thrilling.
S1 is ok, S2 is "meh", S3 is absolute nope.

If you are looking forward for a thriller that has strong characterisation, clever script and solid performances, take a ride with the fall.Allan Cubitt offers a dark and intense thriller which looks through dark shades of human minds. Without shading characters black and white, the script offer a deep insight into the vulnerabilities and strength of characters.Lead characters Gillian Anderson and Jamie Dornan did a really commendable job in portraying Gibson and Spector. The photography, editing and music perfectly blend with the storyline to provide an intense viewing.

I cannot believe how much I was impressed by Dornan and Andersen. Literally every body though acted so intensely and had those deep interior acting that is hard to find. But the eyes of Dornan and the voice of Andersen will haunt me.

Half way through season two. Thought Season 1 was excellent, but Season 2 is turgid. After episode 2 of the current run, they have enough evidence and opportunity to arrest and convict Spector ten times over - but the TV gods stop this happening, as they so obviously fancy getting a third season out of their this nonsense.
Other reviewers suggest it improves again in Season 3. I really hope this is the case!
Writers lost track of what they are writing! Characters lack depth, background or purpose!

reviews.review_title: Could have been so good (spoilers up to season 3)
reviews.content: Don't get me wrong, there are moments when this is edge of your seat but sitting here half way though season 3 and still wondering why this has not finished. So far in season 3, we have learnt nothing. No development. The amnesia plays for sympathy but actually nothing is happening. Slept though half an episode and didn't miss a thing!To me it would have been better (and more realistic) to finish with a couple more episodes in season one.The acting and cinematography is excellent. Just a shame about the rest.My recommendation! After season one you can fast forward and condense and not miss a lot.Here's hoping something happens in the second half of season 3
I'm in love with Stella. What a woman. Great show. Loved the dynamic with Stella & Spector

"... when you gaze long into the abyss. The abyss gazes also into you."
(Friedrich W. Nietzsche)

Bleak, dark and ultimately depressing. Each episode became a chore to watch, especially as the pace slowed to boredom. Not one of the main characters had any charm, like ability or realism about them. Potential dichotomy between Gibson as the social predatory v Spector came to nothing other than vile behaviour to children can and often expresses itself in later life behaviour in adulthood....to differing and extreme degrees. A lot of loose ends left inconclusive and in the end a wasted time watching. As someone who usually enjoys a good serial crime drama this was torture. This was in uncomfortable, boring and ultimately disturbing - certainly not enjoyable (or complete).

reviews.review_title: Not for the dreamy soft hearts
reviews.content: So dark and twisted plot.. full of all kinds of abuse and extremely clever.. Well done to everyone who participated in making such a brilliant series.. As a woman , Stella was my fav star ,but Paul deserved the whole sky.. So twisted characters I needed a break from watching.. and what an end!! I wanted more of the series but it was amazing in total.
A fantastic thriller. Not seen anything as good as this ever. Addictive and a must watch!!!

Gillian Anderson I started watching when the xfiles began. Jamie Dornan new to me but very talented! I started with the Fall & when I find a actor or actress I like I tend to follow there career. I don't tend to take about the series themselves as I fear I give too much away! All I will say is it is a must watch!!

This could have been a very good miniseries if it had played out in 4 to 6 episodes! Instead they water it down and stretch it like crazy to fit 18 episodes! It's absolutely preposterous and became tedious because so often they were just treading water and stretching things out!

reviews.review_title: If it weren't for Gillian, I'd give it a 5
reviews.content: The last season was disappointing. They drew it out for way too long, with very little rhyme or reason. I stopped caring about the characters, although Stella Gibson remained the strongest by far. There also seemed to be no new revelations after the first season. It became bland, boring and unrealistic.
10/10 for Gillian Andersen's role! I finished the series mainly because of her acting, though i really enjoyed seasons 1 and 2. But what on earth did we do to deserve season 3?!?! :((

Here is an excellent presentation of a misunderstood reality - that of Dissociative Identity Disorder (DID). But although hinting at a more primitive and compelling reality, The Fall still continues to ignore the real 'elephant in the room', that of spirit possession. The writer, Allan Cubitt is to be congratulated on his inspiration and courage to even hint at such a reality. One day all will be revealed in all its simplicity and then we will be able to treat it with science and genuine knowledge. Bravo Allan.

Well made, good acting, but too easy, riddled with mistakes and highly unlikely situations that just would not happen in the real world. Disappointing plot, waste of time. Could've been so much better.

Season 1 & 2 were very interesting but in season 3 it seems like their had no more ideas. Much of the plot was illogical for me. I can't understand why this series has such a good rating tbh.
But I liked the role of Stella very much, the actress did a very good job.

reviews.review_title: one of the best series I've ever watched
reviews.content:
Once you start you wont be a able to stop watching this amazing mysterious thriller! Super well directed!
Really enjoyed it!!

Started off well, then started to drag into series 2 , series 3 was boring and drawn out, those last 3 episodes were hard work.Gillian Anderson pouted too much and whispered through out the whole 3 series while clip clopping in high heals and swishing her hair. Overrated and Jamie although a good actor didn't give the look or feel of a serial killer
The whole story is discriminating white men. Nothing more to say I guess.

So this is not a who done it but it comes across that way. We pretty much know who done it right from the beginning. The series was very well done and kept me interested throughout the entire 3 seasons. I loved the way the wrapped the apparent common life into the killers way of life. The characters were well developed and I think all did a great job. At times some of the episodes went slowly but never slow enough to cause me to stop watching. I won't tell the ending but I have to say that I was a tad disappointed in it although I am not sure how else they would end it. So I would say if you need something to binge try it however I think it may be leaving netflix soon.

Overall a good crime show that has its lengths. Jamie Dornan is truly excellent, while the rest of the cast sometimes falls a little flat. Plot is interesting enough to keep one watching but season three drags along.

reviews.review_title: You feel every bit of it!
reviews.content: Watched the three seasons for the second time and relived it all like the first time. Yes it has its down times where we could have done well without, but Paul's twisted mind is what keeps us hanging there in the hopes of seeing him neutralized for good. Very good show.

reviews.review_title: The writer/ director might have s.thing in his mind but could not make it happen.
reviews.content: I liked the first and second seasons. Actually, I guess before the arrest of paul spector, everything was good but then suddenly, things became silly and naive! Despite the director's endeavor to dig into the characters in season 3, they remained shallow. I did not understand the role of Katie?! What happend in Gibson's childhood?! What did the murder of the police officer who had an affaire with Gibson in the first season add to the story?! And it seems that the director did not know how to end the movie?! He chose the simplest way! And it was frustrating, I guesse!

I have watched season 1 and s2e1. It is very good but I am confused. Following may be a spoiler. I thought Sally was not leaving Paul but she did. Why did he thank her in the scene where she was packing to move. Also, I don't know what "bell" is which was being left behind. The acting and directing are great. Gillian Anderson is great and is one of my favorites but she also has some great support from Dornan and Burns as well as the victims.
The killer never was handcuffed or guarded as he should have been at all time. This made the story unbelievable.

The guy in London (David) who was convicted for the murder back in the 2000's, he took the rap for Paul because he is in debt to Paul and I think they worked together. David is gonna be released and will commit new murders just like Paul's - Because they started it together.

From the first few minutes of "The Fall," I was taken. Characters are intriguing and believable, for the most part. I couldn't wait to watch the next episode. But then, like a real criminal investigation with too many loose ends, the story began to fall apart. I keep asking myself why certain clues weren't followed. I could have found the killer (well- played by Dornan) more quickly than the Belfast police.Why? As soon as Paul Spector went to the station to say he was at the park, why didn't the detective make a connection to the fact he was in and out of foster homes? Why didn't the police talk to his wife in person to verify his alibi? Shortly thereafter they had a drawing of his face hanging throughout the station and posted in the papers. Even the blonde on the train wasn't afraid. That's just silly. Why didn't the detective who interviewed him see the striking similarities? Why didn't Sally ask where her husband's car had gone to? There are many questions.I realize the story must be dragged out to keep viewers entertained, but as soon as there were glaring goofs or oversights by the characters, I realized this series was too good to be true. Shame... I'll keep watching, but I feel a bit frustrated and suckerpunched at this late stage in the episodes. Enjoy the show.

Intriguing characters, beautiful cinematography, realistic dialog and a good basic story all compelled me to watch the entire 2014 season. Gillian Anderson plays a calm, cool, and collected Superintendent DI who instills confidence with a splash of envy in all her police entourage as well as her audience. Jamie Dornan plays the egocentric criminal with modest arrogance, a contradiction that seems simply genuine. The story builds through character development, illuminating a common thread running between criminal and cop: the human need for achieving control. Both cop and criminal maintain low-key demeanors, making the pace of the show drag in some places, but creating an overall feeling of intensity that kept me on the edge of my seat. However, the story falters with several instances of questionable police protocol. I have never worked in a police department, but I doubt any police department would assign 10 to 20 plainclothes police to tail a suspect while, simultaneously, only 2 to 4 uniformed officers are available to respond to street crimes. Technical goofs like this make the whole story less plausible. Instead of "Deus ex machina", we have "cops do dumb stuff", allowing the author to add a new twist (or is it just stretching out the story?). More's the pity when a show this promising comes along. Next season, Mr. Cubitt, hire three technical consultants and make it real.

reviews.review_title: Flawed but it's worth watching..in this case everything before the but in the sentence!)
reviews.content:
This is a well produced series with a a great deal of tension. However, it is let down by a number of issues. Some poor casting of minor characters (plot based, you'll work out what I mean), though the acting performances are generally strong, although Anderson over eggs the pudding a bit with pouts and throaty voice from time to time . Unrealistic police procedure and behaviour had me criticising this out loud (to an audience of none, however. Boo Hoo).
Some unlikely character developments.(i) Check out that brat! (ii) Do inspired and admirable women who work in maternity wards behave like this?
Does the S.I.Officer have to wear inappropriate clothing in so many scenes. She looks more like a socialite kitted out for a string of cocktail parties rather than the tragic scenario that is playing out with a steady stream of bereaved and heart -broken relatives of the victims. At least we know she's not flat-footed. Does she have any self-control in her professional relationships? Surely her reputation would proceed her if in reality she behaved like this.
Having said all that , the actors do a very, very good job with the material.The technical aspects of the production are of a high quality.
All in all, it is a compelling series,but the characterisation of the killer's wife in particular left a bad taste. I couldn't help feeling that there could have been a way to leave her moral character intact. She to me was angelic to start and morally bankrupt to finish. She would have taken one look at the mugshot before adding it all up and shopping him immediately.
S1 & S2 were the best series I had seen in a very long time. S3 lots of yawning on my part and I fell asleep a few times. S1 & 2 11/10. S3 2/10

When deciding whether or not I should start this series, I was a little skeptical just because this main plot is a very common one. I absolutely loved Dexter, so I decided to try it out. Despite the basic similarities in the two titles, they are nothing alike. The Fall is definitely a very slow series, while Dexter seemed to keep me hooked with its fast paced intensity. After watching a couple of episodes of The Fall, I quit watching for a week or two, and almost gave up on it completely. I eventually decided to give it another chance, and am very happy that I did. Despite the many slow moments, there is an underlying feeling of extreme suspense. The game of cat and mouse kept me wondering how it would all turn out. The last two episodes, though, were definitely the best of the whole series. They had a much faster pace, and it seemed as if the ball was finally rolling. I do hope the tap into this for the next season(s).

reviews.review_title: Start of OK, gets good, then fails
reviews.content: There is a lot of good things to day about The Fall, fantastic acting photography through out. And an awesome bad buy! However, the three seasons are one one story and there are many scenes which although look good are just spun out and add nothing to the story. This is a kind of Netflix filler strategy which other production teams are now using. By halfway through the second series I am shouting at the TV screen at the obvious hints at the direction of the story - there's no surprises. Half way through the first episode of series three it's all over. I decide I am wasting my time. Condensing the whole story into a fast paced 6 episode series would saved this.

This series, so much we know from the tag line, is about a serial killer, and the female cop trying to catch him. The serial killer and his circumstances are presented with a chilling realism. To the outside world, a loving family man, a trusted counselor. Inside, a twisted mind. Now, serial killers are relatively rare, but you could easily liken him to a child abuser. Often times, those people similarly manage to fool everyone around them. Kids are even entrusted in their care, kids that will end up becoming their victims. There is such a sickening element in this alone that certain scenes of this series are difficult to bear.This also leads me to a word of warning for victims of abuse planning to watch this series (be it sexual, physical or mental abuse). You will likely be shaken up by the events taking place, and worst of all, there is no catharsis taking place here. The entire series so far - Season 1 & 2 - is very well made, showing realistic behaviour of both of the perpetrator and the police. And just like in real life, things go from bad to worse right under people's noses, but they realize it all too late. The viewer, helpless witness to what is happening, can only direct hateful expressions at the TV, or however you choose to deal with it. But there certainly is no happy ending in any of this. If you watch some of this before going to bed, you might be a bit worked up and have trouble falling asleep. I can only imagine that it must be worse for abuse victims watching this.So, for all its brilliance, for all its realism, it is also tough to watch at times. Please keep that in mind.Murderers, rapists, and other such people are often labeled "monsters" and "inhuman", he is called that in this series too. This, of course, is wrong. Instead of dehumanizing such people, the much more troubling realization is that they are very human in the end. If this series teaches us anything, it's that sometimes those people are living right amongst us. Ultimately, we can only counteract this with love, and watching out for any signs of people dear and near to us being in some kind of trouble, especially kids. They might experience something bad, and we must try to spot it and help them.8/10, absolutely gripping, well-made series with great attention to detail.

reviews.review_title: Philosophical, detailed and immersive. Tells everyones story.
reviews.content: A slow, unsettling and somewhat intimate thriller that explores almost every aspect of the process of crime, physical, spiritual and mental, the stages of investigation undertaken by the police, the interference of the media and how individual officers cope with these intrusion attempts. The show is extremely detailed in its approach to the little individual stories. It will give almost every character a 3 dimensional aspect as it tries to navigate through certain philosophies covered throughout the show. This show takes and remasters certain trends from other detective media, I've noticed similarity to Death Note, Silence of the Lambs, Twin peaks etc... and it will utilize these inspirations to create very entertaining episodes and cliffhangers.Sometimes the slowness can be overbearing. Often the director will linger on a closeup or a silence for too long after the audience already understands the intention of the scene. I suppose it's done to allow us to sit with new information for a while longer and empathize with how the character feels in that moment, but the technique feels overused throughout the series.It is very good overall and feels very well read and researched by the creators. The show can flip from detective thriller, to medical drama, to legal drama at a moments notice and takes its time to explore each of those genres and vocations and the individuals that perform them. It becomes more philosophical and psychological as the episodes go on, if you want to really explore and understand a character and explore trauma, PTSD and mental health, this may be the show for you.

It's so Irish it needs subtitles. The amount of poor unnecessary cinematography is enough to fill half a series and some of the acting is just question and answer. Which is yes or no questions. AAAARGH NOOOO. I'm sorry that Gillian Anderson wasn't strong enough to carry a plot and a whole cast of actors through this dreary film about one criminal and no court case. The hospital footage could have been completely left on the editing floor. Dismal

Certainly a lot of twists and turns that were unexpected.Overall I thought the acting was very good by everyone.Despite the overall depressing story - both main plot and numerous sub plots - it held my interest to the end.I took a point off my score for the stupid (IMHO) Catholic bashing.It references a home for boys in Belfast were alleged abuse of the wards of the state boys occurred by staff. The name is fictional and only one allusion to the home being Catholic was made - a "Father" somebody in charge.Shame on the producers - there was a real life organization Kincora Boys Home where alleged systematic abuse occurred. But this was a secular home staffed by Protestants and not Catholics - as Northern Ireland itself is occupied primarily now by English and Scottish Protestant colonists - and "native" Irish Catholics are a minority.

Series 1 has quite dark moments and is not a bad watch, series 2 is alright though not great and series 3 is just plain boring and pointless.I had heard good things about the series and seen a few clips which made Gillian Anderson's character seem intriguing however I was disappointed. They obviously want to make her a strong female lead and while I thought at the start she was going to be interesting to watch, I found her character underdeveloped and quite a hypocrite. She'll sleep with a subordinate yet from how she speaks about the macho police culture you'd expect her to not like a male officer treating lower ranked female officers like she does. Also there were some jarring moments when she just comes out with statements when it didn't seem to fit within the scene to what was happening - but it was a way to get across that kind of person she is. Don't get me wrong, it can be interesting to watch characters who are a mess, who you don't like or don't think are great people but it just came across as bad lazy writing and underdeveloped.I also disliked the male ranked police officer above her (forget the title, assistant something) as he was just permanently a mess and always looking nervous. I get he was somewhat of a side character but he was on enough that there could have been some development.When I first saw that there were three series I thought it would be three separate cases which I think would have been more interesting. By the end of the first series the killer isn't as scary and intriguing as you've gotten to know him more. And through the rest of the series you aren't intrigued to learn more or stay with him.There are also issues with continuing things which were revealed in previous seasons or introducing new things that just seem to be created for that series.For example, in series 1 Gillian Anderson's character records the killer on the phone and they talk for a decent amount of time. Yet in series 2 they are trying to confirm the killer is a specific person and they use a really short phone call recorded from that series, and the expert says it could be the killer but with such a short voice sample they can't be sure. What happened to the recorded call made in series 1? There's no mention of it.Also in series 3 there's one episode were they reveal the killer likes to dress in women's lingerie and they show all these photos of him that way. That was never mentioned before or since that episode and it just didn't seem to go or really add anything.

I have never written a review before on this site, but reading the recent reviews of this show frustrated me so much, so I had to set the record straight:This show is INCREDIBLE. I have never watched a crime drama with such a compelling female lead as this. I keep telling my friends about Gibson by describing her as a feminist/man-hater, but in a classy AF way. So many things she says are absolutely brilliant and made me fangirl to an extreme degree. She is strong and confident and questions a lot of preconceived notions a lot of us casually accept.The show is subtle and not especially flashy, but dark and beautiful. I cannot explain how much I enjoyed watching this show. If you are looking for a show with a strong female lead whom you will adore, WATCH THIS.

reviews.review_title: A nice crime series with loads of whispering.
reviews.content: Series are very interesting in the first two season. It gets a little slow on the last one. What bothers me is the unrealistic way Gillian Anderson speaks. She whispers all the time while everybody speaks at normal tones. This is weird and disturbing. She barely speaks in a normal volume. Why ?

reviews.review_title: so far this year best show I have seen
reviews.content: I am writing on my boyfriend's account however I just wanted to say I have seen the first season. Some people are right in that it does take a slow start, but it is the slow start with the big build up that makes it you wanting to watch more and more. If you like things that make you go WTF? did that just happen? I really like how dark the killer character is, and how far he will go. It is by far one of the best crime-dramas I have seen. I don't watch a lot of British shows and this one is one of the best. I suggest you watch this show. I finished it in a few days or so. the only draw back is that it is only eleven shows to the season. for now, and it is an hour long however it leaves you wanting to find out if they will catch the killer. I can't wait until season 2 comes out.
There are 3 or 4 films I remember and will never watch again because of the violence. This is one. I enjoyed it right up to the end and now I'm nauseous. And a little afraid to fall asleep.

The thing is I wasn't sure if it's because I live in Belfast or because I liked it. It was pretty good.... Jillian Anderson is a good actress and so is Jamie Dornan. I respect this show and glad it came to my attention in a new window years after it was released.

From a gripping first series, "The Fall" took a downward turn early in series 2. After deducing who the killer was, Gillian Anderson's character got a telling-off from her boss and they all decided to call it a night, instead of making an arrest, allowing the killer to evade them and get rid of lots of evidence. After this, the show descended into farce. Why leave a killer, who has confessed to a series of horrific murders, unguarded and unrestrained in the same hospital ward as his victim? Why leave him alone with the psychiatrist? Why all the pontification about fine art and literature? Why all the whispering? What became of the killer's accomplice, his family or his victims? For a show that seemed intent on fostering a sense of emotional investment in the characters, it's strange that it all ended so inconclusively.I find it hard to believe that the writer of this show was also one of the writers for the excellent "Prime Suspect". But perhaps stretching a single murder plot over 17 hours is too much for any writer.On the plus side, Gillian Anderson is attractive, and her English accent is convincing.

reviews.review_title: Great Season 1 but Flawed script in Season 2
reviews.content:
Such a shame as season 1 was great.
The flaws in the police investigation in not protecting 2 key witnesses from the killer is absurd. I had to turn it off at S2 episode 2 as it is unrealistic.
The school kid has more iq than the whole police force.

reviews.review_title: Really great just a rubbish ending
reviews.content: Me and my wife really enjoyed The Fall but we were both left very disappointed by the final episode. No spoilers but it just leaves to many holes to pick at. It feels like they needed to finish it that episode and they forgot to tie up a few key storyline aspects. A big shame of an ending and conclusion for a great tv series

While I've been a member of IMDB for many years, this is my first review, and I'm writing this out of sheer frustration. Gillian Anderson sounded more like a librarian than a police inspector. By the third season, her whispering became so annoying it was very difficult to finish the series. If not for subtitles, we wouldn't have understood a word she said. And while she may have lived in the UK, her accent (albeit whispered), did not sound authentic. In addition, it seems a story that could/should have concluded in one, or possibly two seasons, was dragged out to three, which made the third season especially frustrating, boring and monotonous. We made it to the end, but boy was it a struggle ....

reviews.review_title: Season 3 is a MASSIVE let down
reviews.content: I've had to write my first review after watching this as the 3rd season has so many flaws it's unbelievable.No security for a massive serial killer, one of victims in the same ward, nurse falling for him, Katie still cutting around Belfast without a care in the world after spraying her mate in the face with what could have been acid.This should have ended on season 2 but they've dragged this out massively and the the 3rd is just far too slow.

reviews.review_title: What happened after the second episode?
reviews.content: Only the first two episodes of this show are good. I was so excited I thought I found an exciting new thriller type show. But, after only the second episode the show completely changed into this overdone drama with one of the worst plots I've seen for a show recently. I can't believe I finished both seasons... But I did just binge-watch them all in a few days on Netflix. So dumb honestly don't know how it's so high rated. Gillian Anderson was okay in the show but that's about it. Very unbelievable random side stories that make no sense. Well at least the seasons were short. Thankfully though I heard season 3 is going to be the final one.

I started watching this show based on a friends recommendation. I can't stop watching. The storyline is fantastic and different from anything I've seen. The acting is great. Jamie Dornan's is stellar. I wish there was more.

reviews.review_title: Pretty good show, here's why (so far)
reviews.content: I'm currently on season two episode three of the series, and I've grown to find it quite enjoyable/intriguing. I like how they use a lot of real forensics techniques or facts. Like how they lift tire impressions, rigor mortis, ways to figure out the time of death, etc. they also mentioned facts about serial killers personalities, and how they can be charismatic, and blend in with society. also in the first episode I think, there is a very cool tracking shot from the ceiling, which followed the handsome actor, Jamie Dornan, from room to room. I'm sure the camera trick was probably used in plenty of movies and shows, but it was my first time seeing it, and it was pretty cool.

reviews.review_title: By far my favorite serial killer series
reviews.content: Gillian Anderson's character is everything I'd love to be. I love her grit and confidence. A very well done series. I wish there was more to come. I've watched the series through at least twice and will do again.
Formulaic predictable run of the mill. Some good castings but Gillian Anderson was poor and predictable. Such promise with lack in delivery. Worth a watch if you've exhausted all other good series.

I have just watched the final episode and I have to congratulate the BBC for yet another superior series in this field. I won't repeat the story line as others have done except to say I think some reviewers forget what they are reviewing, i.e. a production designed to entertain the viewer. This show certainly did that and Jamie Dornan was in my book, brilliant. His was a very difficult role especially the final episodes and he carried it brilliantly. Not so, however, was Gillian Anderson. I felt she overplayed the part of the female Chief Superintendent trying to outwit the serial killer. Helen Mirren would have been a better choice in my opinion. The writer also seemed to have quite a low opinion of the senior ranks in the police force as well as the DPP. Well worth watching.

The serial killer is NO Hannibal Lecter. And the actor who portrays the serial killer is NOT Anthony Hopkins. Hopkins made Lecter his. He made him likable, feel something. Spector does nothing for me. I even mute my TV when he is on.I'm only watching the show for Gillian Anderson, for me she is doing okay (I don't hear her British accent as I'm watching in french, so I can't judge). And about showing her cleavage, I see nothing wrong about it. What disturbs me the most is seeing the serial killer play the good father and cop. Apart from this, the pace is slow and it becomes boring. I'm waiting for the moment when the cops FINALLY arrests Spector.
Stella Gibson moves really slow in a slow good story with niet very intelligent chief commissionair

When I first decided to start the series I was like "Yeah, I love crime/detective shows. Can't wait". Now that I've finished it, I got all choked up and I'm like "Why didn't anyone warn me? I wasn't ready for that.." *cries silently*
It is a lot more than a crime/police drama. A must-watch that's for sure!!

reviews.review_title: Awesome season 1 and 2 not so much 3
reviews.content: They should have stopped on season 2. Seems like they're trying to drag a story which doesn't matter anymore. Still an awesome series!!!

reviews.review_title: I don't understand these high ratings!
reviews.content: I love a good British crime show but this is not it! It was so boring and literally none of the characters have any personality. I stuck it out for the first season hoping it'd get better but it doesn't!

The acting and photography in this production are both outstanding. The story demonstrates that serial killers are not unique to any one country. What is lacking in many areas is adequately trained and competent police to deal with them. In this case the Police Service of Northern Ireland seems perfectly capable of the task. The killer like many of his ilk has the ability to appear perfectly normal while committing abhorrent crimes. Spector who is seriously wounded during the final episode may well survive his wounds and perhaps escape? Will Supt.Gibson develop some warped (love hate) relationship with him? We must remember that he has read her diary and is aware of something dark in her past. Looking forward to season 3.

One of the rare tv-shows that almost doee everything right.Every role in this show is casted spot on. Tremendous acting by everyone.Overall an outstanding Tv show, can only recommend.Season 1 is the best
Season two is very good
Season 3 is good.

reviews.review_title: Gillian Anderson - a plank with a blonde wig
reviews.content: This is a polished, high production value series with good scripts, plot twists and pacing. Unfortunately Anderson stinks the whole thing into unwatchability.I don't understand how people rave about this series. 'Wooden' doesn't cover Anderson's performance. Wood has depth, character and shine. Anderson has one blank facial expression the whole show. She's more like MDF.Maybe it's supposed to suggest the deep troubled personality of her character, but it actually makes her look like a Stepford Wife. She might have heard of the concept of 'emotion' but only in the abstract. She's obviously never actually experienced one.Her voice throughout is similarly dead and monotonic. She delivers every line in the same loud whisper, without a hint of meaning, tone or timbre. All the other characters speak like real human beings. Anderson, however, sounds like she's permanently in a state of utter disconnection and boredom.She makes you want to lose the will to live. Every single line is delivered with the same flat "dur dur dur dur dur". It's like quietly and ponderously hitting a muffled drum for eternity.You can hear a hint of my Margaret Thatcher in the accent and delivery. Not the real person Thatcher, but the contrived, trained persona delivering a government message to the media. That same lack of empathy, conviction or giving a sh:t about whether what she's saying is true or not.I never thought much of her in the X-Files but at least Duchovny picked up half the slack as lead. Here she's left to completely ruin a potentially good series, because she's never off the screen long enough to enjoy it.I'm using this series as a litmus test for discernment and intelligence. Anyone who can bear watching Anderson for this long should save their licence fee and buy a Punch and Judy set.That's the way to do it Gilly:-(

We stopped watching at season 3...too boring to watch.
S1 and S2 were still doable.

Well, I can't believe I watched this until the end. It was a great story line and Gillian Anderson plays the part well. Factually accurate until season 3 and as for the ending, well what a disappointment. Why did no one try to resuscitate Spector? It's just a terribly disappointing ending to anotherwise excellent series.

reviews.review_title: Most of this was excellent ... not so much the last 3 episodes, though
reviews.content: I despair at some reviewers. I read one review that decried the fact that the killer is identified from the start so the whodunnit element is missing. It's not a whodunnit .! Don't watch if that's what you're looking for! If you have the attention span of a 4 year old and you want all action wise mouthed cops showing off then this isn't for you. For two and a half series this is a gripping thriller. It's well acted - I thought Aisling Franciosi was excellent flitting from vulnerable schoolgirl to vamp and back. There may have been a few holes in the plot but people make mistakes and things don't always go to plan so obsessing about those is an over-reaction in my view. My only gripe (and the reason I scored it with 8 stars and not more) was how slow it became in the last 3 episodes and I didn't like the ending. I'd still recommend it.

An advice I wish someone had given me: before you watch it, don't watch it.
It has nothing to show for. The personality of the main actress has nothing that is appealing to it, pacing of the events are excruciatingly slow. I was tempted by the high rating to continue watching when I should've listened to my own gut feeling and stopped watching after the first few episodes.
I love the fall, but it makes me think police in great Britain are quite inept 😂😂 it seems to be an English dramma thing... I wonder if it's real
Keeps you on the edge of your seat, very good acting and awesome story line.

I just finished the whole series.
This is my first review on this site, and probably the last one, too.
I expected that, after the end of the second season, a whole other story would begin. However, this did not happened, and I'm very pleased because of that.
Once again, I have never seen such a good thriller ever before.
This is really a masterpiece.

I started watching this a few years ago during season one and came back to it. I understand why American reviewers rate it lower--our worst national characteristic is impatience, and this drama moves very slowly and deliberately. We're used to everything getting wrapped up quickly. I have been watching it on Netflix (which now claims it) and find it very compelling, despite the measured pace. You get very deep inside the characters, and although it's easy to imagine what's coming next in many episodes, there are still twists that you don't expect. The characters are all well drawn, even some of the minor ones. I have watched many British crime dramas and am always looking for more. This one is a winner. As I have visited Northern Ireland, I can sense some of the issues that are only hinted at. But they are there. Well done, BBC.
This started so well but the end is just dreadful. The penultimate episode was tedious and the final episode was full off inconsistencies, leading up to a wholly unsatisfying finish.
I've enjoyed this series immensely. Gillian Anderson is amazing - so talented and beautiful. Brilliant cast and a gripping story.

I missed this originally so thought I'd watch it on Netflix but within first 10 minutes or so this has serious credibility issues
1) Armed officers in the UK do not go to burglary/intruder calls2) Those officers were not our firearms division3) Armed police don't drive the standard police patrol cars

Another serial killer made out to be super human, who is some kind of psychological expert, is 3 steps ahead of everyone, conveniently ex-military, and somehow gets into peoples houses and hotel rooms with ease.Spare me the calm speaking, suave and predictable invincibility of the antagonist. This has been done far too many times before and I yawn everytime he evades capture amongst the survellance of 30 police. The only plus is Gillian Andersons acting.

I really loved this series. But, watching the last episode, I got the impression that it was simply cut off. Like as if they decided to wrap it up. I was expecting to see him go to court. I'm pretty sure that there was a lot to base a 4th season, and was pretty disappointed with the ending.
Good story. Great directing and all the actors were great! I'm almost done streaming it all.
Absolutely the best psycho thriller I've seen in years! Great acting, great cliff hangers, very good casting. Loved every minute of it.

Set in Belfast, this BBC/RTE produced drama is one of the hidden gems in this golden age of television. A crime drama on a par with shows such as The Killing, The Night Of, American Crime, and the original Prime Suspect. A Met officer is seconded to the PSNI to capture an active serial killer in present-day Belfast. Jillian Anderson and Jamie Doran give outstanding performances in the lead roles, and a quality local supporting cast shine equally.Can't recommend this show highly enough.

Was on the edge of my seat watching this. Both Jillian Anderson and Jamie Dornan were amazing. The series follows Anderson as a police superintendent Gibson on loan to Belfast to assess a murder investigation that is stalled. The series moves back and forth juxtaposing what the principals are doing simultaneously. Character development is nuancedGibson is a beautiful woman who is successful in a man's world. She is cool, unapologetic, and in a pinch decisive and commanding. Jamie Doran as Paul is a doting dad by day and a homicidal stalker of a certain type of women by night. He flouts authority and somehow his wife has no inkling of who her husband is. Paul and Sally's daughter seems almost psychic. Are her night terrors just a stage or does she have some awareness of her daddy's hidden life?The supporting staff are strong. There are strong women in this series. The female officer who meets victim to be Sarah Kaye was a strong role. I also liked the pathologist. Paul's wife Sally There are a lot of loose ends, unanswered questions that perhaps will never be answered but real life has those. Hints of corruption and conspiracy that have nothing to do with the murders are presented but not resolved. We are used to programs that tie it all up in a neat package with a bow on top. In this program the box is there, but it is open and some of the contents have been left out.

After Breaking Bad it seemed there was no other series that had my attention including House of Cards. We stumbled on this series by accident and now can't stop watching. Anderson was a favorite of mine since the X-Files and takes on a similar serious persona in this series but different. The series does move slow at times, but definitely keeps your attention enough to want to see what happens on the next episode. Many of the main characters are Irish and sometimes the accent is hard to understand but the actor who plays the serial killer is stellar in his performance and keeps you wondering how in the world he is getting by without being caught. He is convincingly accurate in the personality of his character and found myself completely irritated that he wasn't caught sooner. Am wondering if this series will move Anderson on to chasing other despicable characters or if the series will continue with the present plot. Currently the series only has two seasons.

WARNING CONTAINS SPOILER ALERT; This show started off amazing; it was a new look into a crime TV show about a serial killer. What made this show different is the fact that we got to witness various view points during the show from the serial killer, his family, police/investigators, etc. I was intrigued at this idea and wasn't disappointed.However I feel like they rushed through this idea/plot. It only took one season for him to basically get caught, the next season was all about catching him & now the third is all about trying him in court. I feel like they should've slowed it down. Or at least started the next new season with another killer. I'm disappointed that we didn't get more time with him hunting his victims while police hunted him. This was the best part of the series and I've had to drag my feet through season 2&3.The only thing saving it (for me anyway) is the writing (for the most part). I was hoping that after he was caught that she would move onto a different killer & we would start all over again, but no. They want to drag this out. They had a great idea and decided to literally run with it way too fast in my opinion.

reviews.review_title: Excellent, great start and great end
reviews.content:
By far one of the series I ever saw. It shows how child abuse have a long effect on child life and will stay with child through his/ her adulthood. It shows how it's important to have more supervision on orphanage and child cares home and organization.
Great acts and scenario.

This is a great mystery drama. I binge watched the series it was so good. The only thing that irritates me was Anderson's very poor English accent. It sounded like she needed a cough drop or something.

Got be a story with ine season only
They made the story going too slow and added not solid side story to it.
When heard season 3 coming, thought is this a joke ?

Saw all the seasons and I absolutely love it. First of all I am a huge fan of Gillian Anderson(Stella Gibson) because she did an amazing job. I also liked her acting in X files and looks like the detective role suits her. Even Jamie( Paul Spector) nailed his character and overall the show was good,I am looking forward for the coming seasons in the future.

reviews.review_title: Intense and thrilling but not satisfying enough.
reviews.content: The first few episodes are very much thrilling and would not let you unhook from the scene. The kind of philosophy the protagonist is upholding is debatable. But the last season does not retain the same spirit as of the others. The ending makes it feel like 'now this has to end', that was boring taking into account the amount of thrill and suspense the other seasons gave.
The series throughout was actually a really good watch and definitely creates some interesting questions. The ending was not as mind-blowing as the hype suggested though.
The series was good apart from Gillian Anderson who seemed to whisper all the way through very annoying

This is my first ever review and I'm glad it's started with my thoughts about The Fall which in my eyes was the best thriller series ever. I thoroughly enjoyed this show, brilliant and believable acting, cast and storyline. I was gripped from start to finish and enjoyed the emotional journey this series took me on. The relationship between the two main characters Stella and Paul was enthralling, all the characters made the thriller jigsaw puzzle complete, there wasn't anything that I thought was surplus to the storyline. However, I do agree with a previous review in that I would of given 10/10 if they didn't end the last episode with a cliffhanger...I just needed one more scene to satisfy my appetite and tie up the loose ends but other than that it was truly excellent and I cannot recommend it enough!

I believed the killer but the cop was beyond unbelievable. First she is brought in from Scotland Yard to Belfast because she is so smart, yet she walks around with the dumbest look on her face the whole time. Supposed to be a serious look I assume but looks like a deer in the headlights to me. Like mouth open ummm what? I'm pretty sure only to prolong the complexity of the characters but really only the killer seems intelligent and interesting and developed . She discribes her knowledge and contempt for this killer and her intent to capture yet falls short so often and shows no strength of office at all! The final straw for me when I stopped caring was her silly attempt to save a known serial killer (confessed plus evidence) who had directed her to a kidnapped victim over an officer that had been shot as well! Don't get it! How does that compute? I mean if this guy dies won't they save so much money that early on they had to fund raise for to end this particular case?? I watched but clearly not happy about it.
All I have to say is fu..... protracted. And I never seen a police department so lousy..

I liked this show, as I usually like a good serial killer flick. My issue is with the policing. When does a person in the vicinity of a victim days or hours before the crime become a suspect? When does the news show this footage and say anyone that may have been at this place should turn themselves in? For what? Going to a public park the same day a victim did? Makes no sense. I may have been in a public place with someone who later was the victim of a violent crime. Do I need to go to police and provide an alibi, give my dna, and try to prove I had nothing to do with it? That's reaching. Besides the constant man hating, and seductive 15 year olds, I liked this show.

This is a very well written and shot series, with the perfect amount of tension within each episode. Each and every episode is in equal quality, shifting emphasis from either the story line or to the character struggles. Gillian Anderson acted simply superb. She brought a certain depth to the character. Jamie Dornan also did a splendid job, reminding me of Tom Hardy, not only physically, but also in his acting style.If I would need to compare The Fall to another series, it would have to be to Broadchurch. Although they are similar in tone, The Fall has more depth within its characters. There is not much knowledge about the characters given, but through the series, you catch how interconnected their lives are.
This show is so good. You never know what's going to happen next! Really well written.

I've never watched a series quite like this one. It is original and very well acted by Jamie Dornan. He is incredible in this series. I wasn't sure he could act after watching 50 Shades of Grey, but I have since changed my tune completely regarding his abilities. He played this role to perfection, in my opinion, of course. Gillian Anderson was very good as well. Her accent was a bit muddled in the first season, but she seemed to get it together better in season 2. I'm very much looking forward to seeing season 3. The story line is great and very suspenseful. I enjoyed watching things from the serial killers perspective while being hunted by the police. Jamie Dornan has created a thrilling darkness with his character and that's what made me want to continue watching. I'm not sure why they made three seasons with it. There's only 5 episodes in season 1 and 6 in season 2. This could have easily been wrapped up in two seasons and been more of a short series like Under the Dome. I am now a big fan of Jamie Dornan and I love his Irish accent. Very hot!

Despite the plethora of cop shows out there, there are very few of them that capture gritty realism and tell a story with a gripping, slow-burn pacing the way "The Fall" does. I like to compare it to the American cop show "The Killing," which has a similar vibe and pacing. Only thing that disappoints me, is the show's location. Belfast is a beautiful city that is rich in history, both tragic (Titanic and the Troubles) and inspirational (the Industrial Revolution, the recent peace and economic boom). But very few of Belfast's landmarks or neighborhoods are featured in the show, and very little of its history is reflected in the plot. The show might as well take place in any United Kingdom city and still not lose anything of value. Still, it is a small gripe and it does not take away from that fact that Belfast is becoming a place that's friendly to filmmakers and a hotbed for excellent actors.
